What does a conditional knowledge base entail? ††thanks: This work was partially supported by grant 351/89 from the Basic Research Foundation, Israel Academy of Sciences and Humanities and by the Jean and Helene Alfassa fund for research in Artificial Intelligence. Its final version was prepared while the first author was visiting the Laboratoire d’Informatique Théorique et de Programmation, Univ. Paris 6

Daniel Lehmann Department of Computer Science, Hebrew University, Jerusalem 91904 (Israel)    Menachem Magidor Department of Mathematics, Hebrew University, Jerusalem 91904 (Israel)
Abstract

This paper presents a logical approach to nonmonotonic reasoning based on the notion of a nonmonotonic consequence relation. A conditional knowledge base, consisting of a set of conditional assertions of the type if …then …, represents the explicit defeasible knowledge an agent has about the way the world generally behaves. We look for a plausible definition of the set of all conditional assertions entailed by a conditional knowledge base. In a previous paper [17], S. Kraus and the authors defined and studied preferential consequence relations. They noticed that not all preferential relations could be considered as reasonable inference procedures. This paper studies a more restricted class of consequence relations, rational relations. It is argued that any reasonable nonmonotonic inference procedure should define a rational relation. It is shown that the rational relations are exactly those that may be represented by a ranked preferential model, or by a (non-standard) probabilistic model. The rational closure of a conditional knowledge base is defined and shown to provide an attractive answer to the question of the title. Global properties of this closure operation are proved: it is a cumulative operation. It is also computationally tractable. This paper assumes the underlying language is propositional.

1 Introduction

1.1 Background

Inference is the process of achieving explicit information that was only implicit in the agent’s knowledge. Human beings are astoundingly good at infering useful and very often reliable information from knowledge that seems mostly irrelevant, sometimes erroneous and even self-contradictory. They are even better at correcting inferences they learn to be in contradiction with reality. It is already a decade now that Artificial Intelligence has realized that the analysis of models of such inferences was a major task.

Many nonmonotonic systems have been proposed as formal models of this kind of inferences. The best known are probably: circumscription [22], the modal systems of [23] and [24], default logic [29] and negation as failure [5]. An up-to-date survey of the field of nonmonotonic reasoning may be found in [30]. Though each of these systems is interesting per se, it is not clear that any one of them really captures the whole generality of nonmonotonic reasoning. Recently (see in particular the panel discussion of [36]) a number of researchers expressed their disappointment at existing systems and suggested that no purely logical analysis could be satisfactory.

This work tries to contradict this pessimistic outlook. It takes a purely logical approach, grounded in A. Tarski’s framework of consequence relations [35] and studies the very general notion of a sensible conclusion. It seems that this is a common ground that can be widely accepted: all reasonable inference systems draw only sensible conclusions. On the other hand, as will be shown, the notion of a sensible conclusion has a non-trivial mathematical theory and many interesting properties are shared by all ways of drawing sensible conclusions.

The reader is referred to [17] for a full description of background, motivation and the relationship of the present approach with previous work in Conditional Logic. We only wish to add here that, even though the present work will be compared explicitly only with previous work of E. Adams, some of the intuitions developed here are related with intuitions exposed already in the first works on Conditional Logic, such as [28] or [4]. The interested reader may find many relevant articles in [15] and should in particular look at [14]. The main difference between our approach and Conditional Logic is that we take the view that the truth of a conditional assertion is necessary, i.e., does not depend on the state of the world. For us, worlds give truth values to propositions but not to assertions, preferential models give truth values to assertions, but not to propositions. The models we propose are therefore much simpler than those previously proposed in Conditional Logic and it is doubtful whether they can shed light on the very complex questions of interest to the Conditional Logic community.

Notations and terminology conform with those of [17], but the present paper is essentially self-contained. Preliminary versions of part of the material contained in this paper appeared in [19, 18]. In [17] it was suggested that items of default, i.e., defeasible information should be represented as conditional assertions, i.e., pairs of formulas. For example, the information that birds normally fly will be represented by the conditional assertion b𝑏bitalic_b  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ f𝑓fitalic_f, where b𝑏bitalic_b and f𝑓fitalic_f are propositional variables representing being a bird and flying respectively. A set (finite or infinite) of conditional assertions is called a conditional knowledge base (knowledge base, in short) and represents the defeasible knowledge an agent may have. The fundamental question studied in this paper is the following: given a knowledge base K, what are the conditional assertions that should be considered as entailed, i.e., logically implied, by K? We consider that an assertion α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β should be entailed by K if, on the basis of the defeasible information contained in K and knowing that the proposition α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is true, it would be sensible to conclude (defeasibly) that β𝛽\betaitalic_β is true.

The question asked in the title and detailed just above has no simple answer and has probably no unique answer good for everyone in every situation. It may well be the case that, in different situations or for different domains of knowledge, the pragmatically right answers to the question of the title differ. This feeling has been recently expressed in [9]. The first part of this paper defines the notion of a rational set of assertions and defends the thesis that any reasonable answer to the question of the title must consist of such a set of assertions.

Thesis 1

The set of assertions entailed by any set of assertions is rational.

The second part of the paper describes a specific construction, rational closure, and shows that the rational closure of a set of assertions is rational. This construction is then studied and its value as an answer to the question of the title assessed. We think that, in many situations, this is an acceptable answer, but do not claim that it provides an answer suitable to any situation. We have just argued that such an answer probably does not exist. One of the main interests of the rational closure construction is that it provides a proof of the existence of some uniform, well-behaved and elegant way of answering the question. In doing so, we develop criteria by which to judge possible answers. We shall in particular consider properties of the mapping from K to the set of all the assertions it entails and prove that our construction of the rational closure satisfies them. This effort and these results have to be compared with the essential absence, for the moment, of similar results about the systems of nonmonotonic reasoning mentioned above.

1.2 Plan of this paper

We survey here the main parts of this paper. The introductions to the different sections contain a detailed description. Section 2 is devoted to preferential consequence relations. This family of relations was defined and studied in [17]. The first part of this section mainly recalls definitions and results of [17], its last part presents deep new technical results on preferential entailment that will be used in the sequel, but it may be skipped on a first reading. Section 3 presents the restricted family of relations that is of interest to us: rational relations. This family was first defined, but not studied, in [17, Section 5.4]. The main result of this section is a representation theorem characterizing rational relations in terms of ranked models. Section 4 shows that entailment with respect to ranked models is exactly entailment with respect to preferential models and provides an alternative proof of E. Adams’ [1] characterization of preferential entailment in terms of his probabilistic semantics. Appendix B describes a family of models based on non-standard (in the sense of A. Robinson) probability models and shows that these models provide another exact representation for rational consequence relations. This provides us with a strong justification for considering rational relations. Section 5 draws on all previous sections and is the heart of this paper. It proposes an answer to the question of the title. The notion of rational closure is first defined abstractly and global properties proved. It is then showed that finite knowledge bases have a rational closure and a model-theoretic construction is provided. An efficient algorithm is proposed for computing the rational closure of a finite knowledge base. We then discuss some examples, remark that rational closure does not provide for inheritance of generic properties to exceptional classes, and finally propose a second thesis.

2 Preferential relations and models

2.1 Introduction

The first part of this section, i.e., Sections 2.2–2.3, recalls definitions and results of [17] and provides an example (new) of a preferential relation that cannot be defined by a well-founded model. Then, in Section 2.4, the definition and some properties of preferential entailment are recalled from [17] and some new remarks included. Preferential entailment is a fundamental notion that is used throughout the paper. The last three sections are essentially independent of each other. They present an in-depth study of preferential entailment. In a first reading, they should probably be read only cursorily. The results of Section 2.5 expand on part of [18] and are used in Section 4.2. Section 2.6 presents a new technique to study preferential entailment (i.e., ranking). It is fundamental from Section 5.6 and onwards. Section 2.7 shows that preferential entailment is in the class co-NP, and hence is an co-NP-complete problem. A preliminary version of this last result appeared in [18].

2.2 Preferential relations

Our first step must be to define a language in which to express the basic propositions. In this paper Propositional Calculus is chosen. Let ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L be the set of well formed propositional formulas (thereafter formulas) over a set of propositional variables. If the set of propositional variables chosen is finite, we shall say that ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L is logically finite. The classical propositional connectives will be denoted by ¬,∨,∧,→→\neg,\vee,\wedge,\rightarrow¬ , ∨ , ∧ , → and ↔↔\leftrightarrow↔. The connective →→\rightarrow→ therefore denotes material implication. Small Greek letters will be used to denote formulas.

A world is an assignment of truth values to the propositional variables. The set 𝒰𝒰{\cal U}caligraphic_U is the set of all worlds. The satisfaction of a formula by a world is defined as usual. The notions of satisfaction of a set of formulas, validity of a formula and satisfiability of a set of formulas are defined as usual. We shall write ⊧αmodelsabsent𝛼\models\alpha⊧ italic_α if α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is valid, i.e., iff ∀u∈𝒰for-all𝑢𝒰\forall u\in{\cal U}∀ italic_u ∈ caligraphic_U, u⊧αmodels𝑢𝛼u\models\alphaitalic_u ⊧ italic_α.

If α𝛼\alphaitalic_α and β𝛽\betaitalic_β are formulas then the pair α⁢ ∼ ⁢β𝛼 ∼ 𝛽\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\betaitalic_α ∼ italic_β (read “from α𝛼\alphaitalic_α sensibly conclude β𝛽\betaitalic_β”) is called a conditional assertion. A conditional assertion is a syntactic object to which the reader may attach any meaning he wants, but the meaning we attach to such an assertion, and against which the reader should check the logical systems to be presented in the upcoming sections, is the following: if α𝛼\alphaitalic_α represents the information I have about the true state of the world, I will jump to the conclusion that β𝛽\betaitalic_β is true. A conditional knowledge base is any set of conditional assertions. Typically it is a finite set, but need not be so. Conditional knowledge bases seem to provide a terse and versatile way of specifying defeasible information. They correspond to the explicit information an agent may have.

Certain well-behaved sets of conditional assertions will be deemed worthy of being called consequence relations. We shall use the notation usual for binary relations to describe consequence relations. So, if  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ is a consequence relation, α⁢ ∼ ⁢β𝛼 ∼ 𝛽\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\betaitalic_α ∼ italic_β indicates that the pair ⟨α,β⟩𝛼𝛽\langle\alpha,\beta\rangle⟨ italic_α , italic_β ⟩ is in the consequence relation  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ and α⁢  ≁ ⁢β𝛼  ≁ 𝛽\alpha\mbox{ $\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim$ }\betaitalic_α ≁ italic_β indicates it is not in the relation. Consequence relations correspond to the implicit information an intelligent agent may have. Consequence relations are typically infinite sets.

Certain especially interesting properties of sets of conditional assertions (i.e., binary relations on ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L) will be described and discussed now. They are presented in the form of inference rules. Consequence relations are expected to satisfy those properties.

⊧α↔β,α ∼ γβ⁢ ∼ ⁢γ(𝐋𝐞𝐟𝐭⁢𝐋𝐨𝐠𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐥⁢𝐄𝐪𝐮𝐢𝐯𝐚𝐥𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐞){{\models\alpha\leftrightarrow\beta\ \ ,\ \ \alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma}\over{\beta\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma}}\hskip 15.6491pt{\rm({\bf Left\ Logical\ Equivalence})}divide start_ARG ⊧ italic_α ↔ italic_β , italic_α ∼ italic_γ end_ARG start_ARG italic_β ∼ italic_γ end_ARG ( bold_Left bold_Logical bold_Equivalence ) (1)
⊧α→β,γ ∼ αγ⁢ ∼ ⁢β(𝐑𝐢𝐠𝐡𝐭⁢𝐖𝐞𝐚𝐤𝐞𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐠){{\models\alpha\rightarrow\beta\ \ ,\ \ \gamma\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\alpha}\over{\gamma\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\beta}}\hskip 17.07182pt{\rm({\bf Right\ Weakening})}divide start_ARG ⊧ italic_α → italic_β , italic_γ ∼ italic_α end_ARG start_ARG italic_γ ∼ italic_β end_ARG ( bold_Right bold_Weakening ) (2)
α⁢ ∼ ⁢α(𝐑𝐞𝐟𝐥𝐞𝐱𝐢𝐯𝐢𝐭𝐲)𝛼 ∼ 𝛼𝐑𝐞𝐟𝐥𝐞𝐱𝐢𝐯𝐢𝐭𝐲\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\alpha\hskip 82.51282pt{\rm({\bf Reflexivity})}italic_α ∼ italic_α ( bold_Reflexivity ) (3)
α ∼ β,α ∼ γα⁢ ∼ ⁢β∧γ(𝐀𝐧𝐝){{\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\beta\ \ ,\ \ \alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma}\ \ \ \over{\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\beta\wedge\gamma}}\hskip 22.76228pt{\rm({\bf And})}divide start_ARG italic_α ∼ italic_β , italic_α ∼ italic_γ end_ARG start_ARG italic_α ∼ italic_β ∧ italic_γ end_ARG ( bold_And ) (4)
α ∼ γ,β ∼ γα∨β⁢ ∼ ⁢γ(𝐎𝐫){{\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma\ \ ,\ \ \beta\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma}\over{\alpha\vee\beta\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma}}\hskip 32.72049pt{\rm({\bf Or})}divide start_ARG italic_α ∼ italic_γ , italic_β ∼ italic_γ end_ARG start_ARG italic_α ∨ italic_β ∼ italic_γ end_ARG ( bold_Or ) (5)
α ∼ β,α ∼ γα∧β⁢ ∼ ⁢γ(𝐂𝐚𝐮𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐮𝐬⁢𝐌𝐨𝐧𝐨𝐭𝐨𝐧𝐢𝐜𝐢𝐭𝐲){{\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\beta\ \ ,\ \ \alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma}\over{\alpha\wedge\beta\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma}}\hskip 32.72049pt{\rm({\bf Cautious\ Monotonicity})}divide start_ARG italic_α ∼ italic_β , italic_α ∼ italic_γ end_ARG start_ARG italic_α ∧ italic_β ∼ italic_γ end_ARG ( bold_Cautious bold_Monotonicity ) (6)
Definition 1

A set of conditional assertions that satisfies all six properties above is called a preferential consequence relation.

A more leisurely introduction with motivation may be found in [17] where a larger family of consequence relations, that of cumulative relations, was also studied. This family is closely related to the cumulative inference operations studied by D. Makinson in [21]. The attentive reader of [17] may have noticed that, there, we reserved ourselves an additional degree of freedom, that we have denied ourselves here. There, we allowed 𝒰𝒰{\cal U}caligraphic_U to be a subset of the set of all worlds and considered the ⊧models\models⊧ symbol appearing in Left Logical Equivalence and in Right Weakening to be interpreted relatively to this subset. This was felt necessary to deal with hard constraints. In this work, we shall suppose that a hard constraint α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is interpreted as the soft constraint, i.e., the assertion, ¬⁢α𝛼\neg\alpha¬ italic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ false, which was recognized as equivalent to considering 𝒰𝒰{\cal U}caligraphic_U to be the set of all worlds satisfying α𝛼\alphaitalic_α in [17, page 174]. The second proposal there, i.e., to consider α𝛼\alphaitalic_α to be part of the facts, would not be consistent with our treatment of rational closure.

For the reader’s ease of mind we shall mention two important derived rules. Both S and Cut are satisfied by any preferential relation.

α∧β⁢ ∼ ⁢γα⁢ ∼ ⁢β→γ(𝐒)𝛼𝛽 ∼ 𝛾→𝛼 ∼ 𝛽𝛾𝐒{{\alpha\wedge\beta\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma}\over{\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\>\beta\rightarrow\gamma}}\hskip 62.59596pt{\rm({\bf S})}divide start_ARG italic_α ∧ italic_β ∼ italic_γ end_ARG start_ARG italic_α ∼ italic_β → italic_γ end_ARG ( bold_S ) (7)
α∧β ∼ γ,α ∼ βα⁢ ∼ ⁢γ(𝐂𝐮𝐭){{\alpha\wedge\beta\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma\ \ ,\ \ \alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\beta}\over{\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma\;}}\hskip 22.76228pt{\rm({\bf Cut})}divide start_ARG italic_α ∧ italic_β ∼ italic_γ , italic_α ∼ italic_β end_ARG start_ARG italic_α ∼ italic_γ end_ARG ( bold_Cut ) (8)

The rule of Cut is presented here in a form that is not the most usual one. Notice, in particular, that we require the left-hand side of the second assumption to be part of the left-hand side of the first assumption. This version of Cut is close to the original form proposed by G. Gentzen. The following form, more usually used now, is not acceptable since it implies monotonicity.

α∧β ∼ γ,α′ ∼ βα∧α′⁢ ∼ ⁢γ{{\alpha\wedge\beta\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma\ \ ,\ \ \alpha^{\prime}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\beta}\over{\alpha\wedge\alpha^{\prime}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma\;}}divide start_ARG italic_α ∧ italic_β ∼ italic_γ , italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ italic_β end_ARG start_ARG italic_α ∧ italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ italic_γ end_ARG (9)

2.3 Preferential models and representation theorem

The following definitions are also taken from [17] and justified there. We shall define a class of models that we call preferential since they represent a slight variation on those proposed in [33]. The differences are nevertheless technically important.

Preferential models give a model-theoretic account of the way one performs nonmonotonic inferences. The main idea is that the agent has, in his mind, a partial ordering on possible states of the world. State s𝑠sitalic_s is less than state t𝑡titalic_t, if, in the agent’s mind, s𝑠sitalic_s is preferred to or more natural than t𝑡titalic_t. The agent is willing to conclude β𝛽\betaitalic_β from α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, if all most natural states that satisfy α𝛼\alphaitalic_α also satisfy β𝛽\betaitalic_β.

Some technical definitions are needed. Let U𝑈Uitalic_U be a set and ≺precedes\prec≺ a strict partial order on U𝑈Uitalic_U, i.e., a binary relation that is antireflexive and transitive.

Definition 2

Let V⊆U𝑉𝑈V\subseteq Uitalic_V ⊆ italic_U. We shall say that t∈V𝑡𝑉t\in Vitalic_t ∈ italic_V is minimal in V𝑉Vitalic_V iff there is no s∈V𝑠𝑉s\in Vitalic_s ∈ italic_V, such that s≺tprecedes𝑠𝑡s\prec titalic_s ≺ italic_t. We shall say that t∈V𝑡𝑉t\in Vitalic_t ∈ italic_V is a minimum of V𝑉Vitalic_V iff for every s∈V,s≠tformulae-sequence𝑠𝑉𝑠𝑡s\in V,s\neq titalic_s ∈ italic_V , italic_s ≠ italic_t, we have t≺sprecedes𝑡𝑠t\prec sitalic_t ≺ italic_s.

Definition 3

Let V⊆U𝑉𝑈V\subseteq Uitalic_V ⊆ italic_U. We shall say that V𝑉Vitalic_V is smooth iff  ∀t∈Vfor-all𝑡𝑉\forall t\in V∀ italic_t ∈ italic_V, either ∃s𝑠\exists s∃ italic_s minimal in V𝑉Vitalic_V, such that s≺tprecedes𝑠𝑡s\prec titalic_s ≺ italic_t or t𝑡titalic_t is itself minimal in V𝑉Vitalic_V.

We may now define the family of models we are interested in.

Definition 4

A preferential model W𝑊Witalic_W is a triple ⟨S,l,≺⟩𝑆𝑙precedes\langle S,l,\prec\rangle⟨ italic_S , italic_l , ≺ ⟩ where S𝑆Sitalic_S is a set, the elements of which will be called states, l:S↦𝒰normal-:𝑙maps-to𝑆𝒰l:S\mapsto{\cal U}italic_l : italic_S ↦ caligraphic_U assigns a world to each state and ≺precedes\prec≺ is a strict partial order on S𝑆Sitalic_S satisfying the following smoothness condition: ∀α∈Lfor-all𝛼𝐿\forall\alpha\in L∀ italic_α ∈ italic_L, the set of states α^=def{s∣s∈S,s⁢ ≡α}superscriptnormal-defnormal-^𝛼conditional-set𝑠formulae-sequence𝑠𝑆𝑠 𝛼\widehat{\alpha}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}\{s\mid s\in S,\>s\hskip 2.27621pt\rule[-2.84526pt]{0.28453pt}{11.38109pt}\equiv\alpha\}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP { italic_s ∣ italic_s ∈ italic_S , italic_s ≡ italic_α } is smooth, where  ≡ absent\hskip 2.27621pt\rule[-2.84526pt]{0.28453pt}{11.38109pt}\equiv≡ is defined as s⁢ ≡α𝑠 𝛼s\hskip 2.27621pt\rule[-2.84526pt]{0.28453pt}{11.38109pt}\equiv\alphaitalic_s ≡ italic_α (read s𝑠sitalic_s satisfies α𝛼\alphaitalic_α) iff l⁢(s)⊧αmodels𝑙𝑠𝛼l(s)\models\alphaitalic_l ( italic_s ) ⊧ italic_α. The model W𝑊Witalic_W will be said to be finite iff S𝑆Sitalic_S is finite. It will be said to be well-founded iff ⟨S,≺⟩𝑆precedes\langle S,\prec\rangle⟨ italic_S , ≺ ⟩ is well-founded, i.e., iff there is no infinite descending chain of states.

The smoothness condition is only a technical condition. It is satisfied in any well-founded preferential model, and, in particular, in any finite model. When the language ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L is logically finite, we could have limited ourselves to finite models and forgotten the smoothness condition. Nevertheless, Lemma 1 will show that, in the general case, for the representation result of Theorem 1 to hold we could not have required preferential models to be well-founded. The requirement that the relation ≺precedes\prec≺ be a strict partial order has been introduced only because such models are nicer and the smoothness condition is easier to check on those models, but the soundness result is true for the larger family of models, where ≺precedes\prec≺ is just any binary relation (Definitions 2 and 3 also make sense for any binary relation ≺precedes\prec≺). In such a case, obviously, the smoothness condition cannot be dropped even for finite models. The completeness result holds, obviously, also for the larger family, but is less interesting.

We shall now describe the consequence relation defined by a model.

Definition 5

Suppose a model W=⟨S,l,≺⟩𝑊𝑆𝑙precedesW=\langle S,l,\prec\rangleitalic_W = ⟨ italic_S , italic_l , ≺ ⟩ and α,β∈L𝛼𝛽𝐿\alpha,\beta\in Litalic_α , italic_β ∈ italic_L are given. The consequence relation defined by W𝑊Witalic_W will be denoted by  ∼Wsubscriptsimilar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}∼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and is defined by: α⁢  ∼W ⁢β𝛼  ∼W 𝛽\alpha\mbox{ $\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}$ }\betaitalic_α ∼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β iff for any s𝑠sitalic_s minimal in α^normal-^𝛼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG, s⁢ ≡β𝑠 𝛽s\hskip 2.27621pt\rule[-2.84526pt]{0.28453pt}{11.38109pt}\equiv\betaitalic_s ≡ italic_β.

If α⁢  ∼W ⁢β𝛼  ∼W 𝛽\alpha\mbox{ $\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}$ }\betaitalic_α ∼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β we shall say that the model W𝑊Witalic_W satisfies the conditional assertion α⁢ ∼ ⁢β𝛼 ∼ 𝛽\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\betaitalic_α ∼ italic_β, or that W𝑊Witalic_W is a model of α⁢ ∼ ⁢β𝛼 ∼ 𝛽\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\betaitalic_α ∼ italic_β.

The following theorem characterizes preferential consequence relations.

Theorem 1 (Kraus, Lehmann and Magidor)

A binary relation  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ on ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L is a preferential consequence relation iff it is the consequence relation defined by some preferential model. If the language ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L is logically finite, then every preferential consequence relation is defined by some finite preferential model.

The next result shows we could not have restricted ourselves to well-founded models.

Lemma 1

There is a preferential relation that is defined by no well-founded preferential model.

Proof: Let ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L be the propositional calculus on the variables pi,i∈ωsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑖𝜔p_{i},i\in\omegaitalic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i ∈ italic_ω (ω𝜔\omegaitalic_ω is the set of natural numbers). We shall consider the model W=def⟨V,l,≺⟩superscriptdef𝑊𝑉𝑙precedesW\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}\langle V,l,\prec\rangleitalic_W start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP ⟨ italic_V , italic_l , ≺ ⟩ where V𝑉Vitalic_V is the set {si∣i∈ω∪{∞}}conditional-setsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑖𝜔\{s_{i}\mid i\in\omega\cup\{\infty\}\}{ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ italic_i ∈ italic_ω ∪ { ∞ } }, si≺sjprecedessubscript𝑠𝑖subscript𝑠𝑗s_{i}\prec s_{j}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≺ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT iff i>j𝑖𝑗i>jitalic_i > italic_j (i.e., there is an infinite descending chain of states with a bottom element) and l⁢(si)⁢(pj)𝑙subscript𝑠𝑖subscript𝑝𝑗l(s_{i})(p_{j})italic_l ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is true iff j≥i𝑗𝑖j\geq iitalic_j ≥ italic_i, for i∈ω∪{∞}𝑖𝜔i\in\omega\cup\{\infty\}italic_i ∈ italic_ω ∪ { ∞ } and j∈ω𝑗𝜔j\in\omegaitalic_j ∈ italic_ω. The smoothness property is satisfied since the only subsets of V𝑉Vitalic_V that do not have a minimum are infinite sets A𝐴Aitalic_A that do not contain s∞subscript𝑠s_{\infty}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and any α∈L𝛼𝐿\alpha\in Litalic_α ∈ italic_L that is satisfied in all states of such a set A𝐴Aitalic_A is also satisfied in s∞subscript𝑠s_{\infty}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The model W𝑊Witalic_W defines a preferential relation  ∼Wsubscriptsimilar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}∼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that ∀i∈ωfor-all𝑖𝜔\forall i\in\omega∀ italic_i ∈ italic_ω , pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT  ∼Wsubscriptsimilar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}∼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT pi+1subscript𝑝𝑖1p_{i+1}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and pi+1subscript𝑝𝑖1p_{i+1}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT  ∼Wsubscriptsimilar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}∼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ¬⁢pisubscript𝑝𝑖\neg p_{i}¬ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, but p0subscript𝑝0p_{0}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT  ≁Wsubscriptnot-similar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}{\not\sim}_{W}≁ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT false. But clearly, any preferential model defining such a relation must contain an infinite descending chain of states.     

We do not know of any direct characterization of those relations that may be defined by well-founded preferential models. But Lemma 3 will show that many relations may be defined by well-founded preferential models. It is clear, though, that the canonical preferential model provided by the proof of Theorem 1 is rarely well-founded. Consider, for example, the preferential closure of the empty knowledge base on a logically infinite language ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L. It may be defined by some well-founded preferential model (the order ≺precedes\prec≺ is empty). But its canonical model is not well-founded (consider states whose second components are larger and larger disjunctions). We may only make the following obvious remark: if the underlying language ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L is logically finite, then all canonical models are well-founded.

2.4 Preferential entailment

Now that we have a proof-theoretic definition of a class of relations, a class of models and a representation theorem relating them, it is natural to put down the following definition. It will serve us as a first approximate answer to the question of the title.

Definition 6

The assertion 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A is preferentially entailed by K iff it is satisfied by all preferential models of K. The set of all conditional assertions that are preferentially entailed by K will be denoted by 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The preferential consequence relation 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is called the preferential closure of K.

In [17] it was noted that the characterization of preferential consequence relations obtained in Theorem 1 enables us to prove the following.

Theorem 2

Let K be a set of conditional assertions, and 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A a conditional assertion. The following conditions are equivalent:

  1. 1.

    𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A is preferentially entailed by K, i.e., 𝒜∈𝐊p𝒜superscript𝐊𝑝{\cal A}\in{\bf K}^{p}caligraphic_A ∈ bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

  2. 2.

    𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A has a proof from K in the system P consisting of the Rules 1 to 6.

The following compactness result follows.

Corollary 1 (compactness)

K preferentially entails 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A iff a finite subset of K does.

The following also follows from Theorem 2.

Corollary 2

The set 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, considered as a consequence relation, is a preferential consequence relation, therefore there is a preferential model that satisfies exactly the assertions of 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. If K is itself a preferential consequence relation then 𝐊=𝐊p𝐊superscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}={\bf K}^{p}bold_K = bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The set 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT grows monotonically with K.

We see that the operation 𝐊↦𝐊pmaps-to𝐊superscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}\mapsto{\bf K}^{p}bold_K ↦ bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a compact monotonic consequence operation in the sense of Tarski [35]. We have a particular interest in finite knowledge bases. It is therefore useful to put down the following definition.

Definition 7

A preferential consequence relation is finitely generated iff it is the preferential closure of a finite knowledge base.

Lemma 3 will show that finitely generated relations have interesting properties. In [17], it was shown that any preferential relation defines a strict ordering on formulas by: α<β𝛼𝛽\alpha<\betaitalic_α < italic_β iff α𝛼\alphaitalic_α∨\vee∨β𝛽\betaitalic_β ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ α𝛼\alphaitalic_α and α𝛼\alphaitalic_α∨\vee∨β𝛽\betaitalic_β  ≁not-similar-to absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim≁ β𝛽\betaitalic_β.

Definition 8

A preferential relation is well-founded iff the strict ordering relation <<< it defines is well-founded.

The following is easy to show.

Lemma 2

A preferential relation is well-founded iff the canonical model built in the proof of Theorem 1 is well-founded.

We noticed, at the end of Section 2.3, that not all preferential relations that may be defined by well-founded preferential models are well-founded.

Lemma 3

Any finitely generated preferential relation is defined by some well-founded preferential model.

Proof: Let K be any finite set of assertions. Let Li,i∈ωsubscript𝐿𝑖𝑖𝜔L_{i},i\in\omegaitalic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i ∈ italic_ω be an infinite sequence of larger and larger logically finite sublanguages of L𝐿Litalic_L such that every Lisubscript𝐿𝑖L_{i}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains all the formulas appearing in the assertions of K and such that L𝐿Litalic_L is the union of the Lisubscript𝐿𝑖L_{i}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT’s. By Theorem 1, for each i𝑖iitalic_i there is a finite preferential model Wi′subscriptsuperscript𝑊′𝑖W^{\prime}_{i}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that defines the preferential closure of K over Lisubscript𝐿𝑖L_{i}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let Wisubscript𝑊𝑖W_{i}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the finite preferential model (over L𝐿Litalic_L) obtained by extending the labeling function of Wi′subscriptsuperscript𝑊′𝑖W^{\prime}_{i}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to the variables of L−Li𝐿subscript𝐿𝑖L-L_{i}italic_L - italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in some arbitrary way. Clearly Wisubscript𝑊𝑖W_{i}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a preferential model of K. Let W𝑊Witalic_W be the structure obtained by putting all the Wisubscript𝑊𝑖W_{i}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT’s one alongside the other (the partial ordering ≺precedes\prec≺ on W𝑊Witalic_W never relates states belonging to Wisubscript𝑊𝑖W_{i}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT’s with different i𝑖iitalic_i’s). The structure W𝑊Witalic_W is well-founded, therefore satisfies the smoothness condition and is a preferential model. Any assertion that is preferentially entailed by K (over L𝐿Litalic_L) is satisfied by every Wisubscript𝑊𝑖W_{i}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and is therefore satisfied by W𝑊Witalic_W. For any assertion 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A that is not preferentially entailed by K  one may find a language Lisubscript𝐿𝑖L_{i}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT large enough to include the formulas of 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A. Over Lisubscript𝐿𝑖L_{i}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the assertion 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A is not preferentially entailed by K, by Theorem 2, since a proof in the small language is a proof in the larger one. Therefore Wi′subscriptsuperscript𝑊′𝑖W^{\prime}_{i}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT does not satisfy 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A. We conclude that Wisubscript𝑊𝑖W_{i}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT does not satisfy 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A and that W𝑊Witalic_W does not satisfy 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A.     

2.5 Some properties of preferential entailment

The following result, Theorem 3, is new. It is important for several reasons. It uses the semantic representation of Theorem 1 and a direct proof using only proof-theoretic arguments seems difficult. It will be used in Section 4.2. Its Corollary 3 should provide a starting point for the application to preferential entailment of methods based on or related to resolution. First a definition.

Definition 9

If a formula α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is such that α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ≁not-similar-to absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim≁ false, we shall say that α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is consistent (for the consequence relation  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ). A formula is consistent for a model iff it is consistent for the consequence relation defined by the model, or equivalently iff there is a state in the model that satisfies α𝛼\alphaitalic_α.

We shall now define a basic operation on preferential models. Suppose M𝑀Mitalic_M is a preferential model ⟨V,l,≺⟩𝑉𝑙precedes\langle V,l,\prec\rangle⟨ italic_V , italic_l , ≺ ⟩. For s,t∈V𝑠𝑡𝑉s,t\in Vitalic_s , italic_t ∈ italic_V we shall write s⪯tprecedes-or-equals𝑠𝑡s\preceq titalic_s ⪯ italic_t iff s≺tprecedes𝑠𝑡s\prec titalic_s ≺ italic_t or s=t𝑠𝑡s=titalic_s = italic_t. Let α𝛼\alphaitalic_α be a formula and u∈V𝑢𝑉u\in Vitalic_u ∈ italic_V be a minimal element of α^^𝛼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG. Let ≺αusuperscriptsubscriptprecedes𝛼𝑢\prec_{\alpha}^{u}≺ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the strict partial order obtained from ≺precedes\prec≺ by making u𝑢uitalic_u a minimum of α^^𝛼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG, i.e., s≺αutsuperscriptsubscriptprecedes𝛼𝑢𝑠𝑡s\prec_{\alpha}^{u}titalic_s ≺ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t iff s≺tprecedes𝑠𝑡s\prec titalic_s ≺ italic_t or s⪯uprecedes-or-equals𝑠𝑢s\preceq uitalic_s ⪯ italic_u and there exists a state w∈α^𝑤^𝛼w\in\widehat{\alpha}italic_w ∈ over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG such that w⪯tprecedes-or-equals𝑤𝑡w\preceq titalic_w ⪯ italic_t. The following lemma describes the properties of the construction described above.

Lemma 4

The structure Mαu=def⟨V,l,≺αu⟩superscriptnormal-defsuperscriptsubscript𝑀𝛼𝑢𝑉𝑙superscriptsubscriptprecedes𝛼𝑢M_{\alpha}^{u}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}\langle V,l,\prec_{\alpha}^{u}\rangleitalic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP ⟨ italic_V , italic_l , ≺ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟩ is a preferential model. The consequence relation defined by Mαusuperscriptsubscript𝑀𝛼𝑢M_{\alpha}^{u}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT extends the consequence relation defined by M𝑀Mitalic_M. In this model u𝑢uitalic_u is a minimum of α^normal-^𝛼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG. Both models have the same set of consistent formulas.

Proof: It is easy to see that ≺αusuperscriptsubscriptprecedes𝛼𝑢\prec_{\alpha}^{u}≺ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is irreflexive and transitive. It is also easy to see that, under ≺αusuperscriptsubscriptprecedes𝛼𝑢\prec_{\alpha}^{u}≺ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, u𝑢uitalic_u is a minimum of α^^𝛼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG. We want to show now that, for any β∈L𝛽𝐿\beta\in Litalic_β ∈ italic_L, the set β^^𝛽\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG is smooth, under ≺αusuperscriptsubscriptprecedes𝛼𝑢\prec_{\alpha}^{u}≺ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Let s∈β^𝑠^𝛽s\in\widehat{\beta}italic_s ∈ over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG. Since β^^𝛽\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG is smooth under ≺precedes\prec≺, there is a state t𝑡titalic_t, minimal under ≺precedes\prec≺ in β^^𝛽\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG such that t⪯sprecedes-or-equals𝑡𝑠t\preceq sitalic_t ⪯ italic_s. If t𝑡titalic_t is still minimal in β^^𝛽\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG under ≺αusuperscriptsubscriptprecedes𝛼𝑢\prec_{\alpha}^{u}≺ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then we are done. If not, there is some state v∈β^𝑣^𝛽v\in\widehat{\beta}italic_v ∈ over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG such that v⪯uprecedes-or-equals𝑣𝑢v\preceq uitalic_v ⪯ italic_u and v≺αussuperscriptsubscriptprecedes𝛼𝑢𝑣𝑠v\prec_{\alpha}^{u}sitalic_v ≺ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s. Since β^^𝛽\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG is smooth under ≺precedes\prec≺, there is a state w𝑤witalic_w, minimal in β^^𝛽\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG under ≺precedes\prec≺ such that w≺vprecedes𝑤𝑣w\prec vitalic_w ≺ italic_v. Since w≺uprecedes𝑤𝑢w\prec uitalic_w ≺ italic_u, w𝑤witalic_w must be minimal in β^^𝛽\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG also under ≺αusuperscriptsubscriptprecedes𝛼𝑢\prec_{\alpha}^{u}≺ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. But w≺αussuperscriptsubscriptprecedes𝛼𝑢𝑤𝑠w\prec_{\alpha}^{u}sitalic_w ≺ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s. We have shown that β^^𝛽\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG is smooth under ≺αusuperscriptsubscriptprecedes𝛼𝑢\prec_{\alpha}^{u}≺ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. To see that the consequence relation defined by Mαusuperscriptsubscript𝑀𝛼𝑢M_{\alpha}^{u}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT extends the one defined by M𝑀Mitalic_M, just notice that, since ≺αusuperscriptsubscriptprecedes𝛼𝑢\prec_{\alpha}^{u}≺ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT extends ≺precedes\prec≺, all minimal elements under the former are also minimal under the latter. Lastly, since M𝑀Mitalic_M and Mαusuperscriptsubscript𝑀𝛼𝑢M_{\alpha}^{u}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT have exactly the same set of worlds and the same labeling function, they define exactly the same set of consistent formulas.     

Theorem 3

Let K be a knowledge base and α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β an assertion that is not preferentially entailed by K. The formulas that are inconsistent for the preferential closure of 𝐊∪{α⁢ ∼ ⁢¬⁢β}𝐊𝛼 ∼ 𝛽{\bf K}\cup\{\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\neg\beta\}bold_K ∪ { italic_α ∼ ¬ italic_β } are those that are inconsistent for the preferential closure of K.

Proof: Suppose that α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β is not preferentially entailed by K. Then, let W=⟨S,l,≺⟩𝑊𝑆𝑙precedesW=\langle S,l,\prec\rangleitalic_W = ⟨ italic_S , italic_l , ≺ ⟩ be the preferential model the existence of which is guaranteed by Theorem 1 and that defines 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The model W𝑊Witalic_W does not satisfy α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β. There is therefore a minimal element s∈S𝑠𝑆s\in Sitalic_s ∈ italic_S of α^^𝛼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG that does not satisfy β𝛽\betaitalic_β. Consider now the model W′=defWαssuperscriptdefsuperscript𝑊′superscriptsubscript𝑊𝛼𝑠W^{\prime}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}W_{\alpha}^{s}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. By Lemma 4 this is a preferential model that satisfies all the assertions satisfied by W𝑊Witalic_W, therefore it satisfies all the assertions of K. Since s𝑠sitalic_s is the only minimal element of α^^𝛼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG, it satisfies 𝐊∪{α⁢ ∼¬⁢β}𝐊similar-to𝛼 𝛽{\bf K}\cup\{\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\beta\}bold_K ∪ { italic_α ∼ ¬ italic_β }. Suppose γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ is inconsistent for (𝐊∪{α⁢ ∼ ⁢¬⁢β})psuperscript𝐊𝛼 ∼ 𝛽𝑝({\bf K}\cup\{\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\neg\beta\})^{p}( bold_K ∪ { italic_α ∼ ¬ italic_β } ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then it must be inconsistent for W′superscript𝑊′W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. By Lemma 4 it is inconsistent for W𝑊Witalic_W, therefore inconsistent for 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.     

Corollary 3

Let K be a conditional knowledge base and α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β a conditional assertion. The assertion α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β is preferentially entailed by K iff the assertion α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ false is preferentially entailed by 𝐊∪{α⁢ ∼¬⁢β}𝐊similar-to𝛼 𝛽{\bf K}\cup\{\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\beta\}bold_K ∪ { italic_α ∼ ¬ italic_β }.

Proof: The only if part follows immediately from the soundness of the And rule. The if part, follows immediately from Theorem 3.     

2.6 The rank of a formula

In this section, we introduce a powerful tool for studying preferential entailment. Given a knowledge base, we shall attach an ordinal, its rank, to every formula. We shall prove an important result concerning those ranks, and, in particular, show that a knowledge base K and its preferential closure 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT define the same ranks.

Definition 10

Let K be a conditional knowledge base (i.e., a set of conditional assertions) and α𝛼\alphaitalic_α a formula. The formula α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is said to be exceptional for K iff K preferentially entails the assertion true  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢α𝛼\neg\alpha¬ italic_α. The conditional assertion 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A=defsuperscriptnormal-def\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β is said to be exceptional for K iff its antecedent α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is exceptional for K.

The set of all assertions of K that are exceptional for K will be denoted by E⁢(𝐊)𝐸𝐊E({\bf K})italic_E ( bold_K ). Notice that E⁢(𝐊)⊆𝐊𝐸𝐊𝐊E({\bf K})\subseteq{\bf K}italic_E ( bold_K ) ⊆ bold_K. If all assertions of K are exceptional for K, i.e., if K is equal to E⁢(𝐊)𝐸𝐊E({\bf K})italic_E ( bold_K ), we shall say that K is completely exceptional. The empty knowledge base is completely exceptional. Notice that, in the definition above, K may be replaced by its preferential closure 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Given a conditional knowledge base K (not necessarily finite), we shall now define by ordinal induction an infinite non-increasing sequence of subsets of K. Let C0subscript𝐶0C_{0}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be equal to K. For any successor ordinal τ+1𝜏1\tau+1italic_τ + 1, Cτ+1subscript𝐶𝜏1C_{\tau+1}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will be E⁢(Cτ)𝐸subscript𝐶𝜏E(C_{\tau})italic_E ( italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and for any limit ordinal τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ, Cτsubscript𝐶𝜏C_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the intersection of all Cρsubscript𝐶𝜌C_{\rho}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for ρ<τ𝜌𝜏\rho<\tauitalic_ρ < italic_τ. It is clear that, after some point on, all C𝐶Citalic_C’s are equal and completely exceptional (they may be empty, but need not be so). We shall say that a formula α𝛼\alphaitalic_α has rank τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ (for K) iff τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ is the least ordinal for which α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is not exceptional for Cτsubscript𝐶𝜏C_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. A formula that is exceptional for all Cτsubscript𝐶𝜏C_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT’s is said to have no rank. Notice that such a formula is exceptional for a totally exceptional knowledge base. The following is a fundamental lemma on preferential entailment. It says that, as far as preferential entailment is concerned, non-exceptional assertions cannot help deriving exceptional assertions. The notion of rank defined above proves to be a powerful tool for studying preferential entailment.

Lemma 5

Let τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ be an ordinal. Let K be a conditional knowledge base and 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A a conditional assertion whose antecedent has rank larger or equal to τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ (or has no rank). Then 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A is preferentially entailed by C0subscript𝐶0C_{0}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT iff it is preferentially entailed by Cτsubscript𝐶𝜏C_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Proof: The if part follows from the fact that Cτsubscript𝐶𝜏C_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a subset of C0subscript𝐶0C_{0}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The only if part is proved by induction on the length of the proof of 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A from C0subscript𝐶0C_{0}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. If the proof has length one, i.e., 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A is obtained by Reflexivity or is an assertion of C0subscript𝐶0C_{0}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then the result is obvious. If the last step of the proof is obtained by Right Weakening or And, the result follows from a trivial use of the induction hypothesis. If the last step of the proof is obtained by Left Logical Equivalence, the result follows from the induction hypothesis and the fact that, if α𝛼\alphaitalic_α and α′superscript𝛼′\alpha^{\prime}italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are logically equivalent then α𝛼\alphaitalic_α and α′superscript𝛼′\alpha^{\prime}italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT have the same rank. If the last step is a use of Or, and 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A is of the form α∨β𝛼𝛽\alpha\vee\betaitalic_α ∨ italic_β  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ then just remark that the rank of the disjunction α∨β𝛼𝛽\alpha\vee\betaitalic_α ∨ italic_β is the smaller of the ranks of α𝛼\alphaitalic_α and β𝛽\betaitalic_β. Both α𝛼\alphaitalic_α and β𝛽\betaitalic_β have therefore a rank larger or equal to τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ and one concludes by the induction hypothesis. If the last step is a use of Cautious Monotonicity, and 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A is of the form α∧β𝛼𝛽\alpha\wedge\betaitalic_α ∧ italic_β  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, where α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β and α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ are preferentially entailed (with short proofs) by C0subscript𝐶0C_{0}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, let σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ be the rank of α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. By the induction hypothesis Cσsubscript𝐶𝜎C_{\sigma}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT preferentially entails α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β. Since α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is not exceptional for Cσsubscript𝐶𝜎C_{\sigma}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we conclude that α∧β𝛼𝛽\alpha\wedge\betaitalic_α ∧ italic_β is not exceptional for Cσsubscript𝐶𝜎C_{\sigma}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and therefore has rank σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ. But α∧β𝛼𝛽\alpha\wedge\betaitalic_α ∧ italic_β has rank larger or equal to τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ. Therefore τ≤σ𝜏𝜎\tau\leq\sigmaitalic_τ ≤ italic_σ. The formula α𝛼\alphaitalic_α has rank larger or equal to τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ and we may apply the induction hypothesis to conclude that both α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β and α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ are preferentially entailed by Cρsubscript𝐶𝜌C_{\rho}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.     

Lemma 6

Let K and 𝐊′superscript𝐊normal-′{\bf K}^{\prime}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be knowledge bases such that 𝐊⊆𝐊′⊆𝐊p𝐊superscript𝐊normal-′superscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}\subseteq{\bf K}^{\prime}\subseteq{\bf K}^{p}bold_K ⊆ bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊆ bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For any formula, the rank it is given by 𝐊′superscript𝐊normal-′{\bf K}^{\prime}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is equal to the rank it is given by K.

Proof: Using Lemma 5, one shows by ordinal induction that Cτ⊆Cτ′⊆(Cτ)psubscript𝐶𝜏subscriptsuperscript𝐶′𝜏superscriptsubscript𝐶𝜏𝑝C_{\tau}\subseteq C^{\prime}_{\tau}\subseteq(C_{\tau})^{p}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊆ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊆ ( italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.     

The following definition will be useful in Section 5.6.

Definition 11

A knowledge base K is said to be admissible iff all formulas that have no rank for K are inconsistent for K.

We shall immediately show that many knowledge bases are admissible.

Lemma 7

If the preferential closure of K is defined by some well-founded preferential model, then K is admissible. In particular, any finite knowledge base is admissible.

Proof: We have noticed, in Lemma 6 that ranks are stable under the the replacement of a knowledge base by its preferential closure. Let P𝑃Pitalic_P be the preferential closure of K. Suppose P𝑃Pitalic_P is defined by some well-founded preferential model W𝑊Witalic_W. Suppose α𝛼\alphaitalic_α has no rank. We must show that no state of W𝑊Witalic_W satisfies α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. As noticed above, there is an ordinal τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ such that Cτsubscript𝐶𝜏C_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is completely exceptional and α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is exceptional for Cτsubscript𝐶𝜏C_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We shall show that no state of W𝑊Witalic_W satisfies a formula that is exceptional for Cτsubscript𝐶𝜏C_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Indeed, if there were such a state, there would be such a minimal state, s𝑠sitalic_s, since W𝑊Witalic_W is well-founded. But W𝑊Witalic_W is a model of Cτsubscript𝐶𝜏C_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and no state below s𝑠sitalic_s satisfy any antecedent of Cτsubscript𝐶𝜏C_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, since Cτsubscript𝐶𝜏C_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is totally exceptional. Therefore the preferential model consisting of s𝑠sitalic_s alone is a model of Cτsubscript𝐶𝜏C_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. But, in a model of Cτsubscript𝐶𝜏C_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, no minimal state satisfy a formula that is exceptional for Cτsubscript𝐶𝜏C_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. A contradiction. It follows now from Lemma 3 that any finite knowledge base is admissible.     

2.7 Computing preferential entailment

This section is devoted to the study of the computational complexity of preferential entailment. It is not needed in the sequel. We shall explain in Section 3.5 why preferential entailment is not the right notion of entailment to answer the question of the title, nevertheless preferential entailment is a central concept and it is therefore worthwhile studying its computational complexity. The results here are quite encouraging: the problem is in co-NP, i.e., in the same polynomial class as the problem of deciding whether a propositional formula is valid.

Lemma 8

Let K be a finite conditional knowledge base and α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β a conditional assertion that is not preferentially entailed by K. There is a finite totally (i.e., linearly) ordered preferential model of K  no state of which satisfies α𝛼\alphaitalic_α except the top state. This top state satisfies α𝛼\alphaitalic_α and does not satisfy β𝛽\betaitalic_β.

Proof: Let ℒ′⊆ℒsuperscriptℒ′ℒ{\cal L^{\prime}}\subseteq{\cal L}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊆ caligraphic_L be a logically finite language, large enough to contain α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, β𝛽\betaitalic_β and all the assertions of K. Let us now consider ℒ′superscriptℒ′{\cal L^{\prime}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to be our language of reference. Clearly, α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β is not preferentially entailed by K, since a proof over the smaller language is a proof over the larger language. By Theorem 1, there is a finite preferential model W𝑊Witalic_W (over ℒ′superscriptℒ′{\cal L^{\prime}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) of K that does not satisfy α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β. In W𝑊Witalic_W, there is therefore a state s𝑠sitalic_s, minimal in α^^𝛼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG, that satisfies α𝛼\alphaitalic_α but does not satisfy β𝛽\betaitalic_β. Consider the submodel W′superscript𝑊′W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT obtained by deleting all states of W𝑊Witalic_W that are not below or equal to s𝑠sitalic_s. It is clearly a finite preferential model of K, with a top state that satisfies α𝛼\alphaitalic_α but not β𝛽\betaitalic_β. Let V𝑉Vitalic_V be obtained by imposing on the states of W′superscript𝑊′W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT any total ordering that respects the partial ordering of W′superscript𝑊′W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Since there are only finitely many states in V𝑉Vitalic_V, the smoothness condition is verified and V𝑉Vitalic_V is a preferential model (on ℒ′superscriptℒ′{\cal L^{\prime}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT). It is a model of K but not of 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A. Now we may extend the labeling function of V𝑉Vitalic_V to the propositional variables of ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L that are not in ℒ′superscriptℒ′{\cal L^{\prime}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT any way we want, to get the model requested. Notice that the model obtained satisfies the smoothness condition because it is finite.     

Theorem 4

There is a non-deterministic algorithm that, given a finite set K of conditional assertions and a conditional assertion 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A, checks that 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A is not preferentially entailed by K. The running time of this algorithm is polynomial in the size of K (sum of the sizes of its elements) and 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A.

Proof: Let K be {γi⁢ ∼δi}i=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsimilar-tosubscript𝛾𝑖 subscript𝛿𝑖𝑖1𝑁{\{\gamma_{i}\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\delta_{i}\}}_{i=1}^{N}{ italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Let I⊆{1,…,N}𝐼1…𝑁I\subseteq\{1,\ldots,N\}italic_I ⊆ { 1 , … , italic_N } be a set of indices. We shall define: φI=def⋁i∈Iγisuperscriptdefsubscript𝜑𝐼subscript𝑖𝐼subscript𝛾𝑖\varphi_{I}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}\bigvee_{i\in I}\gamma_{i}italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP ⋁ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ italic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ψI=def⋀i∈I(γi→δi)superscriptdefsubscript𝜓𝐼subscript𝑖𝐼→subscript𝛾𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖\psi_{I}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}\bigwedge_{i\in I}\left(\gamma_{i}\rightarrow\delta_{i}\right)italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP ⋀ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ italic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). A sequence is a sequence of pairs (Ii,fi)subscript𝐼𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖\left(I_{i},f_{i}\right)( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for i=0,…,n𝑖0…𝑛i=0,\ldots,nitalic_i = 0 , … , italic_n, where Ii⊆Isubscript𝐼𝑖𝐼I_{i}\subseteq Iitalic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊆ italic_I and fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a world. Let α𝛼\alphaitalic_α and β𝛽\betaitalic_β be in ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L.

Definition 12

A sequence (Ii,fi)subscript𝐼𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖\left(I_{i},f_{i}\right)( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), i=0,…,n𝑖0normal-…𝑛i=0,\ldots,nitalic_i = 0 , … , italic_n, is a witness for α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β (we mean a witness that α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β is not preferentially entailed by K ) iff

  1. 1.

    fk⊧ψIkmodelssubscript𝑓𝑘subscript𝜓subscript𝐼𝑘f_{k}\models\psi_{I_{k}}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊧ italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,  ∀k=0,…,nfor-all𝑘0normal-…𝑛\forall k=0,\ldots,n∀ italic_k = 0 , … , italic_n

  2. 2.

    fk⊧φIkmodelssubscript𝑓𝑘subscript𝜑subscript𝐼𝑘f_{k}\models\varphi_{I_{k}}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊧ italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,  ∀k=0,…,n−1for-all𝑘0normal-…𝑛1\forall k=0,\ldots,n-1∀ italic_k = 0 , … , italic_n - 1

  3. 3.

    Ik+1=Ik⁢⋂{j∣fk⊧̸γj}subscript𝐼𝑘1subscript𝐼𝑘conditional-set𝑗not-modelssubscript𝑓𝑘subscript𝛾𝑗I_{k+1}=I_{k}\bigcap\{j\mid f_{k}\not\models\gamma_{j}\}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋂ { italic_j ∣ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊧̸ italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT },  ∀k=0,…,n−1for-all𝑘0normal-…𝑛1\forall k=0,\ldots,n-1∀ italic_k = 0 , … , italic_n - 1

  4. 4.

    I0={1,…,N}subscript𝐼01normal-…𝑁I_{0}=\{1,\ldots,N\}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { 1 , … , italic_N }

  5. 5.

    fk⊧̸αnot-modelssubscript𝑓𝑘𝛼f_{k}\not\models\alphaitalic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊧̸ italic_α,  ∀k=0,…,n−1for-all𝑘0normal-…𝑛1\forall k=0,\ldots,n-1∀ italic_k = 0 , … , italic_n - 1

  6. 6.

    fn⊧α∧¬⁢βmodelssubscript𝑓𝑛𝛼𝛽f_{n}\models\alpha\wedge\neg\betaitalic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊧ italic_α ∧ ¬ italic_β.

We must check that: witnesses are short and a conditional assertion has a witness iff it is not preferentially entailed by K. For the first point, just remark that, for k=0,…,n−1𝑘0…𝑛1k=0,\ldots,n-1italic_k = 0 , … , italic_n - 1 the inclusion Ik⊃Ik+1subscript𝐼𝑘1subscript𝐼𝑘I_{k}\supset I_{k+1}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊃ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is strict because of items 3 and 2. The length of the sequence is therefore bounded by the number of assertions in K. But, each pair has a short description. For the second point, suppose first there is a witness for α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β. Then the ranked model W𝑊Witalic_W consisting of worlds f0,…,fnsubscript𝑓0…subscript𝑓𝑛f_{0},\ldots,f_{n}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where fk≺fk+1precedessubscript𝑓𝑘subscript𝑓𝑘1f_{k}\prec f_{k+1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≺ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for k=0,…,n−1𝑘0…𝑛1k=0,\ldots,n-1italic_k = 0 , … , italic_n - 1 satisfies K but not α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β. That it does not satisfy α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β is clear from items 5 and 6. Let us check that W𝑊Witalic_W satisfies γisubscript𝛾𝑖\gamma_{i}italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ δisubscript𝛿𝑖\delta_{i}italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. If none of the fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT’s, k=0,…,n𝑘0…𝑛k=0,\ldots,nitalic_k = 0 , … , italic_n satisfies γisubscript𝛾𝑖\gamma_{i}italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT then W𝑊Witalic_W satisfies γisubscript𝛾𝑖\gamma_{i}italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ η𝜂\etaitalic_η for any η𝜂\etaitalic_η in ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L. Suppose therefore that j𝑗jitalic_j is the smallest k𝑘kitalic_k for which fj⊧γimodelssubscript𝑓𝑗subscript𝛾𝑖f_{j}\models\gamma_{i}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊧ italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We must show that fj⊧δimodelssubscript𝑓𝑗subscript𝛿𝑖f_{j}\models\delta_{i}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊧ italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. But, by items 4 and 3 i∈Ij𝑖subscript𝐼𝑗i\in I_{j}italic_i ∈ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and by item 1, fi⊧δimodelssubscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖f_{i}\models\delta_{i}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊧ italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Suppose now that α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β is not preferentially entailed by some given finite K. By Lemma 8, there is a finite linearly ordered model W𝑊Witalic_W of K, no state of which satisfies α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, except the top state that is labeled by a world m𝑚mitalic_m that satisfies α∧¬⁢β𝛼𝛽\alpha\wedge\neg\betaitalic_α ∧ ¬ italic_β. Let I0=def{1,…,N}superscriptdefsubscript𝐼01…𝑁I_{0}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}\{1,\ldots,N\}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP { 1 , … , italic_N }. It is easy to see that (remark 1): if V𝑉Vitalic_V is any preferential model of K, for any set I⊆I0𝐼subscript𝐼0I\subseteq I_{0}italic_I ⊆ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, V𝑉Vitalic_V satisfies φI⁢ ∼ ⁢ψIsubscript𝜑𝐼 ∼ subscript𝜓𝐼\varphi_{I}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\psi_{I}italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let us now consider first the set α∨φI0^^𝛼subscript𝜑subscript𝐼0\widehat{\alpha\vee\varphi_{I_{0}}}over^ start_ARG italic_α ∨ italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG. It cannot be empty, therefore it has a unique minimal state. Let f0subscript𝑓0f_{0}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the label of this state. We must consider two cases. First suppose that f0⊧αmodelssubscript𝑓0𝛼f_{0}\models\alphaitalic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊧ italic_α. Then f0subscript𝑓0f_{0}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is minimal in α^^𝛼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG and therefore must be m𝑚mitalic_m. In such a case (I0,m)subscript𝐼0𝑚\left(I_{0},m\right)( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_m ) is a witness. The only thing to check is that item 1 is satisfied. Indeed either m⊧φI0models𝑚subscript𝜑subscript𝐼0m\models\varphi_{I_{0}}italic_m ⊧ italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and we conclude by remark 1 or φI0^=∅^subscript𝜑subscript𝐼0\widehat{\varphi_{I_{0}}}=\emptysetover^ start_ARG italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = ∅ and m𝑚mitalic_m satisfies none of the γisubscript𝛾𝑖\gamma_{i}italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT’s. Let us deal now with the case f0⊧̸αnot-modelssubscript𝑓0𝛼f_{0}\not\models\alphaitalic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊧̸ italic_α. We shall build a sequence beginning by (I0,m)subscript𝐼0𝑚\left(I_{0},m\right)( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_m ). Since m𝑚mitalic_m does not satisfy α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, it must satisfy φI0subscript𝜑subscript𝐼0\varphi_{I_{0}}italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which takes care of item 2. Remark 1 takes care of item 1. Let us now define I1=I0⁢⋂{j∣f0⊧̸γj}subscript𝐼1subscript𝐼0conditional-set𝑗not-modelssubscript𝑓0subscript𝛾𝑗I_{1}=I_{0}\bigcap\{j\mid f_{0}\not\models\gamma_{j}\}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋂ { italic_j ∣ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊧̸ italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. I1subscript𝐼1I_{1}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is strictly smaller than I0subscript𝐼0I_{0}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We may now consider the set α∨φI1^^𝛼subscript𝜑subscript𝐼1\widehat{\alpha\vee\varphi_{I_{1}}}over^ start_ARG italic_α ∨ italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG. It is not empty and therefore has a unique minimal element and we may, in this way, go on and build a proof for α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β.     

Since it is clear that preferential non-entailment is at least as hard as satisfiability (consider assertions with antecedent true), we conclude that it is an NP-complete problem, i.e., that preferential entailment is co-NP-complete. A remark of J. Dix that will be explained at the end of Section 5.8 shows that preferential entailment is reducible to the computation of rational closure and that this reduction, when applied to Horn formulas, requires only the consideration of Horn formulas. It follows that, if we restrict ourselves to Horn assertions, computing preferential entailment has only polynomial complexity.

3 Rationality

3.1 Introduction

In this section we explain why not all preferential relations represent reasonable nonmonotonic inference procedures. We present some additional principles of nonmonotonic reasoning and discuss them. Those principles are structurally different from the rules of preferential reasoning, since they are not of the type: deduce some assertion from some other assertions. Sections 3.2 and 3.3 present weak principles. Some results are proven concerning those principles. Deeper results on those principles, found after a first version of this paper had been circulated, appear in [11]. Our central principle is presented in Section 3.4. Those principles were first described in [17] but the technical results presented here are new. In 3.5, the value of preferential entailment as an answer to the question of the title is discussed. Our conclusion is that it is not a satisfactory answer, since it does not provide us with a rational relation. Then, in Section 3.6, a restricted family of preferential models, the family of ranked models, is presented and a representation theorem is proved. The result is central to this paper but the proof of the representation theorem may be skipped on a first reading. The representation theorem appeared in [19]. The family of ranked models is closely related to, but different from, a family studied in [7] and Section 3.7 explains the differences.

3.2 Negation Rationality

In [17, Section 5.4], it was argued that not all preferential consequence relations represented reasonable inference operations. Three rationality properties were discussed there, and it was argued that all three were desirable. Those properties do not lend themselves to be presented as Horn rules (deduce the presence of an assertion in a relation from the presence of other assertions) but have the form: deduce the absence of an assertion from the absence of other assertions. All of them are implied by Monotonicity. The reader may find the discussion of [17] useful. Here technical results will be described. The first property considered is the following.

α∧γ⁢ ≁β,α∧¬⁢γ⁢ ≁βα⁢ ≁β(𝐍𝐞𝐠𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧⁢𝐑𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐲)formulae-sequencenot-similar-to𝛼𝛾 𝛽not-similar-to𝛼𝛾 𝛽not-similar-to𝛼 𝛽𝐍𝐞𝐠𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐑𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐲{{\alpha\wedge\gamma\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim\beta\ ,\ \alpha\wedge\neg\gamma\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim\beta}\over{\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim\beta}}\hskip 45.52458pt{\rm({\bf Negation\ Rationality})}divide start_ARG italic_α ∧ italic_γ ≁ italic_β , italic_α ∧ ¬ italic_γ ≁ italic_β end_ARG start_ARG italic_α ≁ italic_β end_ARG ( bold_Negation bold_Rationality ) (10)
Lemma 9

There is a preferential relation that does not satisfy Negation Rationality.

Proof: Take a preferential model containing four states: si,i=0,…⁢3formulae-sequencesubscript𝑠𝑖𝑖0…3s_{i},i=0,\ldots 3italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i = 0 , … 3, with s0≺s1precedessubscript𝑠0subscript𝑠1s_{0}\prec s_{1}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≺ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and s2≺s3precedessubscript𝑠2subscript𝑠3s_{2}\prec s_{3}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≺ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let the even states be the only states satisfying q𝑞qitalic_q and s0subscript𝑠0s_{0}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and s3subscript𝑠3s_{3}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the only states satisfying p𝑝pitalic_p. One easily verifies that the consequence relation defined by this model is such that true  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ q𝑞qitalic_q, but p𝑝pitalic_p  ≁not-similar-to absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim≁ q𝑞qitalic_q and ¬⁢p𝑝\neg p¬ italic_p  ≁not-similar-to absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim≁ q𝑞qitalic_q.     

No semantic characterization of relations satisfying Negation Rationality is known. It has been shown in [17] that the consequence relation defined by Circumscription does not always satisfy Negation Rationality.

3.3 Disjunctive Rationality

The next property is the following.

α ≁γ,β ≁γα∨β⁢ ≁γ(𝐃𝐢𝐬𝐣𝐮𝐧𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐯𝐞⁢𝐑𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐲){{\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim\gamma\ \ ,\ \ \beta\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim\gamma}\over{\alpha\vee\beta\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim\gamma}}\hskip 85.35826pt{\rm({\bf Disjunctive\ Rationality})}divide start_ARG italic_α ≁ italic_γ , italic_β ≁ italic_γ end_ARG start_ARG italic_α ∨ italic_β ≁ italic_γ end_ARG ( bold_Disjunctive bold_Rationality ) (11)

We may prove the following.

Lemma 10

Any preferential relation that satisfies Disjunctive Rationality satisfies Negation Rationality.

Proof: Suppose α∧γ𝛼𝛾\alpha\wedge\gammaitalic_α ∧ italic_γ  ≁not-similar-to absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim≁ β𝛽\betaitalic_β and α∧¬⁢γ𝛼𝛾\alpha\wedge\neg\gammaitalic_α ∧ ¬ italic_γ  ≁not-similar-to absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim≁ β𝛽\betaitalic_β. By Disjunctive Rationality, we conclude that α∧γ∨α∧¬⁢γ𝛼𝛾𝛼𝛾\alpha\wedge\gamma\vee\alpha\wedge\neg\gammaitalic_α ∧ italic_γ ∨ italic_α ∧ ¬ italic_γ  ≁not-similar-to absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim≁ β𝛽\betaitalic_β. We conclude by Left Logical Equivalence.     

Lemma 11

There is a preferential relation that satisfies Negation Rationality but does not satisfy Disjunctive Rationality.

Proof: Let us consider the following preferential model W𝑊Witalic_W. The model W𝑊Witalic_W has four states: a0,a1,b0,b1subscript𝑎0subscript𝑎1subscript𝑏0subscript𝑏1a_{0},a_{1},b_{0},b_{1}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The ordering is: a0≺a1precedessubscript𝑎0subscript𝑎1a_{0}\prec a_{1}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≺ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and b0≺b1precedessubscript𝑏0subscript𝑏1b_{0}\prec b_{1}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≺ italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The language has three propositional variables: p𝑝pitalic_p, q𝑞qitalic_q and r𝑟ritalic_r. The two states a1subscript𝑎1a_{1}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and b1subscript𝑏1b_{1}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (the top states) are labeled with the same world that satisfies only p𝑝pitalic_p and q𝑞qitalic_q. State a0subscript𝑎0a_{0}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is labeled with the world that satisfies only p𝑝pitalic_p and r𝑟ritalic_r and the state b0subscript𝑏0b_{0}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with the world that satisfies only q𝑞qitalic_q and r𝑟ritalic_r. The preferential relation defined by W𝑊Witalic_W does not satisfy Disjunctive Rationality but satisfies Weak Rationality. For the first claim, notice that: p∨q𝑝𝑞p\vee qitalic_p ∨ italic_q  ∼Wsubscriptsimilar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}∼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT r𝑟ritalic_r but p𝑝pitalic_p  ≁Wsubscriptnot-similar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}{\not\sim}_{W}≁ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT r𝑟ritalic_r and q𝑞qitalic_q  ≁Wsubscriptnot-similar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}{\not\sim}_{W}≁ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT r𝑟ritalic_r.
