For the second claim, suppose α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼Wsubscriptsimilar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}∼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, but α∧β𝛼𝛽\alpha\wedge\betaitalic_α ∧ italic_β  ≁Wsubscriptnot-similar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}{\not\sim}_{W}≁ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ. Then it must be the case that there is a minimal state of α^^𝛼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG that does not satisfy β𝛽\betaitalic_β and, above it, a state that is minimal in α∧β^^𝛼𝛽\widehat{\alpha\wedge\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_α ∧ italic_β end_ARG. This last state must be labeled by a world that is the label of no minimal state of α^^𝛼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG. Therefore, α^^𝛼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG must contain all four states of W𝑊Witalic_W, and α∧β^^𝛼𝛽\widehat{\alpha\wedge\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_α ∧ italic_β end_ARG must contain either the two top states alone or the two top states and one of the bottom states. In each case it is easy to see that α∧¬⁢β𝛼𝛽\alpha\wedge\neg\betaitalic_α ∧ ¬ italic_β  ∼Wsubscriptsimilar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}∼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ since the minimal states of α∧¬⁢β^^𝛼𝛽\widehat{\alpha\wedge\neg\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_α ∧ ¬ italic_β end_ARG are all also minimal in α^^𝛼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG.     

No semantic characterization of relations satisfying Disjunctive Rationality was known at the time this paper was elaborated. M. Freund [10] has now provided a very elegant such characterization together with an alternative proof of our Theorem 5; the canonical model he builds is essentially the same as ours.

3.4 Rational Monotonicity

The last property is the following.

α∧β ≁γ,α ≁¬βα⁢ ≁γ(𝐑𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐚𝐥⁢𝐌𝐨𝐧𝐨𝐭𝐨𝐧𝐢𝐜𝐢𝐭𝐲){{\alpha\wedge\beta\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim\gamma\ \ ,\ \ \alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim\neg\beta}\over{\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim\gamma}}\hskip 56.9055pt{\rm({\bf Rational\ Monotonicity})}divide start_ARG italic_α ∧ italic_β ≁ italic_γ , italic_α ≁ ¬ italic_β end_ARG start_ARG italic_α ≁ italic_γ end_ARG ( bold_Rational bold_Monotonicity ) (12)

This rule is similar to the thesis CV of conditional logic (see [25]). The reader is referred to [17, Section 5.4] for a discussion of our claim that reasonable consequence relations should satisfy Rational Monotonicity. Some researchers in Conditional Logic (J. Pollock in particular) have objected to CV as a valid thesis for (mainly subjunctive) conditionals. Echoes of this debate may be found in [12, end of Section 4.4]. The objections to CV that hold in the conditional logic framework do not hold for us, though their consideration is recommended to the reader. The most attractive feature of Rational Monotonicity is probably that it says that an agent should not have to retract any previous defeasible conclusion when learning about a new fact the negation of which was not previously derivable. In [32], K. Satoh aptly decided to call nonmonotonic reasoning that validates Rational Monotonicity lazy. The rule of Rational Monotonicity should be distinguished from the following rule, which is satisfied by any preferential relation.

α∧β ∼¬γ,α ≁¬βα⁢ ≁γ{{\alpha\wedge\beta\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\gamma\ \ ,\ \ \alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim\neg\beta}\over{\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim\gamma}}divide start_ARG italic_α ∧ italic_β ∼ ¬ italic_γ , italic_α ≁ ¬ italic_β end_ARG start_ARG italic_α ≁ italic_γ end_ARG (13)
Definition 13

A rational consequence relation is a preferential relation that satisfies Rational Monotonicity.

Two different representation theorems will be proved about rational relations, in Sections 3.6 and in Appendix B. The last one seems to provide evidence that reasonable inference procedures validate Rational Monotonicity and that all rational relations represent reasonable inference procedures.

Lemma 12

A rational relation satisfies Disjunctive Rationality.

Proof: Suppose α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ≁not-similar-to absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim≁ γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ and β𝛽\betaitalic_β  ≁not-similar-to absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim≁ γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ. By Left Logical Equivalence we have (α∨β)∧α𝛼𝛽𝛼(\alpha\vee\beta)\wedge\alpha( italic_α ∨ italic_β ) ∧ italic_α  ≁not-similar-to absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim≁ γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ. If we have α∨β𝛼𝛽\alpha\vee\betaitalic_α ∨ italic_β  ≁not-similar-to absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim≁ ¬⁢α𝛼\neg\alpha¬ italic_α, then we could conclude by Rational Monotonicity that α∨β𝛼𝛽\alpha\vee\betaitalic_α ∨ italic_β  ≁not-similar-to absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim≁ γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ. Suppose then that α∨β𝛼𝛽\alpha\vee\betaitalic_α ∨ italic_β  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢α𝛼\neg\alpha¬ italic_α. If we had α∨β𝛼𝛽\alpha\vee\betaitalic_α ∨ italic_β  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, we would conclude by preferential reasoning that β𝛽\betaitalic_β  ≁not-similar-to absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim≁ γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ.     

Lemma 13 (David Makinson)

There is a preferential relation satisfying Disjunctive Rationality that is not rational.

Proof: We shall build a preferential model that defines a consequence relation satisfying Disjunctive Rationality but not Rational Monotonicity. Let ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L be the propositional calculus on the three variables: p0subscript𝑝0p_{0}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, p1subscript𝑝1p_{1}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, p2subscript𝑝2p_{2}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let 𝒰𝒰{\cal U}caligraphic_U contain all propositional worlds on those variables. Let S𝑆Sitalic_S contain three elements: sisubscript𝑠𝑖s_{i}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for i=0,1,2𝑖012i=0,1,2italic_i = 0 , 1 , 2 and l⁢(si)𝑙subscript𝑠𝑖l(s_{i})italic_l ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) satisfy only pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The partial order ≺precedes\prec≺ is such that s1≺s2precedessubscript𝑠1subscript𝑠2s_{1}\prec s_{2}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≺ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and no other pair satisfies the relation. This defines a preferential model W𝑊Witalic_W. First we shall show that the consequence relation defined by W𝑊Witalic_W does not satisfy Rational Monotonicity. Indeed, we have both p0∨p1∨p2subscript𝑝0subscript𝑝1subscript𝑝2p_{0}\vee p_{1}\vee p_{2}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∨ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∨ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT  ∼Wsubscriptsimilar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}∼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ¬⁢p2subscript𝑝2\neg p_{2}¬ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and p0∨p1∨p2subscript𝑝0subscript𝑝1subscript𝑝2p_{0}\vee p_{1}\vee p_{2}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∨ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∨ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT  ≁Wsubscriptnot-similar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}{\not\sim}_{W}≁ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT p1subscript𝑝1p_{1}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Nevertheless, we also have ¬⁢p1∧(p0∨p1∨p2)subscript𝑝1subscript𝑝0subscript𝑝1subscript𝑝2\neg p_{1}\wedge(p_{0}\vee p_{1}\vee p_{2})¬ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∧ ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∨ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∨ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )  ≁Wsubscriptnot-similar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}{\not\sim}_{W}≁ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ¬⁢p2subscript𝑝2\neg p_{2}¬ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let us show now that any preferential model that does not satisfy Disjunctive Rationality must have at least 4444 states. Suppose α∨β𝛼𝛽\alpha\vee\betaitalic_α ∨ italic_β  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, but α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ≁not-similar-to absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim≁ γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ and β𝛽\betaitalic_β  ≁not-similar-to absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim≁ γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ. The last two assumptions imply the existence of states a𝑎aitalic_a and b𝑏bitalic_b, minimal in α^^𝛼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG and β^^𝛽\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG respectively and that do not satisfy γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, and therefore are not minimal in α∨β^^𝛼𝛽\widehat{\alpha\vee\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_α ∨ italic_β end_ARG. Those states are different, since any state minimal in both α^^𝛼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG and β^^𝛽\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG would be minimal in α∨β^^𝛼𝛽\widehat{\alpha\vee\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_α ∨ italic_β end_ARG. By the smoothness condition there must be a state a′superscript𝑎′a^{\prime}italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT minimal in α∨β^^𝛼𝛽\widehat{\alpha\vee\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_α ∨ italic_β end_ARG and such that a′≺aprecedessuperscript𝑎′𝑎a^{\prime}\prec aitalic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≺ italic_a. Clearly a′superscript𝑎′a^{\prime}italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfies γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ and does not satisfy α𝛼\alphaitalic_α (since a𝑎aitalic_a is minimal in α^^𝛼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG) but satisfies β𝛽\betaitalic_β. Similarly there must be a state b′superscript𝑏′b^{\prime}italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT minimal in α∨β^^𝛼𝛽\widehat{\alpha\vee\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_α ∨ italic_β end_ARG and such that b′≺bprecedessuperscript𝑏′𝑏b^{\prime}\prec bitalic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≺ italic_b and b′superscript𝑏′b^{\prime}italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfies γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ and does not satisfy β𝛽\betaitalic_β, but satisfies α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. It is left to show that all four states are different. We have already noticed that a≠b𝑎𝑏a\not=bitalic_a ≠ italic_b. The states a′superscript𝑎′a^{\prime}italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and b′superscript𝑏′b^{\prime}italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfy γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ and are therefore different from a𝑎aitalic_a and b𝑏bitalic_b. But b′superscript𝑏′b^{\prime}italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfies α𝛼\alphaitalic_α and a′superscript𝑎′a^{\prime}italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT does not and therefore a′≠b′superscript𝑎′superscript𝑏′a^{\prime}\not=b^{\prime}italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≠ italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.     

3.5 Discussion of Preferential Entailment

We may now assess preferential entailment as a possible answer to the question of the title. Corollary 2 explains why the notion of preferential entailment cannot be the one we are looking for: the relation 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can be any preferential relation and is not in general rational. For typical K’s, 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT fails to satisfy a large number of instances of Rational Monotonicity and is therefore highly unsuitable. One particularly annoying instance of this is the following. Suppose a conditional knowledge base K contains one single assertion p𝑝pitalic_p  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ q𝑞qitalic_q where p𝑝pitalic_p and q𝑞qitalic_q are different propositional variables. Let r𝑟ritalic_r be a propositional variable, different from p𝑝pitalic_p and q𝑞qitalic_q. We intuitively expect the assertion p∧r𝑝𝑟p\wedge ritalic_p ∧ italic_r  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ q𝑞qitalic_q to follow from K. The rationale for that has been discussed extensively in the literature and boils down to this: since we have no information whatsoever about the influence of r𝑟ritalic_r on objects satisfying p𝑝pitalic_p it is sensible to assume that it has no influence and that there are normal p𝑝pitalic_p-objects that satisfy r𝑟ritalic_r. The normal p∧r𝑝𝑟p\wedge ritalic_p ∧ italic_r-objects are therefore normal p𝑝pitalic_p-objects and have all the properties enjoyed by normal p𝑝pitalic_p-objects. Nevertheless it is easy to check that p∧r𝑝𝑟p\wedge ritalic_p ∧ italic_r  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ q𝑞qitalic_q is not in 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The problem lies, at least in part, with the fact that 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is not rational, since any rational relation containing p𝑝pitalic_p  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ q𝑞qitalic_q , must contain p∧r𝑝𝑟p\wedge ritalic_p ∧ italic_r  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ q𝑞qitalic_q unless it contains p𝑝pitalic_p  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢r𝑟\neg r¬ italic_r.

In conclusion, it seems that the set of conditional assertions entailed by K should be larger and more monotonic than the set 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. It should also be rational. This question will be brought up again in Section 5 and a solution will be proposed.

3.6 Ranked models and a representation theorem for rational relations

In this section a family of preferential models will be defined and it will be shown that the relations defined by models of this family are exactly the rational relations.

Lemma 14

If ≺precedes\prec≺ is a partial order on a set V𝑉Vitalic_V, the following conditions are equivalent.

  1. 1.

    for any x,y,z∈V𝑥𝑦𝑧𝑉x,y,z\in Vitalic_x , italic_y , italic_z ∈ italic_V if x⊀ynot-precedes𝑥𝑦x\not\prec yitalic_x ⊀ italic_y, y⊀xnot-precedes𝑦𝑥y\not\prec xitalic_y ⊀ italic_x and z≺xprecedes𝑧𝑥z\prec xitalic_z ≺ italic_x, then z≺yprecedes𝑧𝑦z\prec yitalic_z ≺ italic_y

  2. 2.

    for any x,y,z∈V𝑥𝑦𝑧𝑉x,y,z\in Vitalic_x , italic_y , italic_z ∈ italic_V if x≺yprecedes𝑥𝑦x\prec yitalic_x ≺ italic_y, then, either z≺yprecedes𝑧𝑦z\prec yitalic_z ≺ italic_y or x≺zprecedes𝑥𝑧x\prec zitalic_x ≺ italic_z

  3. 3.

    for any x,y,z∈V𝑥𝑦𝑧𝑉x,y,z\in Vitalic_x , italic_y , italic_z ∈ italic_V if x⊀ynot-precedes𝑥𝑦x\not\prec yitalic_x ⊀ italic_y and y⊀znot-precedes𝑦𝑧y\not\prec zitalic_y ⊀ italic_z, then x⊀znot-precedes𝑥𝑧x\not\prec zitalic_x ⊀ italic_z

  4. 4.

    there is a totally ordered set ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω (the strict order on ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω will be denoted by <<<) and a function r:V↦Ωnormal-:𝑟maps-to𝑉normal-Ωr:V\mapsto\Omegaitalic_r : italic_V ↦ roman_Ω (the ranking function) such that s≺tprecedes𝑠𝑡s\prec titalic_s ≺ italic_t iff r⁢(s)<r⁢(t)𝑟𝑠𝑟𝑡r(s)<r(t)italic_r ( italic_s ) < italic_r ( italic_t ).

The proof is simple and will not be given. A partial order satisfying any of the conditions of Lemma 14 will be called modular (this terminology is proposed in [12] as an extension of the notion of modular lattice of [13]).

Definition 14

A ranked model W𝑊Witalic_W is a preferential model ⟨V,l,≺⟩𝑉𝑙precedes\langle V,l,\prec\rangle⟨ italic_V , italic_l , ≺ ⟩ for which the strict partial order ≺precedes\prec≺ is modular.

Those models are called ranked since the effect of function r𝑟ritalic_r of property 4 of Lemma 14 is to rank the states: a state of smaller rank being more normal than a state of higher rank. We shall always suppose that a ranked model W𝑊Witalic_W comes equipped with a totally ordered set ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω and a ranking function r𝑟ritalic_r. Notice that we still require W𝑊Witalic_W to satisfy the smoothness condition. It is easy to see that for any subset T𝑇Titalic_T of V𝑉Vitalic_V and any t∈T𝑡𝑇t\in Titalic_t ∈ italic_T, t𝑡titalic_t is minimal in T𝑇Titalic_T iff r⁢(t)𝑟𝑡r(t)italic_r ( italic_t ) is the minimum of the set r⁢(T)𝑟𝑇r(T)italic_r ( italic_T ). It follows that all minimal elements of T𝑇Titalic_T have the same image by r𝑟ritalic_r. The smoothness condition is then equivalent to the following: for any formula α∈L𝛼𝐿\alpha\in Litalic_α ∈ italic_L, if α^^𝛼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG is not empty, the set r⁢(α^)𝑟^𝛼r(\widehat{\alpha})italic_r ( over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG ) has a minimum. The smoothness condition is always verified if ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω is a well-ordered set. The reader may check that the preferential model W𝑊Witalic_W defined in the proof of Lemma 1 is ranked (it is even totally ordered). It follows that there are rational relations that are defined by no well-founded ranked model. The following is a soundness result.

Lemma 15

If W𝑊Witalic_W is a ranked model, the consequence relation  ∼Wsubscriptsimilar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}∼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT it defines is rational.

Proof: It is enough to show that  ∼Wsubscriptsimilar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}∼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies Rational Monotonicity. For this, the smoothness condition is not needed; it is needed, though, for the soundness of Cautious Monotonicity. Suppose W𝑊Witalic_W is a ranked model. We shall use the notations of Definition 14. Suppose also that α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼Wsubscriptsimilar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}∼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ and α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ≁Wsubscriptnot-similar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}{\not\sim}_{W}≁ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ¬⁢β𝛽\neg\beta¬ italic_β. From this last assumption we conclude that there is a minimal element of α^^𝛼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG that satisfies β𝛽\betaitalic_β. Let t∈V𝑡𝑉t\in Vitalic_t ∈ italic_V be such a state. Let s∈V𝑠𝑉s\in Vitalic_s ∈ italic_V be a minimal element of α∧β^^𝛼𝛽\widehat{\alpha\wedge\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_α ∧ italic_β end_ARG. Since t∈α∧β^𝑡^𝛼𝛽t\in\widehat{\alpha\wedge\beta}italic_t ∈ over^ start_ARG italic_α ∧ italic_β end_ARG, t⊀snot-precedes𝑡𝑠t\not\prec sitalic_t ⊀ italic_s and r⁢(s)≤r⁢(t)𝑟𝑠𝑟𝑡r(s)\leq r(t)italic_r ( italic_s ) ≤ italic_r ( italic_t ). But this implies that s𝑠sitalic_s is minimal in α^^𝛼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG: any state u𝑢uitalic_u such that u≺sprecedes𝑢𝑠u\prec sitalic_u ≺ italic_s satisfies r⁢(u)<r⁢(s)𝑟𝑢𝑟𝑠r(u)<r(s)italic_r ( italic_u ) < italic_r ( italic_s ) and therefore r⁢(u)<r⁢(t)𝑟𝑢𝑟𝑡r(u)<r(t)italic_r ( italic_u ) < italic_r ( italic_t ) and u≺tprecedes𝑢𝑡u\prec titalic_u ≺ italic_t. Since α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼Wsubscriptsimilar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}∼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, s⁢ ≡γ𝑠 𝛾s\hskip 2.27621pt\rule[-2.84526pt]{0.28453pt}{11.38109pt}\equiv\gammaitalic_s ≡ italic_γ.     

We shall show now that the converse of Lemma 15 holds. We shall first mention four derived rules of preferential logic. In fact the first three of these rules are even valid in cumulative logic (see [17, Section 3]). Their proof (either proof-theoretic or model-theoretic) is straightforward and is omitted.

Lemma 16

The following rules are derived rules of preferential logic:

α⁢ ∼𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐬𝐞α∧β⁢ ∼𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐬𝐞similar-to𝛼 𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐬𝐞similar-to𝛼𝛽 𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐬𝐞{{\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim{\bf false}}\over{\alpha\wedge\beta\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim{\bf false}}}divide start_ARG italic_α ∼ bold_false end_ARG start_ARG italic_α ∧ italic_β ∼ bold_false end_ARG (14)
α∨β⁢ ∼¬⁢βα⁢ ∼¬⁢βsimilar-to𝛼𝛽 𝛽similar-to𝛼 𝛽{{\alpha\vee\beta\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\beta}\over{\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\beta}}divide start_ARG italic_α ∨ italic_β ∼ ¬ italic_β end_ARG start_ARG italic_α ∼ ¬ italic_β end_ARG (15)
α∨β∨γ⁢ ∼¬⁢α∧¬⁢ββ∨γ⁢ ∼¬⁢βsimilar-to𝛼𝛽𝛾 𝛼𝛽similar-to𝛽𝛾 𝛽{{\alpha\vee\beta\vee\gamma\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\alpha\wedge\neg\beta}\over{\beta\vee\gamma\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\beta}}divide start_ARG italic_α ∨ italic_β ∨ italic_γ ∼ ¬ italic_α ∧ ¬ italic_β end_ARG start_ARG italic_β ∨ italic_γ ∼ ¬ italic_β end_ARG (16)
α∨β⁢ ∼¬⁢αα∨β∨γ⁢ ∼¬⁢αsimilar-to𝛼𝛽 𝛼similar-to𝛼𝛽𝛾 𝛼{{\alpha\vee\beta\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\alpha}\over{\alpha\vee\beta\vee\gamma\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\alpha}}divide start_ARG italic_α ∨ italic_β ∼ ¬ italic_α end_ARG start_ARG italic_α ∨ italic_β ∨ italic_γ ∼ ¬ italic_α end_ARG (17)

We shall now derive a property of rational relations.

Lemma 17

If  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ is a rational relation, then the following rule is valid:

α∨γ ∼¬α,β∨γ ≁¬βα∨β⁢ ∼¬⁢α{{\alpha\vee\gamma\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\alpha\ \ ,\ \ \beta\vee\gamma\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim\neg\beta}\over{\alpha\vee\beta\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\alpha}}divide start_ARG italic_α ∨ italic_γ ∼ ¬ italic_α , italic_β ∨ italic_γ ≁ ¬ italic_β end_ARG start_ARG italic_α ∨ italic_β ∼ ¬ italic_α end_ARG (18)

Proof: From the first hypothesis, by Rule 17 one deduces α∨β∨γ𝛼𝛽𝛾\alpha\vee\beta\vee\gammaitalic_α ∨ italic_β ∨ italic_γ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢α𝛼\neg\alpha¬ italic_α. From the second hypothesis, by Rule 16 one deduces α∨β∨γ𝛼𝛽𝛾\alpha\vee\beta\vee\gammaitalic_α ∨ italic_β ∨ italic_γ  ≁not-similar-to absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim≁ ¬⁡(α∨β)𝛼𝛽\neg(\alpha\vee\beta)¬ ( italic_α ∨ italic_β ). If one applies now Rational Monotonicity, one gets the desired conclusion.     

For the completeness result, we proceed in the style of L. Henkin. Completeness proofs in this style have been used in conditional logics since [34]. Since a number of technical lemmas are needed, we have relegated them to Appendix A and state here the characterization theorem.

Theorem 5

A binary relation  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ on ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L is a rational consequence relation iff it is the consequence relation defined by some ranked model. If the language ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L is logically finite, then every rational consequence relation is defined by some finite ranked model.

Proof: The if part is Lemma 15. For the only if part, let  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ be a consequence relation satisfying the rules of R. The relation  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ defines a structure W𝑊Witalic_W as described in Appendix A. By Lemmas 41 and 36, W𝑊Witalic_W is a ranked model. We claim that, for any α,β∈L𝛼𝛽𝐿\alpha,\beta\in Litalic_α , italic_β ∈ italic_L, α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β iff α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼Wsubscriptsimilar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}∼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT β𝛽\betaitalic_β. Suppose first α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β. By Lemma 42, if <m,β><m,\beta>< italic_m , italic_β > is minimal in α^^𝛼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG, then m𝑚mitalic_m is normal for α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. We conclude that m⊧βmodels𝑚𝛽m\models\betaitalic_m ⊧ italic_β and <m,β> ≡βformulae-sequenceabsent𝑚𝛽 𝛽<m,\beta>\hskip 2.27621pt\rule[-2.84526pt]{0.28453pt}{11.38109pt}\equiv\beta< italic_m , italic_β > ≡ italic_β. Therefore α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼Wsubscriptsimilar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}∼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT β𝛽\betaitalic_β. Suppose now that α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼Wsubscriptsimilar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}∼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT β𝛽\betaitalic_β. Let m𝑚mitalic_m be a normal world for α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. By Corollary 7, the pair <m,α><m,\alpha>< italic_m , italic_α > is minimal in α^^𝛼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG and therefore m⊧βmodels𝑚𝛽m\models\betaitalic_m ⊧ italic_β. All normal worlds for α𝛼\alphaitalic_α therefore satisfy β𝛽\betaitalic_β and Lemma 8 of [17] implies that α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β. For the last sentence of the theorem, notice that, if the language ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L is logically finite, the model W𝑊Witalic_W is finite.     

As we remarked just prior to Lemma 15, the theorem would not hold had we required models to be well-founded.

3.7 Comparison with Delgrande’s work

The system of proof-rules and the models presented above may be compared with the results of J. Delgrande in [7, 8]. The general thrust is very similar but differences are worth noticing. A first difference is in the language used. Delgrande’s language differs from this paper’s in three respects: his work is specifically tailored to first-order predicate calculus, whereas this work deals with propositional calculus; he allows negation and disjunction of conditional assertions, which are not allowed in this paper; he allows nesting of conditional operators in the language, though his completeness result is formulated only for unnested formulas. Therefore Delgrande’s central completeness result in [7], only shows that any proposition in which there is no nesting of conditional operators (let us call those propositions flat) that is valid has a proof from the axioms and rules of his system. But this proof may use propositions that are not flat. The completeness results reported here show that valid assertions have proofs that contain only flat assertions.

A second difference is that Delgrande’s logical system is different from ours: Delgrande’s logic N does not contain Cautious Monotonicity. Our class of ranked models is more restricted than his class of models: our models are required to obey the smoothness condition and Delgrande’s are not. One may also notice that our logic enjoys the finite model property, but Delgrande’s does not. This difference between our two logical systems may sound insignificant when one remarks that many instances of the rule of Cautious Monotonicity may be derived from Rational Monotonicity, and are therefore valid in Delgrande’s system N. What we mean is that if α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β and α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ then, if α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ≁not-similar-to absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim≁ ¬⁢β𝛽\neg\beta¬ italic_β one may conclude α∧β𝛼𝛽\alpha\wedge\betaitalic_α ∧ italic_β  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ by Rational Monotonicity rather than by Cautious Monotonicity. But if α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢β𝛽\neg\beta¬ italic_β, and therefore α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ false one cannot conclude. The Rule 14 is sound in preferential logic but not in Delgrande’s logic. A proof will soon be given. We want to remark here that Rule (14) is very natural, since the meaning of α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ false is that if α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is true than anything may be true. It therefore means that it is absolutely unthinkable that α𝛼\alphaitalic_α be true. In such a case we would expect α∧β𝛼𝛽\alpha\wedge\betaitalic_α ∧ italic_β to be also absolutely unthinkable.

Let us show now that Rule (14) is not valid for Delgrande’s structures. Consider the following structure. Let the set V𝑉Vitalic_V consists of one infinite descending chain: ≺precedes\prec≺ is a total ordering. Suppose now that the top element of V𝑉Vitalic_V is the only state that satisfies the propositional variable p𝑝pitalic_p. In this structure 𝐭𝐫𝐮𝐞^^𝐭𝐫𝐮𝐞\widehat{\bf true}over^ start_ARG bold_true end_ARG is V𝑉Vitalic_V and has no minimal element, therefore 𝐭𝐫𝐮𝐞⁢ ∼ ⁢𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐬𝐞𝐭𝐫𝐮𝐞 ∼ 𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐬𝐞{\bf true}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }{\bf false}bold_true ∼ bold_false. But p^^𝑝\widehat{p}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG consists only of the top element and has a minimal point and therefore p𝑝pitalic_p  ≁not-similar-to absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim≁ false. We have shown that the Rule 14 is not valid for Delgrande’s structures. This example also shows that Delgrande’s logic does not posses the finite model property.

A third difference is that his definition of the set of conditional assertions entailed by a conditional knowledge base is different from the one presented here, at least at first sight.

4 Ranked entailment

4.1 Introduction

After having defined the family of relations and the family of models we are interested in, we proceed to study the notion of entailment provided by those models. Our main result is presented in 4.2. It is negative, in the sense that this entailment is equivalent to preferential entailment. A preliminary version of this result may be found in [19]. The collapsing of the two notions of entailment, as opposed to the two different classes of relations represented, sheds a new light on the results of [1]. Section 4.3 describes the probabilistic semantics given to preferential entailment by E. Adams in [1] and shows how the result of Section 4.2 provides an alternative proof for Adams’ results. The results of this section were contained in [19].

4.2 Ranked entailment is preferential entailment

In the discussion of Section 3.5, we expressed the wish that the set of assertions entailed by a conditional knowledge base K be rational and larger than 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. A natural candidate would be the set of all assertions that are satisfied in all ranked models that satisfy the assertions of K. This is an intersection of rational relations. This proposal fails in a spectacular way. Problems with this proposal have been noted in [8, Section 4]. It is also easy to see that the intersection of rational relations may fail to be rational. Theorem 6 shows this failure to be total.

Lemma 18

Let ℰℰ{\cal E}caligraphic_E be any preferential relation. There exists a rational extension of ℰℰ{\cal E}caligraphic_E for which a formula is inconsistent only if it is inconsistent for ℰℰ{\cal E}caligraphic_E.

Proof: Let us choose some enumeration of triples of formulas α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, β𝛽\betaitalic_β and γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ in which every triple appears an unbounded number of times. Let K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be equal to ℰℰ{\cal E}caligraphic_E. At every step i𝑖iitalic_i we define Ki+1subscript𝐾𝑖1K_{i+1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the following way. Let α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, β𝛽\betaitalic_β and γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ be the triple enumerated at step i𝑖iitalic_i. Unless Kisubscript𝐾𝑖K_{i}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains the pair α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ but contains neither α∧β𝛼𝛽\alpha\wedge\betaitalic_α ∧ italic_β  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ nor α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢β𝛽\neg\beta¬ italic_β, we shall take Ki+1subscript𝐾𝑖1K_{i+1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to be equal to Kisubscript𝐾𝑖K_{i}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. If Kisubscript𝐾𝑖K_{i}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies the condition above, we shall take Ki+1subscript𝐾𝑖1K_{i+1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to be the preferential closure of Ki∪{α ∼ β}subscript𝐾𝑖α ∼ βK_{i}\cup\{\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\mbox{$\beta$}\}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∪ { roman_α ∼ roman_β }. Notice that, by Cautious Monotonicity, α∧β𝛼𝛽\alpha\wedge\betaitalic_α ∧ italic_β  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ will enter Ki+1subscript𝐾𝑖1K_{i+1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. It is clear that the Kisubscript𝐾𝑖K_{i}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT’s provide an increasing sequence of preferential extensions of ℰℰ{\cal E}caligraphic_E. Let K∞subscript𝐾K_{\infty}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the union of all the Kisubscript𝐾𝑖K_{i}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT’s. Clearly K∞subscript𝐾K_{\infty}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a preferential extension of ℰℰ{\cal E}caligraphic_E. By construction, and since we took care of removing all counter-examples to the rule of Rational Monotonicity, K∞subscript𝐾K_{\infty}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a rational consequence relation. We claim that a formula α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is inconsistent for K∞subscript𝐾K_{\infty}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (i.e., α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ false is in K∞subscript𝐾K_{\infty}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) only if it is inconsistent already for ℰℰ{\cal E}caligraphic_E. Indeed, if α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is inconsistent for K∞subscript𝐾K_{\infty}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT it must be inconsistent for some Kisubscript𝐾𝑖K_{i}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, but Theorem 3 shows that, by construction, all Kisubscript𝐾𝑖K_{i}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT’s have the same inconsistent formulas.     

Theorem 6

If the assertion 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A is satisfied by all ranked models that satisfy all the assertions of K, then it is satisfied by all preferential such models.

Proof: Let 𝒜=defδ⁢ ∼ ⁢εsuperscriptdef𝒜𝛿 ∼ 𝜀{\cal A}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}\delta\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\varepsiloncaligraphic_A start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP italic_δ ∼ italic_ε be as in the hypotheses. Let ℰℰ{\cal E}caligraphic_E be the rational extension of the preferential closure of 𝐊∪{δ⁢ ∼ ⁢¬⁢ε}𝐊𝛿 ∼ 𝜀{\bf K}\cup\{\delta\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\neg\varepsilon\}bold_K ∪ { italic_δ ∼ ¬ italic_ε }, whose existence is asserted by Lemma 18. The assertion δ⁢ ∼ ⁢ε𝛿 ∼ 𝜀\delta\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\varepsilonitalic_δ ∼ italic_ε is in ℰℰ{\cal E}caligraphic_E since it is in any rational relation that extends K, by Theorem 5. Since δ⁢ ∼ ⁢¬⁢ε𝛿 ∼ 𝜀\delta\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\neg\varepsilonitalic_δ ∼ ¬ italic_ε is obviously in ℰℰ{\cal E}caligraphic_E, we conclude that δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ is inconsistent for ℰℰ{\cal E}caligraphic_E and therefore inconsistent for the preferential closure of 𝐊∪{δ⁢ ∼ ⁢¬⁢ε}𝐊𝛿 ∼ 𝜀{\bf K}\cup\{\delta\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\neg\varepsilon\}bold_K ∪ { italic_δ ∼ ¬ italic_ε }. By Corollary 3, 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A is preferentially entailed by K.     

4.3 Comparison with Adams’ probabilistic entailment

In this section we shall show that ranked models are closely related to Adams’ probabilistic entailment described in [1]. Theorem 6, then, provides an alternative proof of Adams’ axiomatic characterization of probabilistic entailment. There are some technical differences between Adams’ framework and ours since Adams insists on allowing formulas as conditional assertions: for him the formula α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is a synonym for true  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. We also insist on studying infinite knowledge bases whenever possible, where Adams restricts himself to finite knowledge bases.

A probability assignment for the language ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L is a probability measure on ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L yielded by some probability measure given on 𝒰𝒰{\cal U}caligraphic_U. E. Adams proposed the following definitions.

Definition 15 (Adams)

A probability assignment p𝑝pitalic_p for the language ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L is said to be proper for a conditional assertion α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β iff p⁢(α)>0𝑝𝛼0p(\alpha)>0italic_p ( italic_α ) > 0. It is proper for a set of conditional assertions iff it is proper for each element. If p𝑝pitalic_p is proper for 𝒜=defαsuperscriptnormal-def𝒜𝛼{\cal A}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}\alphacaligraphic_A start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP italic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β, we shall use p⁢(𝒜)𝑝𝒜p({\cal A})italic_p ( caligraphic_A ) to denote the conditional probability p⁢(β∣α)𝑝conditional𝛽𝛼p(\beta\mid\alpha)italic_p ( italic_β ∣ italic_α ).

Definition 16 (Adams)

Let K be a set of conditional assertions. We shall say that K is probabilistically consistent if and only if for any real number ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0italic_ϵ > 0 there exists a probability assignment p𝑝pitalic_p for ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L that is proper for K and such that, for all 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A in K, one has p⁢(𝒜)≥1−ϵ𝑝𝒜1italic-ϵp({\cal A})\geq 1-\epsilonitalic_p ( caligraphic_A ) ≥ 1 - italic_ϵ.

Definition 17

Let K be a set of conditional assertions and 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A a conditional assertion. We shall say that K probabilistically entails 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A iff for all ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0italic_ϵ > 0 there exists δ>0𝛿0\delta>0italic_δ > 0 such that for all probability assignments p𝑝pitalic_p for ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L which are proper for K and 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A, if p⁢(ℬ)≥1−δ𝑝ℬ1𝛿p({\cal B})\geq 1-\deltaitalic_p ( caligraphic_B ) ≥ 1 - italic_δ for all ℬℬ{\cal B}caligraphic_B in K, then p⁢(𝒜)≥1−ϵ𝑝𝒜1italic-ϵp({\cal A})\geq 1-\epsilonitalic_p ( caligraphic_A ) ≥ 1 - italic_ϵ.

In [1], Adams studies extensively the relations between the two notions of probabilistic consistency and probabilistic entailment, at least for finite sets of conditional assertions. Here we shall only show the fundamental relation that exists between Adams’ notions and ours. First, we shall make three easy remarks. The first one concerns only probabilistic notions and was claimed by Adams for finite knowledge bases but is true in general.

Lemma 19

A set K of conditional assertions is probabilistically inconsistent iff it probabilistically entails any conditional assertion.

Our second remark provides a first link between probabilistic notions and the notions introduced in this paper. It is essentially the soundness part of Adams’ soundness and completeness result (see beginning of proof of 4.2 at page 62 of [1]). This is the easy direction.

Lemma 20

Any conditional assertion preferentially entailed by K is probabilistically entailed by K.

Our third remark is the following.

Lemma 21

If the conditional assertion α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β is in K and α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ false is preferentially entailed by K then K is probabilistically inconsistent.

Proof: Under the assumptions of the lemma, Lemma 20 shows that α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ false is probabilistically entailed by K. But for any probability assignment p𝑝pitalic_p that is proper for α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β, p⁢(α⁢ ∼𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐬𝐞)𝑝similar-to𝛼 𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐬𝐞p(\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim{\bf false})italic_p ( italic_α ∼ bold_false ) is defined and equal to 00. Since K probabilistically entails α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ false we conclude that there is an ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0italic_ϵ > 0 such that no probability assignment that is proper for K and α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β gives probabilities larger than 1−ϵ1italic-ϵ1-\epsilon1 - italic_ϵ to all assertions of K. Since any probability assignment that is proper for K is also proper for α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β the conclusion is proved.     

We shall now prove the converse of Lemma 20 in the case K is finite and probabilistically consistent. The basic remark is the following. Suppose W𝑊Witalic_W is a finite (i.e., the set S𝑆Sitalic_S of states is finite) ranked model. Let ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0italic_ϵ > 0 be some real number. We shall describe a probability measure pϵsubscript𝑝italic-ϵp_{\epsilon}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on S𝑆Sitalic_S. The first principle that will be used in defining pϵsubscript𝑝italic-ϵp_{\epsilon}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is that all states of the same rank will have equal probabilities. The second principle is that the weight of the set of all states of rank n𝑛nitalic_n, wnsubscript𝑤𝑛w_{n}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will be such that wn+1wn=ϵsubscript𝑤𝑛1subscript𝑤𝑛italic-ϵ{w_{n+1}\over w_{n}}=\epsilondivide start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = italic_ϵ. The intuitive meaning of this choice (since ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ will approach zero) is that normal states are more probable than exceptional states. There is clearly exactly one probability measure satisfying both principles above, for any given finite ranked model. The probability measure pϵsubscript𝑝italic-ϵp_{\epsilon}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, defined on states, yields a probability measure on formulas. It is clear that a formula α𝛼\alphaitalic_α has probability zero under pϵsubscript𝑝italic-ϵp_{\epsilon}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT iff α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is inconsistent in W𝑊Witalic_W, i.e., α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼Wsubscriptsimilar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}∼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT false. Suppose α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is consistent. Let us consider the conditional probability of β𝛽\betaitalic_β given α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, which is well defined. If α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼Wsubscriptsimilar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}∼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT β𝛽\betaitalic_β then this conditional probability is larger than 1−ϵ−ϵ2−ϵ3−…1italic-ϵsuperscriptitalic-ϵ2superscriptitalic-ϵ3…1-\epsilon-\epsilon^{2}-\epsilon^{3}-\dots1 - italic_ϵ - italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - … and therefore approaches one when ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ approaches zero. On the other hand, if α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ≁Wsubscriptnot-similar-to𝑊 absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}{\not\sim}_{W}≁ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT β𝛽\betaitalic_β, then this conditional probability cannot exceed 1−1m11𝑚1-{1\over m}1 - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG where m𝑚mitalic_m is the number of states at the rank which is minimal for α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. It is therefore bounded away from 1111 when ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ approaches 00.

Lemma 22

Let a finite probabilistically consistent knowledge base K be given and suppose 𝒜=defαsuperscriptnormal-def𝒜𝛼{\cal A}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}\alphacaligraphic_A start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP italic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β is not preferentially entailed by K. Then, K does not probabilistically entail 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A.

Proof: Let K and 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A be as described in the lemma. Let ℒ′superscriptℒ′{\cal L^{\prime}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be some logically finite sublanguage of ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L that contains α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, β𝛽\betaitalic_β and all propositions appearing in K. Relative to ℒ′superscriptℒ′{\cal L^{\prime}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the hypotheses of the lemma are still true. By Lemmas 18 and Theorem 3, there is a rational relation ℰℰ{\cal E}caligraphic_E that contains K and α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢β𝛽\neg\beta¬ italic_β and for which a formula is inconsistent only if it is inconsistent for 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. By Theorem 5, there is a finite ranked model, W𝑊Witalic_W that satisfies α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢β𝛽\neg\beta¬ italic_β and all assertions of K but whose inconsistent formulas are exactly those of 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Since α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is not inconsistent for 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the model W𝑊Witalic_W does not satisfy α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β. Let W′superscript𝑊′W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the model obtained by extending the labeling function of W𝑊Witalic_W to the full language ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L in an arbitrary way. We shall now apply the construction of pϵsubscript𝑝italic-ϵp_{\epsilon}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT described above on the model W′superscript𝑊′W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Using the model W′superscript𝑊′W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and a sequence of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ’s approaching zero, we define a sequence of probability measures pϵsubscript𝑝italic-ϵp_{\epsilon}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let us show that all assignments pϵsubscript𝑝italic-ϵp_{\epsilon}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are proper for K and 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A. If γ∈L′𝛾superscript𝐿′\gamma\in L^{\prime}italic_γ ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the assignment pϵsubscript𝑝italic-ϵp_{\epsilon}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT gives zero probability to γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ iff γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ is inconsistent in W𝑊Witalic_W, i.e., inconsistent for 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. But K is probabilistically consistent and, by Lemma 21, pϵsubscript𝑝italic-ϵp_{\epsilon}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is proper for K. Since W′superscript𝑊′W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT does not satisfy 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A, its antecedent cannot be inconsistent in W′superscript𝑊′W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and pϵsubscript𝑝italic-ϵp_{\epsilon}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is proper for 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A too. When ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ approaches zero, the conditional probabilities corresponding to each assertion of K approach 1111 and the conditional probability corresponding to A is bounded away from 1111.     

That the result cannot be extended to infinite sets of conditional assertions follows from Adams’ remark that his notion of probabilistic consistency does not enjoy the compactness property and from Corollary 1. Adams’ example [1, pages 51–52] is closely related to the construction of Lemma 1. The results of Adams presented in this section have been interpreted, in particular by [26], to mean that probabilistic semantics validate preferential reasoning. We certainly agree. But the results that will be presented now show, in our opinion, that probabilistic semantics support the claim that inference procedures should not only be preferential but also rational. Indeed we show, in Appendix B, that some very natural probabilistic models always define rational relations and that, when the language ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L is countable, all rational relations may be defined by such models. Those models are non-standard probability spaces, in the sense of A. Robinson. Since no use of those models will be made in the paper, their treatment has been relegated to an appendix.

5 The rational closure of a conditional knowledge base

5.1 Introduction

So far, we have argued for Thesis 1 and gathered much knowledge about rational relations, showing in particular that there is no obvious way to define a notion of closure satisfying Thesis 1. In this section we shall show that there is a natural notion of closure (called rational closure) that satisfies Thesis 1. We shall study it and prove that it possesses many very elegant mathematical properties. We shall, then, evaluate the value of rational closure as an answer to the question of the title. In conclusion, we shall propose Thesis 2, that claims that any satisfactory answer is a superset of rational closure. In other terms we think that any reasonable system should endorse any assertion contained in the rational closure, but it may also endorse some additional assertions. At present, we do not know of any natural construction satisfying Thesis 1 other than rational closure.

A first possible answer is rejected in 5.2. This result appeared in [18]. The remainder of the paper describes rational closure. In 5.3 a partial ordering between rational relations is defined, which captures the notion of a relation being preferable to (i.e., smaller, less adventurous, more reasonable than) another one. The rational closure of a knowledge base is then defined in 5.4 as the rational extension of a knowledge base that is preferable in the ordering defined in Section 5.3 to all other rational extensions. Not every knowledge base has a rational closure, but in Section 5.6 it will be shown that any admissible (see Definition 11) knowledge base has a rational closure. By Lemma 7, then, any finite knowledge base has a rational closure. We claim that the rational closure of a knowledge base, when it exists, provides a reasonable answer to the question of the title. Global properties of the operation of rational closure are described in 5.5. These results, concerning the global behavior of a nonmonotonic inference operation, are the first of their kind. In 5.6 an algorithmic construction of the rational closure of an admissible knowledge base is described. This algorithmic description essentially replaces and improves upon the proof-theoretic description of [18]. A corrected and generalized model-theoretic construction, first described in [18] is proposed in 5.7. Section 5.8 presents an algorithm to compute the rational closure of a finite knowledge base and discusses complexity issues. Section 5.9 discusses the appeal of rational closure and provides some examples. Section 6 concludes by considering topics for further research. In [27] J. Pearl proposes his own version of the rational closure construction that had been described in [18].

5.2 Perfect extensions

All that has been done so far does not allow us to give a satisfactory answer to the question of the title. Let K be a set of conditional assertions. We would like to define a consequence relation 𝐊¯¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG, the rational closure of K, that contains all the conditional assertions that we intuitively expect to follow from K. At this point the reader should be convinced that 𝐊¯¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG should be a rational consequence relation that extends K. Any such relation obviously also extends 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. It seems that we would also like this rational extension of K to be as small as possible. Unfortunately Theorem 6 shows that the intersection of all rational extensions of K is exactly 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and therefore not in general rational and highly unsuitable as shown in Section 3.5. There is obviously a maximal such extension: the full consequence relation, (i.e., α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β for all α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, β𝛽\betaitalic_β in ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L) but this is certainly not the one we are looking for. Can we find out a number of properties that we would like 𝐊¯¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG to possess, in order to, at least, narrow the field of possibilities? We shall look both for local properties of 𝐊¯¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG with respect to K and for global properties of the mapping 𝐊↦𝐊¯maps-to𝐊¯𝐊{\bf K}\mapsto\overline{\bf K}bold_K ↦ over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG. The sequel will present a proposal for the definition of 𝐊¯¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG and proofs that it enjoys both local and global (in particular a strong form of cumulativity) properties.

If 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT happens to be rational, then we probably have no reason to look further and should take 𝐊¯¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG to be equal to 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. If 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is not rational, then there is an assertion α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β in 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and a formula γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ such that neither α∧γ𝛼𝛾\alpha\wedge\gammaitalic_α ∧ italic_γ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β nor α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢γ𝛾\neg\gamma¬ italic_γ are in 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. It seems that the right thing to do, in most such cases, is to introduce α∧γ𝛼𝛾\alpha\wedge\gammaitalic_α ∧ italic_γ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β in 𝐊¯¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG. One may try to require that any assertion in 𝐊¯−𝐊p¯𝐊superscript𝐊𝑝\overline{\bf K}-{\bf K}^{p}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG - bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be of the form α∧γ𝛼𝛾\alpha\wedge\gammaitalic_α ∧ italic_γ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β where α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β is in 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, i.e., that any assertion in 𝐊¯−𝐊p¯𝐊superscript𝐊𝑝\overline{\bf K}-{\bf K}^{p}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG - bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT have support in 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. It will be shown that this may well be impossible. Let us encapsulate this idea in definitions.

Definition 18

An assertion α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β is said to be supported by (or in) 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT iff there is a formula γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ such that α⊧γmodels𝛼𝛾\alpha\models\gammaitalic_α ⊧ italic_γ and γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β is in 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Definition 19

A rational extension 𝐊′superscript𝐊normal-′{\bf K}^{\prime}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of K is called perfect iff every assertion of 𝐊′superscript𝐊normal-′{\bf K}^{\prime}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is supported by 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

We may present the following disappointing result.

Lemma 23

There is a finite conditional knowledge base that has no rational perfect extension.

Proof: Let ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L be the set of all propositional formulas built out of the set of four propositional variables: {a,b,c,d}𝑎𝑏𝑐𝑑\{a,b,c,d\}{ italic_a , italic_b , italic_c , italic_d }. Let W𝑊Witalic_W be the preferential model with three states: {s,t,u}𝑠𝑡𝑢\{s,t,u\}{ italic_s , italic_t , italic_u }, in which s≺tprecedes𝑠𝑡s\prec titalic_s ≺ italic_t (and this is the only pair in the relation ≺precedes\prec≺) and s𝑠sitalic_s satisfies only a𝑎aitalic_a, t𝑡titalic_t satisfies only b𝑏bitalic_b and u𝑢uitalic_u satisfies only c𝑐citalic_c and d𝑑ditalic_d. Let K be the set of all conditional assertions satisfied in W𝑊Witalic_W. We claim that K has no rational perfect extension. Notice, first, that W𝑊Witalic_W satisfies a∨b𝑎𝑏a\vee bitalic_a ∨ italic_b  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢b𝑏\neg b¬ italic_b. This assertion is therefore in K. Any ranked model satisfying a∨b𝑎𝑏a\vee bitalic_a ∨ italic_b  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢b𝑏\neg b¬ italic_b must satisfy at least one of the following two assertions: a∨c𝑎𝑐a\vee citalic_a ∨ italic_c  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢c𝑐\neg c¬ italic_c or b∨c𝑏𝑐b\vee citalic_b ∨ italic_c  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢b𝑏\neg b¬ italic_b. Any rational extension of K must therefore contain one of the two assertions above. But a∨c𝑎𝑐a\vee citalic_a ∨ italic_c  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢c𝑐\neg c¬ italic_c has clearly no support in 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and therefore any perfect rational extension of K must contain: b∨c𝑏𝑐b\vee citalic_b ∨ italic_c  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢b𝑏\neg b¬ italic_b. But W𝑊Witalic_W satisfies c𝑐citalic_c  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ d𝑑ditalic_d and any ranked model satisfying both b∨c𝑏𝑐b\vee citalic_b ∨ italic_c  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢b𝑏\neg b¬ italic_b and c𝑐citalic_c  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ d𝑑ditalic_d must also satisfy b∨c𝑏𝑐b\vee citalic_b ∨ italic_c  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ d𝑑ditalic_d. Any perfect rational extension of K must therefore contain this last formula but it clearly lacks support in 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We conclude that K has no perfect rational extension.     

It is therefore reasonable to look for less than perfect extensions. Let us first examine perfection concerning two special kinds of formulas. The following is easily proved.

Lemma 24

An assertion of the form α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ false is supported by 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT iff it is in 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. An assertion of the form true  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is supported by 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT iff it is in 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

We shall propose a construction of 𝐊¯¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG such that 𝐊¯¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG does not contain any formula of the form α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ false or of the form true  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ α𝛼\alphaitalic_α that is not in 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

5.3 Ordering rational relations

In this section we shall define a strict partial ordering between rational relations. This ordering captures the notion of a relation being preferable to, i.e., less adventurous than another one. An intuitive explanation will be given immediately after the definition. For the rest of this section we shall write α<β𝛼𝛽\alpha<\betaitalic_α < italic_β for ( or in) K to mean the assertion α∨β𝛼𝛽\alpha\vee\betaitalic_α ∨ italic_β  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢β𝛽\neg\beta¬ italic_β is in K𝐾Kitalic_K. We shall write α≤β𝛼𝛽\alpha\leq\betaitalic_α ≤ italic_β for ( or in) K𝐾Kitalic_K when it is not the case that β𝛽\betaitalic_β<<<α𝛼\alphaitalic_α in K𝐾Kitalic_K.

Definition 20

Let K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be two rational consequence relations. We shall say that K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is preferable to K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and write K0≺K1precedessubscript𝐾0subscript𝐾1K_{0}\prec K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≺ italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT iff:

  1. 1.

    there exists an assertion α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β in K1−K0subscript𝐾1subscript𝐾0K_{1}-K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that for all γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ such that γ<α𝛾𝛼\gamma<\alphaitalic_γ < italic_α for K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and for all δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ such that γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ is in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we also have γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and

  2. 2.

    for any γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ  if γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ is in K0−K1subscript𝐾0subscript𝐾1K_{0}-K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT there is an assertion ρ⁢ ∼ηsimilar-to𝜌 𝜂\rho\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\etaitalic_ρ ∼ italic_η in K1−K0subscript𝐾1subscript𝐾0K_{1}-K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that ρ<γ𝜌𝛾\rho<\gammaitalic_ρ < italic_γ for K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

The intuitive explanation behind Definition 20 is the following. Suppose two agents, who agree on a common knowledge base, are discussing the respective merits of two rational relations K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. A typical attack would be: your relation contains an assertion, α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β, that mine does not contain (and therefore contains unsupported assertions). A possible defense against such an attack could be: yes, but your relation contains an assertion γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ that mine does not, and you yourself think that γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ refers to a situation that is more usual than the one refered to by α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. Such a defense must be accepted as valid. Definition 20 exactly says that the proponent of K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has an attack that the proponent of K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT cannot defend against (this is part 1) but that he (i.e., the proponent of K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) may find a defense against any attack from the proponent of K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (this is part 2 of the definition).

Lemma 25

The relation ≺precedes\prec≺ between rational consequence relations is irreflexive and transitive.

Proof: Irreflexivity follows immediately from Condition 1. For transitivity, let us suppose that K0≺K1precedessubscript𝐾0subscript𝐾1K_{0}\prec K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≺ italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β the witness promised by Condition 1 and that K1≺K2precedessubscript𝐾1subscript𝐾2K_{1}\prec K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≺ italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ as a witness. Our first step will be to show that there exists an assertion ε𝜀\varepsilonitalic_ε ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ζ𝜁\zetaitalic_ζ in K2−K0subscript𝐾2subscript𝐾0K_{2}-K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that ε≤α𝜀𝛼\varepsilon\leq\alphaitalic_ε ≤ italic_α in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ε≤γ𝜀𝛾\varepsilon\leq\gammaitalic_ε ≤ italic_γ in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We shall have to consider many different cases.

  1. 1.

    Suppose γ<α𝛾𝛼\gamma<\alphaitalic_γ < italic_α in K2subscript𝐾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

    1. (a)

      If γ<α𝛾𝛼\gamma<\alphaitalic_γ < italic_α is not in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then γ<α𝛾𝛼\gamma<\alphaitalic_γ < italic_α is a suitable ε𝜀\varepsilonitalic_ε ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ζ𝜁\zetaitalic_ζ.

    2. (b)

      If γ<α𝛾𝛼\gamma<\alphaitalic_γ < italic_α is in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ is a suitable ε𝜀\varepsilonitalic_ε ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ζ𝜁\zetaitalic_ζ, since if it were in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT it would be in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  2. 2.

    Suppose therefore that γ<α𝛾𝛼\gamma<\alphaitalic_γ < italic_α is not in K2subscript𝐾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., for K2subscript𝐾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, α≤γ𝛼𝛾\alpha\leq\gammaitalic_α ≤ italic_γ.

    1. (a)

      If γ<α𝛾𝛼\gamma<\alphaitalic_γ < italic_α is in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then it is in K1−K2subscript𝐾1subscript𝐾2K_{1}-K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and there is an assertion ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ η𝜂\etaitalic_η in K2−K1subscript𝐾2subscript𝐾1K_{2}-K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that ξ<γ∨α𝜉𝛾𝛼\xi<\gamma\vee\alphaitalic_ξ < italic_γ ∨ italic_α in K2subscript𝐾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

      1. i.

        If ξ<γ∨α𝜉𝛾𝛼\xi<\gamma\vee\alphaitalic_ξ < italic_γ ∨ italic_α is not in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then it is a suitable ε𝜀\varepsilonitalic_ε ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ζ𝜁\zetaitalic_ζ.

      2. ii.

        If ξ<γ∨α𝜉𝛾𝛼\xi<\gamma\vee\alphaitalic_ξ < italic_γ ∨ italic_α is in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then ξ<α𝜉𝛼\xi<\alphaitalic_ξ < italic_α in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and we have both that ξ<γ∨α𝜉𝛾𝛼\xi<\gamma\vee\alphaitalic_ξ < italic_γ ∨ italic_α in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and that ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ η𝜂\etaitalic_η cannot be in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, otherwise it would be in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We conclude that ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ η𝜂\etaitalic_η is a suitable ε𝜀\varepsilonitalic_ε ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ζ𝜁\zetaitalic_ζ.

    2. (b)

      Suppose therefore that γ<α𝛾𝛼\gamma<\alphaitalic_γ < italic_α is not in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., for K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, like for K2subscript𝐾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, α≤γ𝛼𝛾\alpha\leq\gammaitalic_α ≤ italic_γ.

      1. i.

        If α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β is in K2subscript𝐾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then it is a suitable ε𝜀\varepsilonitalic_ε ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ζ𝜁\zetaitalic_ζ.

      2. ii.

        If α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β is not in K2subscript𝐾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then it is in K1−K2subscript𝐾1subscript𝐾2K_{1}-K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and there is a ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ η𝜂\etaitalic_η in K2−K1subscript𝐾2subscript𝐾1K_{2}-K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that ξ<α𝜉𝛼\xi<\alphaitalic_ξ < italic_α in K2subscript𝐾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

        1. A.

          If ξ<α𝜉𝛼\xi<\alphaitalic_ξ < italic_α is not in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then it is a suitable ε𝜀\varepsilonitalic_ε ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ζ𝜁\zetaitalic_ζ since, in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ξ∨α≤α≤γ𝜉𝛼𝛼𝛾\xi\vee\alpha\leq\alpha\leq\gammaitalic_ξ ∨ italic_α ≤ italic_α ≤ italic_γ.

        2. B.

          If ξ<α𝜉𝛼\xi<\alphaitalic_ξ < italic_α is in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT then ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ η𝜂\etaitalic_η is a suitable ε𝜀\varepsilonitalic_ε ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ζ𝜁\zetaitalic_ζ since ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ η𝜂\etaitalic_η cannot be in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, otherwise it would be in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

We have now proved the existence of an assertion ε𝜀\varepsilonitalic_ε ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ζ𝜁\zetaitalic_ζ with the desired properties. Let us proceed to the proof that K0≺K2precedessubscript𝐾0subscript𝐾2K_{0}\prec K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≺ italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For property 1, we claim that ε𝜀\varepsilonitalic_ε ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ζ𝜁\zetaitalic_ζ provides a suitable witness. It is indeed in K2−K0subscript𝐾2subscript𝐾0K_{2}-K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by construction. Suppose now that ξ<ε𝜉𝜀\xi<\varepsilonitalic_ξ < italic_ε in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then ξ<α𝜉𝛼\xi<\alphaitalic_ξ < italic_α in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and therefore ξ<ε𝜉𝜀\xi<\varepsilonitalic_ξ < italic_ε in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Therefore ξ<γ𝜉𝛾\xi<\gammaitalic_ξ < italic_γ in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. If ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ η𝜂\etaitalic_η is in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then it must be in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT since ξ<α𝜉𝛼\xi<\alphaitalic_ξ < italic_α in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and also in K2subscript𝐾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT since ξ<γ𝜉𝛾\xi<\gammaitalic_ξ < italic_γ in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This concludes the verification of Condition 1.

For Condition 2, suppose that φ𝜑\varphiitalic_φ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ θ𝜃\thetaitalic_θ is in K0−K2subscript𝐾0subscript𝐾2K_{0}-K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We have to find a ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ η𝜂\etaitalic_η in K2−K0subscript𝐾2subscript𝐾0K_{2}-K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that ξ<φ𝜉𝜑\xi<\varphiitalic_ξ < italic_φ in K2subscript𝐾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We shall consider a number of different cases.

  1. 1.

    If ε<φ𝜀𝜑\varepsilon<\varphiitalic_ε < italic_φ in K2subscript𝐾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then ε𝜀\varepsilonitalic_ε ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ζ𝜁\zetaitalic_ζ is a suitable ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ η𝜂\etaitalic_η.

  2. 2.

    Suppose then that ε<φ𝜀𝜑\varepsilon<\varphiitalic_ε < italic_φ is not in K2subscript𝐾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., φ≤ε𝜑𝜀\varphi\leq\varepsilonitalic_φ ≤ italic_ε for K2subscript𝐾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

    1. (a)

      Suppose, first that ε<φ𝜀𝜑\varepsilon<\varphiitalic_ε < italic_φ is in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, therefore in K1−K2subscript𝐾1subscript𝐾2K_{1}-K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. There is then an assertion ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ in K2−K1subscript𝐾2subscript𝐾1K_{2}-K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that ρ<ε∨φ𝜌𝜀𝜑\rho<\varepsilon\vee\varphiitalic_ρ < italic_ε ∨ italic_φ in K2subscript𝐾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

      1. i.

        If ρ<ε∨φ𝜌𝜀𝜑\rho<\varepsilon\vee\varphiitalic_ρ < italic_ε ∨ italic_φ is in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then ρ<α𝜌𝛼\rho<\alphaitalic_ρ < italic_α in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and we conclude that ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ is not in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, otherwise it would be in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We conclude that ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ is a suitable ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ η𝜂\etaitalic_η.

      2. ii.

        If ρ<ε∨φ𝜌𝜀𝜑\rho<\varepsilon\vee\varphiitalic_ρ < italic_ε ∨ italic_φ is not in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then it is a suitable ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ η𝜂\etaitalic_η.

    2. (b)

      Suppose, then, that ε<φ𝜀𝜑\varepsilon<\varphiitalic_ε < italic_φ is not in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., for K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, φ≤ε𝜑𝜀\varphi\leq\varepsilonitalic_φ ≤ italic_ε.

      1. i.

        If ε<φ𝜀𝜑\varepsilon<\varphiitalic_ε < italic_φ is in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then it is in K0−K1subscript𝐾0subscript𝐾1K_{0}-K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Therefore there is an assertion ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ in K1−K0subscript𝐾1subscript𝐾0K_{1}-K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that ρ<ε∨φ𝜌𝜀𝜑\rho<\varepsilon\vee\varphiitalic_ρ < italic_ε ∨ italic_φ in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. But then ρ<γ𝜌𝛾\rho<\gammaitalic_ρ < italic_γ in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and we conclude that ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ is in K2subscript𝐾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and that ρ<φ𝜌𝜑\rho<\varphiitalic_ρ < italic_φ in K2subscript𝐾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The assertion ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ is a suitable ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ η𝜂\etaitalic_η.

      2. ii.

        Suppose, then that, on the contrary, ε<φ𝜀𝜑\varepsilon<\varphiitalic_ε < italic_φ is not in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., φ≤ε𝜑𝜀\varphi\leq\varepsilonitalic_φ ≤ italic_ε in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and K2subscript𝐾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

        1. A.
