          Suppose first that φ𝜑\varphiitalic_φ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ θ𝜃\thetaitalic_θ is in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, therefore in K1−K2subscript𝐾1subscript𝐾2K_{1}-K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then, there is an assertion ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ in K2−K1subscript𝐾2subscript𝐾1K_{2}-K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, such that ρ<φ𝜌𝜑\rho<\varphiitalic_ρ < italic_φ in K2subscript𝐾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. There are two cases. If ρ<φ𝜌𝜑\rho<\varphiitalic_ρ < italic_φ is in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then ρ<ε𝜌𝜀\rho<\varepsilonitalic_ρ < italic_ε in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ is not in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, otherwise it would be in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, since ρ<ε≤α𝜌𝜀𝛼\rho<\varepsilon\leq\alphaitalic_ρ < italic_ε ≤ italic_α in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The assertion ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ is a suitable ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ η𝜂\etaitalic_η. If, on the other hand ρ<φ𝜌𝜑\rho<\varphiitalic_ρ < italic_φ is not in K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then it is in K2−K0subscript𝐾2subscript𝐾0K_{2}-K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and it is a suitable ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ η𝜂\etaitalic_η.

        2. B.

          Suppose now that φ𝜑\varphiitalic_φ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ θ𝜃\thetaitalic_θ is not in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, therefore in K0−K1subscript𝐾0subscript𝐾1K_{0}-K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. There is an assertion ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ in K1−K0subscript𝐾1subscript𝐾0K_{1}-K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, such that ρ<φ𝜌𝜑\rho<\varphiitalic_ρ < italic_φ in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. But ρ<φ≤ε≤γ𝜌𝜑𝜀𝛾\rho<\varphi\leq\varepsilon\leq\gammaitalic_ρ < italic_φ ≤ italic_ε ≤ italic_γ in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and since ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ is in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT it must be in K2subscript𝐾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Also, since ρ<φ𝜌𝜑\rho<\varphiitalic_ρ < italic_φ is in K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, it must be in K2subscript𝐾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We see that ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ is a suitable ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ η𝜂\etaitalic_η.

   

5.4 Definition of rational closure

We may now define the rational closure of a knowledge base.

Definition 21

Let K be an arbitrary knowledge base. If there is a rational extension 𝐊¯normal-¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG of K that is preferable to all other rational extensions of K, then 𝐊¯normal-¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG will be called the rational closure of K.

Notice first that the rational closure of a knowledge base is unique, if it exists, since preference is a partial ordering. Notice then that there are knowledge bases that do not have a rational closure. Example 1 will show this. In Section 5.6 we shall show that admissible knowledge bases, including all finite knowledge bases, have a rational closure.

Example 1

Let ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L be the propositional calculus built upon the variables pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where n𝑛nitalic_n is an arbitrary integer (i.e., positive or negative). Let N𝑁Nitalic_N be the knowledge base that contains all assertions of the form pn⁢ ∼pn+2similar-tosubscript𝑝𝑛 subscript𝑝𝑛2p_{n}\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim p_{n+2}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and of the form pn⁢ ∼¬⁢pn−2similar-tosubscript𝑝𝑛 subscript𝑝𝑛2p_{n}\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg p_{n-2}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ ¬ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all integers n𝑛nitalic_n. We shall show that N𝑁Nitalic_N has no rational closure.

We shall first prove a lemma about invariance of the operation of rational closure under renaming of the proposional variables. This lemma is of independent interest.

Definition 22
  1. 1.

    A renaming of the propositional calculus ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L is a bijection of the propositional variables.

  2. 2.

    Let f𝑓fitalic_f be a renaming of ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L. The formula obtained from α𝛼\alphaitalic_α by substituting f⁢(p)𝑓𝑝f(p)italic_f ( italic_p ) for the propositional variable p𝑝pitalic_p will be denoted by f⁢(α)𝑓𝛼f(\mbox{$\alpha$})italic_f ( italic_α ).

  3. 3.

    Let f𝑓fitalic_f be as above and α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β a conditional assertion. The assertion f⁢(α)⁢ ∼f⁢(β)similar-to𝑓𝛼 𝑓𝛽f(\mbox{$\alpha$})\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim f(\mbox{$\beta$})italic_f ( italic_α ) ∼ italic_f ( italic_β ) will be denoted by f⁢(α⁢ ∼β)𝑓similar-to𝛼 𝛽f(\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\beta)italic_f ( italic_α ∼ italic_β ).

  4. 4.

    Let f𝑓fitalic_f be as above and K𝐾Kitalic_K a consequence relation. The relation f⁢(K)𝑓𝐾f(K)italic_f ( italic_K ) will be defined by f⁢(K)={f⁢(α ∼ β)∣α ∼ β∈K}𝑓𝐾conditional-set𝑓α ∼ βα ∼ β𝐾f(K)=\{f(\mbox{\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\mbox{$\beta$}})\mid\mbox{\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\mbox{$\beta$}}\in K\}italic_f ( italic_K ) = { italic_f ( italic_α italic_∼ italic_β ) ∣ italic_α italic_∼ italic_β ∈ italic_K }.

Lemma 26 (Invariance under renaming)

Let f𝑓fitalic_f be a renaming of ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L.

  1. 1.

    Let K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be rational consequence relations. Then K0≺K1precedessubscript𝐾0subscript𝐾1K_{0}\prec K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≺ italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT iff f⁢(K0)≺f⁢(K1)precedes𝑓subscript𝐾0𝑓subscript𝐾1f(K_{0})\prec f(K_{1})italic_f ( italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≺ italic_f ( italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

  2. 2.

    Let K𝐾Kitalic_K be a consequence relation and K¯¯𝐾\overline{K}over¯ start_ARG italic_K end_ARG its rational closure ,then f⁢(K¯)𝑓¯𝐾f(\overline{K})italic_f ( over¯ start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ) is the rational closure of f⁢(K)𝑓𝐾f(K)italic_f ( italic_K )

  3. 3.

    Let K𝐾Kitalic_K be a consequence relation which is invariant under f𝑓fitalic_f, namely f⁢(K)=K𝑓𝐾𝐾f(K)=Kitalic_f ( italic_K ) = italic_K,then its rational closure (if it exists) is invariant under f𝑓fitalic_f.

Proof: The proof is immediate from the definitions, noting that f𝑓fitalic_f is also a bijection of the set of all consequence relations.     

Lemma 27

The knowledge base N𝑁Nitalic_N defined above has no rational closure.

Proof: We shall reason by contradiction. Suppose R𝑅Ritalic_R is the rational closure of N𝑁Nitalic_N. From Lemma 30 in the sequel (the proof of which does not depend on the present lemma), we know that there is no assertion of the form α ∼ ⁢𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐬𝐞α ∼ 𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐬𝐞\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }{\bf false}roman_α ∼ bold_false in R𝑅Ritalic_R that is not in Npsuperscript𝑁𝑝N^{p}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Using a construction very similar to the one used in the proof of Lemma 1, one may build, for any integer n𝑛nitalic_n, a preferential model of N𝑁Nitalic_N, containing a top state that satisfies pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Therefore, for any n𝑛nitalic_n, pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is consistent for R𝑅Ritalic_R.

Remember that a<b𝑎𝑏a<bitalic_a < italic_b is the assertion a∨b𝑎𝑏a\vee bitalic_a ∨ italic_b  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢b𝑏\neg b¬ italic_b. We shall write a<b𝑎𝑏a<bitalic_a < italic_b to mean that a∨b𝑎𝑏a\vee bitalic_a ∨ italic_b  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢b𝑏\neg b¬ italic_b is in R𝑅Ritalic_R. If follows from results of Section 3.6 that, on formulas that are consistent for R𝑅Ritalic_R, the relation <<< is a strict modular ordering. Notice, also, that, for any n𝑛nitalic_n, the assertion pn+2<pnsubscript𝑝𝑛2subscript𝑝𝑛p_{n+2}<p_{n}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT belongs to Npsuperscript𝑁𝑝N^{p}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, since both pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ pn+2subscript𝑝𝑛2p_{n+2}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and pn+2subscript𝑝𝑛2p_{n+2}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢pnsubscript𝑝𝑛\neg p_{n}¬ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are in Npsuperscript𝑁𝑝N^{p}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore pn+2<pnsubscript𝑝𝑛2subscript𝑝𝑛p_{n+2}<p_{n}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. There are, in R𝑅Ritalic_R, two infinite (in both directions) chains (for <<<), one containing the variables of odd index, the other one containing those of even index. Since <<< is modular, we may consider only four cases:

  1. 1.

    For every even n𝑛nitalic_n and odd k𝑘kitalic_k, pn>pksubscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝑝𝑘p_{n}>p_{k}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let f𝑓fitalic_f be the renaming of ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L given by f⁢(m)=m+1𝑓𝑚𝑚1f(m)=m+1italic_f ( italic_m ) = italic_m + 1. Clearly f⁢(N)=N𝑓𝑁𝑁f(N)=Nitalic_f ( italic_N ) = italic_N. Hence, by Lemma  26 we must have f⁢(R)=R𝑓𝑅𝑅f(R)=Ritalic_f ( italic_R ) = italic_R. But this last statement implies pn>pksubscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝑝𝑘p_{n}>p_{k}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for even n𝑛nitalic_n and odd k𝑘kitalic_k, and therefore implies that all pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT’s are inconsistent for R𝑅Ritalic_R. A contradiction.

  2. 2.

    For every even n𝑛nitalic_n and odd k𝑘kitalic_k, pn<pksubscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝑝𝑘p_{n}<p_{k}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The argument is exactly as in case 1, systematically interchanging ‘odd’ and ‘even’.

  3. 3.

    There is an odd k𝑘kitalic_k ,and there are even m𝑚mitalic_m and n𝑛nitalic_n such that pn<pk<pmsubscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝑝𝑚p_{n}<p_{k}<p_{m}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In this case, define a renaming f𝑓fitalic_f by f⁢(l)=l𝑓𝑙𝑙f(l)=litalic_f ( italic_l ) = italic_l for odd l𝑙litalic_l and f⁢(l)=l+m−n𝑓𝑙𝑙𝑚𝑛f(l)=l+m-nitalic_f ( italic_l ) = italic_l + italic_m - italic_n for even l𝑙litalic_l. The contradiction is as above by noting that f𝑓fitalic_f transforms pn<pksubscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝑝𝑘p_{n}<p_{k}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT into pm<pksubscript𝑝𝑚subscript𝑝𝑘p_{m}<p_{k}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  4. 4.

    None of the above is true. In such a case one may see that there must exist an even m𝑚mitalic_m ,and odd i𝑖iitalic_i and j𝑗jitalic_j such that pi<pm<pjsubscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑝𝑚subscript𝑝𝑗p_{i}<p_{m}<p_{j}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The argument is exactly as in case 3, systematically interchanging ‘odd’ and ‘even’.

   

5.5 Global properties of the operation of rational closure

First, we show that rational closure possesses a loop property analogous to the property discussed in [17, Section 4]. This is a powerful property that one is happy to have.

Lemma 28 (Loop property)

Let Kisubscript𝐾𝑖K_{i}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for i=0,…,n−1𝑖0normal-…𝑛1i=0,\ldots,n-1italic_i = 0 , … , italic_n - 1 be knowledge bases such that, for any i𝑖iitalic_i, Ki+1⊆Ki¯subscript𝐾𝑖1normal-¯subscript𝐾𝑖K_{i+1}\subseteq\overline{K_{i}}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊆ over¯ start_ARG italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG, where addition is understood modulo n𝑛nitalic_n. Then for any i,j𝑖𝑗i,jitalic_i , italic_j, one has Ki¯=Kj¯normal-¯subscript𝐾𝑖normal-¯subscript𝐾𝑗\overline{K_{i}}=\overline{K_{j}}over¯ start_ARG italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = over¯ start_ARG italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG.

Proof: Let K⪯K′precedes-or-equals𝐾superscript𝐾′K\preceq K^{\prime}italic_K ⪯ italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT mean that either K≺K′precedes𝐾superscript𝐾′K\prec K^{\prime}italic_K ≺ italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or K=K′𝐾superscript𝐾′K=K^{\prime}italic_K = italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Since Ki¯¯subscript𝐾𝑖\overline{K_{i}}over¯ start_ARG italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG is a rational extension of Ki+1subscript𝐾𝑖1K_{i+1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we have Ki+1¯⪯Ki¯precedes-or-equals¯subscript𝐾𝑖1¯subscript𝐾𝑖\overline{K_{i+1}}\preceq\overline{K_{i}}over¯ start_ARG italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⪯ over¯ start_ARG italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG, for all i𝑖iitalic_i’s (modulo n𝑛nitalic_n). We conclude that the rational closures of all the 𝐊isubscript𝐊𝑖{\bf K}_{i}bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT’s are equal.     

The following property of reciprocity is the special case n=2𝑛2n=2italic_n = 2.

Corollary 4

If X⊆Y¯𝑋normal-¯𝑌X\subseteq\overline{Y}italic_X ⊆ over¯ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG and Y⊆X¯𝑌normal-¯𝑋Y\subseteq\overline{X}italic_Y ⊆ over¯ start_ARG italic_X end_ARG, then X¯=Y¯normal-¯𝑋normal-¯𝑌\overline{X}=\overline{Y}over¯ start_ARG italic_X end_ARG = over¯ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG.

The following property of cumulativity is equivalent to reciprocity in the presence of inclusion (i.e., K⊆K¯𝐾¯𝐾K\subseteq\overline{K}italic_K ⊆ over¯ start_ARG italic_K end_ARG).

Corollary 5

If X⊆Y⊆X¯𝑋𝑌normal-¯𝑋X\subseteq Y\subseteq\overline{X}italic_X ⊆ italic_Y ⊆ over¯ start_ARG italic_X end_ARG then X¯=Y¯normal-¯𝑋normal-¯𝑌\overline{X}=\overline{Y}over¯ start_ARG italic_X end_ARG = over¯ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG.

The meaning of Corollary 5 is that one may add to a knowledge base anything that is in its rational closure without changing this closure. We may now show that, in two different respects, rational closure is close to being perfect.

Lemma 29

The consequence relation 𝐊¯normal-¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG, if it exists, contains an assertion of the form true  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ α𝛼\alphaitalic_α only if this assertion is in 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Proof: Suppose an assertion of the form above is in 𝐊¯¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG. We shall show that it must be in any rational extension of K and will conclude by Theorem 6. Suppose K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a rational extension of K and true  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is in 𝐊¯−K′¯𝐊superscript𝐾′\overline{\bf K}-K^{\prime}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG - italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Since 𝐊¯¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG≺K′precedesabsentsuperscript𝐾′\prec K^{\prime}≺ italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we know there is an assertion γ⁢ ∼δsimilar-to𝛾 𝛿\gamma\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\deltaitalic_γ ∼ italic_δ in K′−𝐊¯superscript𝐾′¯𝐊K^{\prime}-\overline{\bf K}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG such that γ<𝛾absent\gamma<italic_γ < true in K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. But this means true  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ false is in K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and contradicts the fact that true  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is not in K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.     

Lemma 30

The consequence relation 𝐊¯normal-¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG, if it exists, contains an assertion of the form α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ false only if this assertion is in 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Proof: Let V𝑉Vitalic_V and T𝑇Titalic_T be preferential models defining the relations 𝐊¯¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG and 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT respectively. Such models exist by Theorem 1. Let U𝑈Uitalic_U be the model obtained by putting T𝑇Titalic_T on top of V𝑉Vitalic_V, i.e., every state of V𝑉Vitalic_V is less than every state of T𝑇Titalic_T. One easily sees that U𝑈Uitalic_U satisfies the smoothness property and is therefore a preferential model. It defines a preferential relation S𝑆Sitalic_S. An assertion of the form α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ false is in S𝑆Sitalic_S only if it is in 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, since T𝑇Titalic_T is a submodel of U𝑈Uitalic_U. If α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is not inconsistent in 𝐊¯¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG  then for any β𝛽\betaitalic_β, α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β is in S𝑆Sitalic_S iff it is in 𝐊¯¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG. By Lemma 18, there is a rational extension R𝑅Ritalic_R of S𝑆Sitalic_S with the same set of inconsistent formulas. If one looks at the construction described in the proof of this lemma, one sees that it will add to S𝑆Sitalic_S only assertions with antecedent inconsistent in 𝐊¯¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG. Therefore, if α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is not inconsistent in 𝐊¯¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG, for any β𝛽\betaitalic_β, α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β is in R𝑅Ritalic_R iff it is in 𝐊¯¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG. Now, R𝑅Ritalic_R is a rational extension of K. If R𝑅Ritalic_R is equal to 𝐊¯¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG, we are through. Suppose not. Then we have 𝐊¯≺Rprecedes¯𝐊𝑅\overline{\bf K}\prec Rover¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG ≺ italic_R. Suppose now that α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ false is in 𝐊¯−R¯𝐊𝑅\overline{\bf K}-Rover¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG - italic_R. There must be an assertion γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ in R−𝐊¯𝑅¯𝐊R-\overline{\bf K}italic_R - over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG such that γ<α𝛾𝛼\gamma<\alphaitalic_γ < italic_α in R𝑅Ritalic_R. But γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ in R−𝐊¯𝑅¯𝐊R-\overline{\bf K}italic_R - over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG implies that γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ false is in 𝐊¯¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG and γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ is in 𝐊¯¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG. A contradiction.     

5.6 Admissible knowledge bases and their rational closure

In this section, we show that an admissible (see Definition 11) knowledge base has a rational closure and that this rational closure may be defined in terms of the ranks of the formulas, as defined in Section 2.6. This provides a useful and elegant characterization of the rational closure of an admissible knowledge base.

Theorem 7

Let K be an admissible conditional knowledge base. The rational closure 𝐊¯normal-¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG of K exists and is the set S𝑆Sitalic_S of all assertions α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β such that either

  1. 1.

    the rank of α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is strictly less than the rank of α∧¬⁢β𝛼𝛽\alpha\wedge\neg\betaitalic_α ∧ ¬ italic_β (this includes the case α𝛼\alphaitalic_α has a rank and α∧¬⁢β𝛼𝛽\alpha\wedge\neg\betaitalic_α ∧ ¬ italic_β has none), or

  2. 2.

    α𝛼\alphaitalic_α has no rank (In this case α∧¬⁢β𝛼𝛽\alpha\wedge\neg\betaitalic_α ∧ ¬ italic_β has no rank either).

Proof: Suppose indeed that every formula consistent with 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has a rank. We have many things to check. First let us prove that S𝑆Sitalic_S contains K. If α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β is in K and α𝛼\alphaitalic_α has rank τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ, then Cτsubscript𝐶𝜏C_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β and entails true  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ α→β→𝛼𝛽\alpha\rightarrow\betaitalic_α → italic_β. Therefore α∧¬⁢β𝛼𝛽\alpha\wedge\neg\betaitalic_α ∧ ¬ italic_β is exceptional for Cτsubscript𝐶𝜏C_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and has rank strictly larger than τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ.

We should now check that S𝑆Sitalic_S is rational. For Left Logical Equivalence, Right Weakening and Reflexivity the proof is easy. For Cautious Monotonicity, notice that if α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β is in S𝑆Sitalic_S, then α𝛼\alphaitalic_α and α∧β𝛼𝛽\alpha\wedge\betaitalic_α ∧ italic_β have the same rank. For And and Or, notice that the rank of a disjunction is the smaller of the ranks of its components. For Rational Monotonicity, notice that if α⁢ ∼¬⁢βsimilar-to𝛼 𝛽\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\betaitalic_α ∼ ¬ italic_β is not in S𝑆Sitalic_S, then α𝛼\alphaitalic_α and α∧β𝛼𝛽\alpha\wedge\betaitalic_α ∧ italic_β have the same rank.

We must now check that if R𝑅Ritalic_R is a rational extension of K that is different from S𝑆Sitalic_S then S≺Rprecedes𝑆𝑅S\prec Ritalic_S ≺ italic_R. Let R𝑅Ritalic_R be such an extension. We shall first show that S𝑆Sitalic_S and R𝑅Ritalic_R must agree on all assertions whose antecedents have no rank (the notion of rank is always defined by reference to K). Indeed, by construction, any such assertion is in S𝑆Sitalic_S, and it is preferentially entailed by K since K is admissible. It is therefore in R𝑅Ritalic_R. We conclude that S𝑆Sitalic_S and R𝑅Ritalic_R must differ for some assertion that has rank. Let τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ be the smallest rank at which S𝑆Sitalic_S and R𝑅Ritalic_R differ, i.e., the smallest rank of an α𝛼\alphaitalic_α such that there is a β𝛽\betaitalic_β such that α⁢ ∼β∈(S−R)∪(R−S)similar-to𝛼 𝛽𝑆𝑅𝑅𝑆\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\beta\in(S-R)\cup(R-S)italic_α ∼ italic_β ∈ ( italic_S - italic_R ) ∪ ( italic_R - italic_S ). We have two cases to consider, either there is a formula α𝛼\alphaitalic_α of rank greater or equal to τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ such that, for all formulas β𝛽\betaitalic_β of rank greater or equal to τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ, α≤β𝛼𝛽\alpha\leq\betaitalic_α ≤ italic_β in R𝑅Ritalic_R, or there is no such formula.

Suppose there is such an α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. Our first claim is that, for any β𝛽\betaitalic_β of rank greater than τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ, the assertion α<β𝛼𝛽\alpha<\betaitalic_α < italic_β is in R𝑅Ritalic_R. Consider indeed a ranked model W𝑊Witalic_W that defines R𝑅Ritalic_R. Let W′′superscript𝑊′′W^{\prime\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the supermodel obtained from W𝑊Witalic_W by adding to W𝑊Witalic_W, at each level l𝑙litalic_l a state labeled with world w𝑤witalic_w for all worlds w𝑤witalic_w that label a state of rank less than l𝑙litalic_l in W𝑊Witalic_W. It is clear that W′′superscript𝑊′′W^{\prime\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is ranked and defines the same relation as W𝑊Witalic_W, and, in W′′superscript𝑊′′W^{\prime\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, every label that appears at some level l𝑙litalic_l also appears at all greater levels. Let W′superscript𝑊′W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the submodel of W′′superscript𝑊′′W^{\prime\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that contains all those states of level (rank in W′′superscript𝑊′′W^{\prime\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) greater or equal to the minimal level l𝑙litalic_l at which some state satisfies α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. It clearly satisfies the smoothness property (for this we needed to go through the construction of W′′superscript𝑊′′W^{\prime\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT). Since a formula is satisfied in W′′superscript𝑊′′W^{\prime\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT at some level less than l𝑙litalic_l iff it is of rank less than τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ, no antecedent of an assertion of Cτsubscript𝐶𝜏C_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is satisfied at any level less than l𝑙litalic_l. But W′′superscript𝑊′′W^{\prime\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a model of K and therefore W′superscript𝑊′W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a model of Cτsubscript𝐶𝜏C_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. But Cτsubscript𝐶𝜏C_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT preferentially entails true  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢β𝛽\neg\beta¬ italic_β. The model W′superscript𝑊′W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT therefore satisfies true  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢β𝛽\neg\beta¬ italic_β but not true  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢α𝛼\neg\alpha¬ italic_α. It therefore also satisfies α<β𝛼𝛽\alpha<\betaitalic_α < italic_β. But the antecedent of this last assertion has rank greater or equal to τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ, and therefore no state of W′′superscript𝑊′′W^{\prime\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that is not in W′superscript𝑊′W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfies it. Therefore α<β𝛼𝛽\alpha<\betaitalic_α < italic_β is satisfied by W′′superscript𝑊′′W^{\prime\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and is an element of R𝑅Ritalic_R. satisfies Our second claim is that there is an assertion γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ in R−S𝑅𝑆R-Sitalic_R - italic_S, such that γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ is of rank τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ and γ≤α𝛾𝛼\gamma\leq\alphaitalic_γ ≤ italic_α in R𝑅Ritalic_R. We consider two cases.

  1. 1.

    There is an assertion ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ η𝜂\etaitalic_η in S−R𝑆𝑅S-Ritalic_S - italic_R with ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ of rank τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ. Then ξ∧¬⁢η𝜉𝜂\xi\wedge\neg\etaitalic_ξ ∧ ¬ italic_η has rank greater than τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ, and by our first claim, α<ξ∧¬⁢η𝛼𝜉𝜂\alpha<\xi\wedge\neg\etaitalic_α < italic_ξ ∧ ¬ italic_η is in R𝑅Ritalic_R. But ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ η𝜂\etaitalic_η is not in R𝑅Ritalic_R, and therefore we must have α<ξ𝛼𝜉\alpha<\xiitalic_α < italic_ξ for R𝑅Ritalic_R. This last assertion is not in S𝑆Sitalic_S since both α𝛼\alphaitalic_α and ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ have rank τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ. The assertion α<ξ𝛼𝜉\alpha<\xiitalic_α < italic_ξ is a suitable γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ.

  2. 2.

    There is an assertion ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ η𝜂\etaitalic_η in R−S𝑅𝑆R-Sitalic_R - italic_S with ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ of rank τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ. If ξ≤α𝜉𝛼\xi\leq\alphaitalic_ξ ≤ italic_α in R𝑅Ritalic_R, then ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ η𝜂\etaitalic_η is a suitable γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ. Suppose, then, that α<ξ𝛼𝜉\alpha<\xiitalic_α < italic_ξ in R𝑅Ritalic_R. Since ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ has the same rank as α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, α<ξ𝛼𝜉\alpha<\xiitalic_α < italic_ξ is in R−S𝑅𝑆R-Sitalic_R - italic_S and a suitable γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ.

We may now conclude that S≺Rprecedes𝑆𝑅S\prec Ritalic_S ≺ italic_R. The assertion γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ fulfills the requirements of Condition 1 of Definition 20, since γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ has rank τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ. For Condition 2, suppose ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ η𝜂\etaitalic_η is in S−R𝑆𝑅S-Ritalic_S - italic_R, then ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ must be of rank greater or equal to τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ and ξ∧¬⁢η𝜉𝜂\xi\wedge\neg\etaitalic_ξ ∧ ¬ italic_η is of rank greater than τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ. By our first remark we conclude that α<ξ∧¬⁢η𝛼𝜉𝜂\alpha<\xi\wedge\neg\etaitalic_α < italic_ξ ∧ ¬ italic_η for R𝑅Ritalic_R. It is a matter of elementary properties of rational relations to check that if α<ξ∧¬⁢η𝛼𝜉𝜂\alpha<\xi\wedge\neg\etaitalic_α < italic_ξ ∧ ¬ italic_η is in R𝑅Ritalic_R, but ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ η𝜂\etaitalic_η is not, then α<ξ𝛼𝜉\alpha<\xiitalic_α < italic_ξ for R𝑅Ritalic_R. Since γ≤α𝛾𝛼\gamma\leq\alphaitalic_γ ≤ italic_α in R𝑅Ritalic_R, we conclude that γ<ξ𝛾𝜉\gamma<\xiitalic_γ < italic_ξ for R𝑅Ritalic_R.

Suppose now that there is no such α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. Take any formula γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ of rank τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ. There is a formula δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ of rank greater or equal to τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ such that δ<γ𝛿𝛾\delta<\gammaitalic_δ < italic_γ for R𝑅Ritalic_R. But this assertion is then in R−S𝑅𝑆R-Sitalic_R - italic_S. It satisfies Condition 1 of Definition 20, since its antecedent has rank τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ. Suppose now φ𝜑\varphiitalic_φ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ θ𝜃\thetaitalic_θ is in S−R𝑆𝑅S-Ritalic_S - italic_R. Then φ𝜑\varphiitalic_φ is of rank at least τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ. If it is of rank τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ, there is a formula π𝜋\piitalic_π of rank at least τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ such that π<φ𝜋𝜑\pi<\varphiitalic_π < italic_φ is in R𝑅Ritalic_R, but not in S𝑆Sitalic_S and this provides the witness requested by Condition 2. If it is of rank greater than τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ, then the assertion δ<γ𝛿𝛾\delta<\gammaitalic_δ < italic_γ defined just above will do.     

5.7 A model-theoretic description of rational closure

We shall describe here a model-theoretic construction that transforms a preferential model W𝑊Witalic_W into a ranked model W′superscript𝑊′W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by letting all states of W𝑊Witalic_W sink as low as they can respecting the order of W𝑊Witalic_W, i.e., ranks the states of W𝑊Witalic_W by their height in W𝑊Witalic_W. We shall show that, under certain conditions, the model W′superscript𝑊′W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT defines the rational closure of the relation defined by W𝑊Witalic_W. This construction is clearly interesting only when the model W𝑊Witalic_W is well-founded. We know that, in this case, the relation defined by W𝑊Witalic_W indeed possesses a rational closure (Theorem 7 and Lemma 7). It would have been pleasant to be able to prove the validity of such a construction on an arbitrary well-founded preferential model. Unfortunately we are not able to show this in general, but need to suppose, in addition, that the preferential relation defined by W𝑊Witalic_W is well-founded (see Definition 8). This is quite a severe restriction, since we have seen at the end of Section 2.3 that finitely-generated relations on arbitrary languages ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L are not always well-founded. When the language ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L is logically finite, we know all preferential relations are well-founded. Given a well-founded preferential relation, the construction may be applied to any of its well-founded models.

Let P𝑃Pitalic_P be a well-founded preferential relation and W=⟨S,l,≺⟩𝑊𝑆𝑙precedesW=\langle S,l,\prec\rangleitalic_W = ⟨ italic_S , italic_l , ≺ ⟩ any well-founded preferential model that defines P𝑃Pitalic_P. We shall define, for any ordinal τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ, two sets of states: Uτsubscript𝑈𝜏U_{\tau}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Vτsubscript𝑉𝜏V_{\tau}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Those sets satisfy, for any τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ, Uτ⊆Vτ⊆Uτ+1subscript𝑈𝜏subscript𝑉𝜏subscript𝑈𝜏1U_{\tau}\subseteq V_{\tau}\subseteq U_{\tau+1}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊆ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊆ italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The set Uτsubscript𝑈𝜏U_{\tau}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains, in addition to the elements of previous V𝑉Vitalic_V’s, the states that are minimal among those states not previously added. The set Vτsubscript𝑉𝜏V_{\tau}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains, in addition to the states of Uτsubscript𝑈𝜏U_{\tau}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, all states that satisfy only formulas already satisfied by states previously considered.

Uτ=def⋃ρ<τVρsuperscriptdefsubscript𝑈𝜏subscript𝜌𝜏subscript𝑉𝜌U_{\tau}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}\bigcup_{\rho<\tau}{V_{\rho}}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ < italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
∪{s∈S∣∀t∈S⁢such⁢that⁢t≺s,there⁢is⁢a⁢ρ<τ⁢such⁢that⁢t∈Vρ}conditional-set𝑠𝑆formulae-sequencefor-all𝑡𝑆suchthat𝑡precedes𝑠thereisa𝜌𝜏suchthat𝑡subscript𝑉𝜌\cup\{s\in S\mid\forall t\in S{\rm\ such\ that\ }t\prec s,{\rm there\ is\ a\ }\rho<\tau{\rm\ such\ that\ }t\in V_{\rho}\}∪ { italic_s ∈ italic_S ∣ ∀ italic_t ∈ italic_S roman_such roman_that italic_t ≺ italic_s , roman_there roman_is roman_a italic_ρ < italic_τ roman_such roman_that italic_t ∈ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } (19)
Vτ=def{s∈S∣∀α∈ℒ⁢such⁢that⁢s⁢ ≡α,∃t∈Uτ⁢such⁢that⁢t⁢ ≡α}superscriptdefsubscript𝑉𝜏conditional-set𝑠𝑆formulae-sequencefor-all𝛼ℒsuchthat𝑠 𝛼𝑡subscript𝑈𝜏suchthat𝑡 𝛼V_{\tau}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}\{s\in S\mid\forall\alpha\in{\cal L}{\rm\ such\ that\ }s\hskip 2.27621pt\rule[-2.84526pt]{0.28453pt}{11.38109pt}\equiv\alpha,\exists t\in U_{\tau}{\rm\ such\ that\ }t\hskip 2.27621pt\rule[-2.84526pt]{0.28453pt}{11.38109pt}\equiv\alpha\}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP { italic_s ∈ italic_S ∣ ∀ italic_α ∈ caligraphic_L roman_such roman_that italic_s ≡ italic_α , ∃ italic_t ∈ italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_such roman_that italic_t ≡ italic_α } (20)

Since the model W𝑊Witalic_W is well-founded, every state s∈S𝑠𝑆s\in Sitalic_s ∈ italic_S is in some Vτsubscript𝑉𝜏V_{\tau}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let the height of a state s∈S𝑠𝑆s\in Sitalic_s ∈ italic_S (in W𝑊Witalic_W) be the least ordinal τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ for which s∈Vτ𝑠subscript𝑉𝜏s\in V_{\tau}italic_s ∈ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We shall now show that there is a close relationship between the rank of a formula α𝛼\alphaitalic_α in P𝑃Pitalic_P (see definition following Definition 10) and the height in W𝑊Witalic_W of the states that satisfy α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. For any ordinal τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ, we shall denote by Wτsubscript𝑊𝜏W_{\tau}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the substructure of W𝑊Witalic_W consisting of all states of height larger or equal to τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ. Notice that, since W𝑊Witalic_W is well-founded, Wτsubscript𝑊𝜏W_{\tau}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a preferential model. Notice also that all elements of Uτ−⋃ρ<τVρsubscript𝑈𝜏subscript𝜌𝜏subscript𝑉𝜌U_{\tau}-\bigcup_{\rho<\tau}{V_{\rho}}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ < italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are minimal elements of Wτsubscript𝑊𝜏W_{\tau}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Lemma 31

Let τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ be an ordinal. Let α𝛼\alphaitalic_α be a formula of rank at least τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ and β𝛽\betaitalic_β be any formula.

  1. 1.

    No state of height less than τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ satisfies α𝛼\alphaitalic_α.

  2. 2.

    The model Wτsubscript𝑊𝜏W_{\tau}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β iff α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β is preferentially entailed by Cτsubscript𝐶𝜏C_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

In particular, if α𝛼\alphaitalic_α has no rank, no state in S𝑆Sitalic_S satisfies α𝛼\alphaitalic_α.

Proof: It proceeds by simultaneous ordinal induction on τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ. Suppose both claims have been proved for all ordinals ρ<τ𝜌𝜏\rho<\tauitalic_ρ < italic_τ. Let us prove our first claim. Since α𝛼\alphaitalic_α has rank at least τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ, for any ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ, ρ<τ𝜌𝜏\rho<\tauitalic_ρ < italic_τ, Cρsubscript𝐶𝜌C_{\rho}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT preferentially entails true  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢α𝛼\neg\alpha¬ italic_α. By the induction hypothesis (item 2), Wρsubscript𝑊𝜌W_{\rho}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies true  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢α𝛼\neg\alpha¬ italic_α. Therefore no state of Uρ−⋃σ<ρVσsubscript𝑈𝜌subscript𝜎𝜌subscript𝑉𝜎U_{\rho}-\bigcup_{\sigma<\rho}{V_{\sigma}}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ < italic_ρ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. If there were a state s𝑠sitalic_s of height ρ<τ𝜌𝜏\rho<\tauitalic_ρ < italic_τ satisfying α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, there would be a state t𝑡titalic_t of Uρ−⋃σ<ρVσsubscript𝑈𝜌subscript𝜎𝜌subscript𝑉𝜎U_{\rho}-\bigcup_{\sigma<\rho}{V_{\sigma}}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ < italic_ρ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfying α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. We conclude that no state of height less than τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ satisfies α𝛼\alphaitalic_α.

For the second claim, by Lemma 5, α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β is preferentially entailed by C0subscript𝐶0C_{0}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (i.e., in P𝑃Pitalic_P, i.e., satisfied by W𝑊Witalic_W) iff it is preferentially entailed by Cτsubscript𝐶𝜏C_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. By the first claim, α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β is satisfied by W𝑊Witalic_W iff it is satisfied by Wτsubscript𝑊𝜏W_{\tau}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.     

Lemma 32

A formula α𝛼\alphaitalic_α has rank τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ in P𝑃Pitalic_P iff there is a state s∈S𝑠𝑆s\in Sitalic_s ∈ italic_S of height τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ that satisfies α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  and there is no such state of height less than τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ.

Proof: We shall prove the only if part. The if part is then obvious. First, remark that if  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ is a preferential relation that contains the assertion α𝛼\alphaitalic_α∨\vee∨β𝛽\betaitalic_β ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬\neg¬α𝛼\alphaitalic_α , then it contains the assertion true  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬\neg¬α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. This is easily shown by preferential reasoning. Suppose now that α𝛼\alphaitalic_α has rank τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ. Lemma 31 shows that no state of height less than τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ satisfies α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. We must show that there is a state of height τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ satisfying α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. Let β𝛽\betaitalic_β be any formula of rank larger or equal to τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ that is minimal with respect to <<< among those formulas. There is such a formula since the set is not empty (α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is there) and <<< is well-founded. Since α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is not exceptional for Cτsubscript𝐶𝜏C_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the assertion true  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬\neg¬α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is not preferentially entailed by Cτsubscript𝐶𝜏C_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and therefore the assertion α𝛼\alphaitalic_α∨\vee∨β𝛽\betaitalic_β ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬\neg¬α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is not preferentially entailed by Cτsubscript𝐶𝜏C_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. But α𝛼\alphaitalic_α∨\vee∨β𝛽\betaitalic_β has rank τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ and, by Lemma 31, Wτsubscript𝑊𝜏W_{\tau}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT does not satisfy α𝛼\alphaitalic_α∨\vee∨β𝛽\betaitalic_β ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬\neg¬α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. There is, therefore, in Wτsubscript𝑊𝜏W_{\tau}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT a state s𝑠sitalic_s satisfying α𝛼\alphaitalic_α such that no state t𝑡titalic_t in Wτsubscript𝑊𝜏W_{\tau}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, t≺sprecedes𝑡𝑠t\prec sitalic_t ≺ italic_s, satisfies β𝛽\betaitalic_β. We shall show that s𝑠sitalic_s is minimal in Wτsubscript𝑊𝜏W_{\tau}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and has therefore height τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ. Suppose s𝑠sitalic_s is not minimal in Wτsubscript𝑊𝜏W_{\tau}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. There would be a state t𝑡titalic_t minimal in Wτsubscript𝑊𝜏W_{\tau}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that t≺sprecedes𝑡𝑠t\prec sitalic_t ≺ italic_s. This state t𝑡titalic_t has height τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ and, by construction, it satisfies some formula β′superscript𝛽′\beta^{\prime}italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that is not satisfied at any smaller height. By Lemma 31, β′superscript𝛽′\beta^{\prime}italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has rank larger or equal to τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ, and the formula β∨β′𝛽superscript𝛽′\beta\vee\beta^{\prime}italic_β ∨ italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has rank larger or equal to τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ. Since β∨β′≤β𝛽superscript𝛽′𝛽\beta\vee\beta^{\prime}\leq\betaitalic_β ∨ italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ italic_β, the minimality of β𝛽\betaitalic_β implies that β≤β∨β′𝛽𝛽superscript𝛽′\beta\leq\beta\vee\beta^{\prime}italic_β ≤ italic_β ∨ italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In other terms, β∨β′⁢ ∼ ⁢β𝛽superscript𝛽′ ∼ 𝛽\beta\vee\beta^{\prime}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\betaitalic_β ∨ italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ italic_β. But the state t𝑡titalic_t, in W𝑊Witalic_W, satisfies β′superscript𝛽′\beta^{\prime}italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and is minimal among states satisfying β∨β′𝛽superscript𝛽′\beta\vee\beta^{\prime}italic_β ∨ italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore t𝑡titalic_t satisfies β𝛽\betaitalic_β. A contradiction.     

Lemma 32 shows that, given a well-founded preferential relation (resp. a finite knowledge base), and a well-founded preferential model W𝑊Witalic_W for it (resp. for its preferential closure), one may build a ranked model for its rational closure by ranking the states of W𝑊Witalic_W by their depth.

5.8 Computing rational closure

We shall now provide an algorithm for deciding whether an assertion is in the rational closure of a finite knowledge base. The notation E⁢(C)𝐸𝐶E(C)italic_E ( italic_C ) has been defined following Definition 10. Lemma 7 and Theorem 7 show that, given a finite knowledge base K and an assertion α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β  the following algorithm is adequate.

C=𝐊𝐶𝐊C={\bf K}italic_C = bold_K;
while α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is exceptional for C𝐶Citalic_C and E⁢(C)≠C𝐸𝐶𝐶E(C)\neq Citalic_E ( italic_C ) ≠ italic_C, C:=E⁢(C)assign𝐶𝐸𝐶C:=E(C)italic_C := italic_E ( italic_C );
if α∧¬⁢β𝛼𝛽\alpha\wedge\neg\betaitalic_α ∧ ¬ italic_β is exceptional for C𝐶Citalic_C then answer yes else answer no.

The only thing left for us to implement is checking whether a formula is exceptional for a given finite knowledge base. The next lemma shows this is easily done.

Definition 23

Let 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A be the conditional assertion α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β. The material counterpart of 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A, denoted by 𝒜~normal-~𝒜\tilde{\cal A}over~ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG, is the formula α→βnormal-→𝛼𝛽\alpha\rightarrow\betaitalic_α → italic_β, where →normal-→\rightarrow→, as usual, denotes material implication. If K is a set of assertions, its material counterpart 𝐊~normal-~𝐊\tilde{\bf K}over~ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG is the set of material counterparts of K.

Lemma 33

Let K be a conditional knowledge base and α𝛼\alphaitalic_α a formula. Then 𝐊~⊧αmodelsnormal-~𝐊𝛼\tilde{\bf K}\models\alphaover~ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG ⊧ italic_α iff K preferentially entails true  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ α𝛼\alphaitalic_α.

Proof: The if part follows from the fact that any world satisfying 𝐊~~𝐊\tilde{\bf K}over~ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG and not α𝛼\alphaitalic_α provides a one state preferential model satisfying K and not satisfying true  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. For the only if part suppose 𝐊~⊧αmodels~𝐊𝛼\tilde{\bf K}\models\alphaover~ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG ⊧ italic_α. By compactness, there is a finite subset of 𝐊~~𝐊\tilde{\bf K}over~ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG that entails α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. By rules S, And and Right Weakening we conclude that K preferentially entails true  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ α𝛼\alphaitalic_α.     

Corollary 6

Let K be a conditional knowledge base and α𝛼\alphaitalic_α a formula. The formula α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is exceptional for K iff 𝐊~⊧¬⁢αmodelsnormal-~𝐊𝛼\tilde{\bf K}\models\neg\alphaover~ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG ⊧ ¬ italic_α.

We see that, if K contains n𝑛nitalic_n assertions, in the previous algorithm, we may go over the while loop at most O⁢(n)𝑂𝑛O(n)italic_O ( italic_n ) times. Each time we shall have to consider at most n+1𝑛1n+1italic_n + 1 formulas and decide whether they are exceptional or not. The whole algorithm needs at most O⁢(n2)𝑂superscript𝑛2O(n^{2})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) such decisions. In the most general case all such decisions are instances of the satisfiability problem for propositional calculus, therefore solvable in non-deterministic polynomial time (in the size of the knowledge base K times the size of the formulas involved). Therefore, even in the most general case, the problem is not much more complex than the satisfiability problem for propositional calculus. These results may be improved if we restrict ourselves to assertions of a restricted type. For example, if the assertions of K are of the Horn type (we mean their material counterpart is a Horn formula), and the assertion α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β is of the same type, then, since each decision may be taken in polynomial deterministic time, the whole algorithm runs in deterministic polynomial time. The complexity discussion above is mainly of theoretical interest. The important practical question is: given a fixed large knowledge base, what information, of reasonable size, should be precomputed to allow efficient answers to queries of the type: is an 𝒜𝒜{\cal A}caligraphic_A in the rational closure? The pre-computation of the different Cnsubscript𝐶𝑛C_{n}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT sub-bases would already reduce the exponent of n𝑛nitalic_n in the complexity of the algorithm by one.

J. Dix noticed that the algorithm just presented for computing the rational closure of a finite knowledge base may be used to compute the preferential closure of such a knowledge base, since, by Corollary 3 and Lemmas 7 and 30, the assertion α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β is in 𝐊psuperscript𝐊𝑝{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT iff the assertion α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ false is in the rational closure of the knowledge base K ∪{α⁢ ∼¬⁢β}similar-to𝛼 𝛽\cup\,\{\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\beta\}∪ { italic_α ∼ ¬ italic_β }.

5.9 A discussion of rational closure

We have so far shown that rational closure provides a mathematically elegant and effective answer to the question of the title that satisfies Thesis 1. It is now time to evaluate whether it provides an answer that matches our intuitions. We shall first present two now classical knowledge bases, describe their rational closure and examine whether they fit our intuitions. Then, we shall discuss the way rational closure treats inheritance of generic properties to abnormal individuals. Finally, we shall try to address the question of whether our formalism is suitable to describe domain knowledge.

Example 2 (Nixon diamond)

Let our knowledge base consist of the following two assertions.

  1. 1.

    republican  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬\neg¬pacifist

  2. 2.

    quaker  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ pacifist

It is easy to see that none of the assertions of the base is exceptional, but that the formula republican∧\wedge∧quaker is exceptional. From this we deduce that neither the assertion republican∧\wedge∧quaker  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ pacifist nor the assertion republican∧\wedge∧quaker  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬\neg¬pacifist is in the rational closure. This seems the intuitively correct decision in the presence of contradictory information. In fact, if we know somebody to be both a Quaker and a Republican, we (i.e., rational closure) shall draw about him only conclusions that are logically implied by our information. Rational closure endorses worker ∧\wedge∧ republican  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬\neg¬pacifist, meaning that, since we have no information on the pacifism of workers, we shall assume that Republican workers behave as Republicans in this respect. We (i.e., rational closure) also endorse pacifist  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬\neg¬republican, meaning we are ready to use contraposition in many circumstances. We do not have ¬\neg¬pacifist  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ republican, though, and quite rightly, since Republicans may well be a small minority among non-pacifists. We have true  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬\neg¬ (republican ∧\wedge∧ quaker), meaning we think being both a Republican and a Quaker is exceptional. We endorse republican  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬\neg¬quaker and quaker  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬\neg¬republican, that are also intuitively correct conclusions. If we add to our knowledge base the fact that rich people are typically Republicans, we shall deduce that rich people are typically not pacifists, meaning we endorse a restricted form of transitivity. We shall also deduce that Quakers are typically not rich, which is perhaps more debatable. We shall not conclude anything about the pacifism of rich Quakers though, since rich Quakers are exceptional. We shall not conclude anything either concerning rich Quakers that are not Republicans, which is more debatable. If we want to conclude that rich non-Republican Quakers are pacifists, we should add this assertion explicitly to the knowledge base. The addition will not interfere with previously discussed assertions.

Example 3 (Penguin triangle)

Let our knowledge base consist of the following three assertions.

  1. 1.

    penguin  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ bird

  2. 2.

    penguin  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬\neg¬fly

  3. 3.

    bird  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ fly

The first two assertions are exceptional, the last one is not. It follows that we (i.e., rational closure) endorse the following assertions: fly  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬\neg¬penguin (a case of contraposition), ¬\neg¬fly  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬\neg¬bird (another case of contraposition), ¬\neg¬fly  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬\neg¬penguin (penguins are exceptional, even among non-flying objects), bird  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬\neg¬penguin (penguins are exceptional birds), ¬\neg¬bird  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬\neg¬penguin (penguins are exceptional also among non-birds), bird∧\wedge∧penguin  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬\neg¬fly (this is an intuitively correct preemption: we prefer specific information to non-specific information), penguin∧\wedge∧black  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬\neg¬fly (black penguins don’t fly either, since they are normal penguins), bird∧\wedge∧green  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ fly (green birds are normal birds).

The following assertions are not endorsed: b⁢i⁢r⁢d∧¬⁢f⁢l⁢ynormal-bnormal-inormal-rnormal-dnormal-fnormal-lnormal-y{\em bird}\wedge\neg{\em fly}normal_b normal_i normal_r normal_d ∧ ¬ normal_f normal_l normal_y  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ penguin (there could be non-flying birds other than penguins), b⁢i⁢r⁢d∧¬⁢f⁢l⁢ynormal-bnormal-inormal-rnormal-dnormal-fnormal-lnormal-y{\em bird}\wedge\neg{\em fly}normal_b normal_i normal_r normal_d ∧ ¬ normal_f normal_l normal_y  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬\neg¬penguin (seems intuitively clear), penguin  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ fly (obviously).

A more general reflexion suggests the following. Theorem 7 shows that, in the rational closure, no information about normal cases may be relevant to abnormal cases. It is a very intriguing question whether human beings obey this rule of reasoning or not. A specific example has been discussed by J. Pearl in a personal communication. It probably goes back to A. Baker. Suppose we know that most Swedes are blond and tall. If we are going to meet Jon, whom we know to be short and to come from Sweden, should we necessarily expect him to be fair? The answer endorsed by rational closure is not necessarily, since short Swedes are exceptional and we have no specific information about such cases. We do not know how people generally handle this and, even if we knew, it is not clear that AI systems should react in exactly the same way: people are, after all, notoriously bad with statistical information. The answer to the question how should people behave in this case, if they were smart and had all the relevant information, depends on the sociobiology of the Swedish population and is not relevant either. There is very solid ground, though, to claim that, in the framework described here, in which a knowledge base contains only positive conditional assertions, the only sensible way to handle this problem is not to expect anything about the color of Jon’s hair. The reason is that, if we ever find out that most short Swedes are blond (or dark, for that matter) it will be easy enough to add this information to our knowledge base. On the contrary, had we chosen to infer that Jon is expected to be blond, and had we found out that half of the short Swedes only are fair, we would not have been able to correct our knowledge base to remove the unwanted inference: adding the fact that most short Swedes are not blond being obviously incorrect.

Since, by looking at a number of examples, we have gathered some experience on the behavior of rational closure, we would like to propose the following strengthening of Thesis 1.

Thesis 2

The set of assertions entailed by any set of assertions K is a rational superset of  𝐊¯normal-¯𝐊\overline{\bf K}over¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG.

Thesis 2 means that a reasonable system should endorse any assertion contained in the rational closure, but it may also endorse some additional assertions, as long as it defines a rational relation. The search for natural constructions satisfying Thesis 2, but providing more inheritance than rational closure is open.

The main question that has not been addressed yet is whether conditional knowledge bases are suitable to describe domain knowledge. Undoubtedly much work still has to be done before we may answer this question satisfactorily. We shall only try to express here why we think the answer may well be positive. Representing common sense knowledge is far from trivial in any one of the existing formalisms, such as Circumscription or Default Logic. Indeed to represent any substantive piece of common sense knowledge in one of those formalisms, one needs to be an expert at the mechanics of the formalism used, and they differ greatly from one formalism to the next. Deciding on the different abnormality predicates in Circumscription and the relations between them, or working out the default rules in Default Logic so as to ensure the correct precedence of defaults needs the hand of an expert. In the formalism proposed here, conditional knowledge bases, the treatment is much simpler since abnormality predicates do not appear explicitely and the default information is described in a much poorer language than Default Logic. We rely on the general algorithm for computing rational closure (or some other algorithm that will be found suitable) to deal in a mechanical, uniform and tractable manner with the interactions between different pieces of default information. The fact that our language of assertions is much poorer than other formalisms seems to us to be a great asset.

Nevertheless, it is probable that the size of useful conditional knowledge bases will be very large. Indeed, in our approach, adding new assertions to the knowledge base may solve almost any problem. Two main topics for further research may then be delineated. The first one is to find practical ways to avoid having to look at the whole knowledge base before answering any query. The set of assertions constituting a knowledge base will have to be structured (off-line, once and for all) in such a way that irrelevant assertions do not have to be looked at. The second one is to find lucid and compact descriptions of large conditional knowledge bases. This will involve looking seriously into the question: where does the conditional knowledge come from? Different answers may be appropriate in different domains: it may well be that conditional knowledge is derived from causal knowledge in ways that are different from those in which it is derived from conventions of speech or statistical information.

6 Conclusion

We have presented a mathematically tractable framework for nonmonotonic reasoning that can be proved to possess many pragmatically attractive features. Its computational complexity compares favorably with that of most well-established systems. In many cases the intuitively correct answer is obtained. In others, the answer given and the way it was obtained provide an interesting point of view on the knowledge base. Much more practical experience is needed before one may assess the pragmatic value of the approach. The task of extending the results presented here to first-order languages is not an easy one. First steps towards this goal are described in [20].

7 Acknowledgements

David Makinson suggested importing the thesis CV of conditional logic into the study of nonmonotonic consequence relations, i.e., suggested to consider what is called here rational relations. He conjectured that the corresponding family of models was that of ranked models. He was also instrumental in stressing the importance of studying global properties of nonmonotonic inference operations. Discussions with the following people helped us to disprove hasty conjectures, putting this work in perspective, and improve the presentation of this paper: Johan van Benthem, Michael Freund, Haim Gaifman, Hector Geffner, Matthew Ginsberg, David Israel, Sarit Kraus, John McCarthy and Judea Pearl. Karl Schlechta’s suggestions and Jürgen Dix’s remarks on a previous draft have been very useful. Finally, this paper has been fortunate to receive attention and care of a rare quality from two anonymous referees. We want to thank them.

Appendix A Lemmas needed to prove Theorem 5

Let us suppose that some rational consequence relation  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ is given. The notion of a consistent formula has been presented in Definition 9. Let S𝑆Sitalic_S denote the set of all consistent formulas. Let us now recall Definition 10 of [17].

Definition 24

The world m∈𝒰𝑚𝒰m\in{\cal U}italic_m ∈ caligraphic_U is a normal world for α𝛼\alphaitalic_α iff ∀β∈Lfor-all𝛽𝐿\forall\beta\in L∀ italic_β ∈ italic_L such that α⁢ ∼ ⁢β𝛼 ∼ 𝛽\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\betaitalic_α ∼ italic_β, m⊧βmodels𝑚𝛽m\models\betaitalic_m ⊧ italic_β.

The following is an easy corollary of Lemma 8 of [17].

Lemma 34

A formula is consistent iff there is a normal world for it.

We shall now define a pre-order relation on the set S𝑆Sitalic_S.

Definition 25

Where α,β∈S𝛼𝛽𝑆\alpha,\beta\in Sitalic_α , italic_β ∈ italic_S, we shall say that α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is not more exceptional than β𝛽\betaitalic_β and write α⁢ℛ⁢β𝛼ℛ𝛽\alpha\cal R\betaitalic_α caligraphic_R italic_β iff α∨β𝛼𝛽\alpha\vee\betaitalic_α ∨ italic_β  ≁not-similar-to absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim≁ ¬⁢α𝛼\neg\alpha¬ italic_α.

Lemma 35

The relation ℛℛ\cal Rcaligraphic_R is transitive.

Proof: Straightforward from Lemma 17. The fact that the relation ℛℛ\cal Rcaligraphic_R was restricted to the set S𝑆Sitalic_S is not used here and ℛℛ\cal Rcaligraphic_R would have been transitive also on the whole language ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L.     

Lemma 36

Let α,β∈S𝛼𝛽𝑆\alpha,\beta\in Sitalic_α , italic_β ∈ italic_S. Either α⁢ℛ⁢β𝛼ℛ𝛽\alpha\cal R\betaitalic_α caligraphic_R italic_β or β⁢ℛ⁢α𝛽ℛ𝛼\beta\cal R\alphaitalic_β caligraphic_R italic_α (or both). In particular ℛℛ\cal Rcaligraphic_R is reflexive.

Proof: The proof proceeds by contradiction. Suppose we have α⁢R̸⁢β𝛼script-R̸𝛽\alpha\not{{\cal R}}\betaitalic_α caligraphic_R̸ italic_β and β⁢R̸⁢α𝛽script-R̸𝛼\beta\not{{\cal R}}\alphaitalic_β caligraphic_R̸ italic_α. Then we have α∨β𝛼𝛽\alpha\vee\betaitalic_α ∨ italic_β  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢α𝛼\neg\alpha¬ italic_α and α∨β𝛼𝛽\alpha\vee\betaitalic_α ∨ italic_β  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢β𝛽\neg\beta¬ italic_β. By And and Reflexivity we have α∨β𝛼𝛽\alpha\vee\betaitalic_α ∨ italic_β  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢α∧¬⁢β∧(α∨β)𝛼𝛽𝛼𝛽\neg\alpha\wedge\neg\beta\wedge(\alpha\vee\beta)¬ italic_α ∧ ¬ italic_β ∧ ( italic_α ∨ italic_β ), and therefore α∨β𝛼𝛽\alpha\vee\betaitalic_α ∨ italic_β  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ false and, by Rule 14, (α∨β)∧β𝛼𝛽𝛽(\alpha\vee\beta)\wedge\beta( italic_α ∨ italic_β ) ∧ italic_β  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ false. Therefore β𝛽\betaitalic_β  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ false, contradicting β∈S𝛽𝑆\beta\in Sitalic_β ∈ italic_S. The fact that ℛℛ\cal Rcaligraphic_R was restricted to S𝑆Sitalic_S is crucial here.     

The following will be useful in the sequel.

Lemma 37

If α⁢ℛ⁢β𝛼ℛ𝛽\alpha\cal R\betaitalic_α caligraphic_R italic_β, any normal world for α𝛼\alphaitalic_α that satisfies β𝛽\betaitalic_β is normal for β𝛽\betaitalic_β.

Proof: Suppose α⁢ℛ⁢β𝛼ℛ𝛽\alpha\cal R\betaitalic_α caligraphic_R italic_β, m𝑚mitalic_m is normal for α𝛼\alphaitalic_α and satisfies β𝛽\betaitalic_β. Let γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ be such that β𝛽\betaitalic_β  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ. We must show that m⊧γmodels𝑚𝛾m\models\gammaitalic_m ⊧ italic_γ. Since m𝑚mitalic_m is normal for α𝛼\alphaitalic_α and satisfies β𝛽\betaitalic_β, it is enough to show that α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β→γ→𝛽𝛾\beta\rightarrow\gammaitalic_β → italic_γ. But, β𝛽\betaitalic_β  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ implies, by Left Logical Equivalence, (α∨β)∧β𝛼𝛽𝛽(\alpha\vee\beta)\wedge\beta( italic_α ∨ italic_β ) ∧ italic_β  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ. By the rule S of [17], one then obtains α∨β𝛼𝛽\alpha\vee\betaitalic_α ∨ italic_β  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β→γ→𝛽𝛾\beta\rightarrow\gammaitalic_β → italic_γ. But, by definition of ℛℛ\cal Rcaligraphic_R, α∨β𝛼𝛽\alpha\vee\betaitalic_α ∨ italic_β  ≁not-similar-to absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim≁ ¬⁢α𝛼\neg\alpha¬ italic_α and, by Rational Monotonicity one deduces (α∨β)∧α𝛼𝛽𝛼(\alpha\vee\beta)\wedge\alpha( italic_α ∨ italic_β ) ∧ italic_α  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β→γ→𝛽𝛾\beta\rightarrow\gammaitalic_β → italic_γ.     

Definition 26

Let α,β∈S𝛼𝛽𝑆\alpha,\beta\in Sitalic_α , italic_β ∈ italic_S. We shall say that α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is as exceptional as β𝛽\betaitalic_β and write α∼βsimilar-to𝛼𝛽\alpha\sim\betaitalic_α ∼ italic_β iff α⁢ℛ⁢β𝛼ℛ𝛽\alpha\cal R\betaitalic_α caligraphic_R italic_β and β⁢ℛ⁢α𝛽ℛ𝛼\beta\cal R\alphaitalic_β caligraphic_R italic_α.

Since ℛℛ\cal Rcaligraphic_R is reflexive and transitive, the relation ∼similar-to\sim∼ is an equivalence relation. The equivalence class of a formula α𝛼\alphaitalic_α will be denoted by α¯¯𝛼\overline{\alpha}over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG and E𝐸Eitalic_E will denote the set of equivalence classes of formulas of S𝑆Sitalic_S under ∼similar-to\sim∼. We shall write α¯≤β¯¯𝛼¯𝛽\overline{\alpha}\leq\overline{\beta}over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG ≤ over¯ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG iff α⁢ℛ⁢β𝛼ℛ𝛽\alpha\cal R\betaitalic_α caligraphic_R italic_β and we shall write α¯<β¯¯𝛼¯𝛽\overline{\alpha}<\overline{\beta}over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG < over¯ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG iff α¯≤β¯¯𝛼¯𝛽\overline{\alpha}\leq\overline{\beta}over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG ≤ over¯ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG and α≁βnot-similar-to𝛼𝛽\alpha\not\sim\betaitalic_α ≁ italic_β. This notation should cause no confusion with a similar notation used with a different meaning, in the context of preferential relations, in [17] and in Section 2.4. By Lemmas 35 and 36, the relation <<< is a strict total order on the set E𝐸Eitalic_E.

Lemma 38

Let α,β𝛼𝛽\alpha,\betaitalic_α , italic_β be consistent formulas. If β¯<α¯normal-¯𝛽normal-¯𝛼\overline{\beta}<\overline{\alpha}over¯ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG < over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG then β𝛽\betaitalic_β  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢α𝛼\neg\alpha¬ italic_α.

Proof: The assumption implies that α⁢R̸⁢β𝛼script-R̸𝛽\alpha\not{{\cal R}}\betaitalic_α caligraphic_R̸ italic_β, i.e., α∨β𝛼𝛽\alpha\vee\betaitalic_α ∨ italic_β  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢α𝛼\neg\alpha¬ italic_α. Rule (15) implies the conclusion.     

Lemma 39

Let α,β𝛼𝛽\alpha,\betaitalic_α , italic_β be consistent formulas. If there is a normal world for α𝛼\alphaitalic_α that satisfies β𝛽\betaitalic_β, then β¯≤α¯normal-¯𝛽normal-¯𝛼\overline{\beta}\leq\overline{\alpha}over¯ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG ≤ over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG.

Proof: If there is a normal world for α𝛼\alphaitalic_α that satisfies β𝛽\betaitalic_β, then we conclude by Lemma 38 that α𝛼\alphaitalic_α  ≁not-similar-to absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim≁ ¬⁢β𝛽\neg\beta¬ italic_β.     

Let W𝑊Witalic_W be the ranked model ⟨V,l,≺⟩𝑉𝑙precedes\langle V,l,\prec\rangle⟨ italic_V , italic_l , ≺ ⟩, where V⊆𝒰×S𝑉𝒰𝑆V\subseteq{\cal U}\times Sitalic_V ⊆ caligraphic_U × italic_S is the set of all pairs <m,α><m,\alpha>< italic_m , italic_α > such that m𝑚mitalic_m is a normal world for α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, l(<m,α>)l(<m,\alpha>)italic_l ( < italic_m , italic_α > ) is defined to be m𝑚mitalic_m and ≺precedes\prec≺ is defined as <m,α>≺<n,β><m,\alpha>\prec<n,\beta>< italic_m , italic_α > ≺ < italic_n , italic_β > iff α¯<β¯¯𝛼¯𝛽\overline{\alpha}<\overline{\beta}over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG < over¯ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG. To show that W𝑊Witalic_W is a ranked model, we must prove that it satisfies the smoothness condition.

Lemma 40

In W𝑊Witalic_W, the state <m,α><m,\alpha>< italic_m , italic_α > is minimal in β^normal-^𝛽\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG iff m⊧βmodels𝑚𝛽m\models\betaitalic_m ⊧ italic_β and β¯=α¯normal-¯𝛽normal-¯𝛼\overline{\beta}=\overline{\alpha}over¯ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG = over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG

Proof: First notice that <m,α>∈β^<m,\alpha>\in\widehat{\beta}< italic_m , italic_α > ∈ over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG iff m⊧βmodels𝑚𝛽m\models\betaitalic_m ⊧ italic_β. For the only if part, suppose that <m,α><m,\alpha>< italic_m , italic_α > is minimal in β^^𝛽\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG. The world m𝑚mitalic_m is normal for α𝛼\alphaitalic_α and satisfies β𝛽\betaitalic_β. By Lemma 39 we conclude that β¯≤α¯¯𝛽¯𝛼\overline{\beta}\leq\overline{\alpha}over¯ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG ≤ over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG. But, since β𝛽\betaitalic_β is consistent, by Lemma 34 there is a normal world n𝑛nitalic_n for β𝛽\betaitalic_β. The pair <n,β><n,\beta>< italic_n , italic_β > is an element of V𝑉Vitalic_V that satisfies β𝛽\betaitalic_β and, by the minimality of <m,α><m,\alpha>< italic_m , italic_α > in β^^𝛽\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG, <n,β>⊀<m,α><n,\beta>\not\prec<m,\alpha>< italic_n , italic_β > ⊀ < italic_m , italic_α >, i.e., β¯≮α¯not-less-than¯𝛽¯𝛼\overline{\beta}\not<\overline{\alpha}over¯ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG ≮ over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG, i.e., α¯≤β¯¯𝛼¯𝛽\overline{\alpha}\leq\overline{\beta}over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG ≤ over¯ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG. We conclude β¯=α¯¯𝛽¯𝛼\overline{\beta}=\overline{\alpha}over¯ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG = over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG. For the if part, suppose that m𝑚mitalic_m is a normal world for α𝛼\alphaitalic_α that satisfies β𝛽\betaitalic_β and that β¯=α¯¯𝛽¯𝛼\overline{\beta}=\overline{\alpha}over¯ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG = over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG. If n𝑛nitalic_n is normal for γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ and <n,γ>≺<m,α><n,\gamma>\prec<m,\alpha>< italic_n , italic_γ > ≺ < italic_m , italic_α > then γ¯<α¯¯𝛾¯𝛼\overline{\gamma}<\overline{\alpha}over¯ start_ARG italic_γ end_ARG < over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG and therefore γ¯<β¯¯𝛾¯𝛽\overline{\gamma}<\overline{\beta}over¯ start_ARG italic_γ end_ARG < over¯ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG. By Lemma 38 γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ ¬⁢β𝛽\neg\beta¬ italic_β and n𝑛nitalic_n, which is normal for γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, cannot satisfy β𝛽\betaitalic_β. The state <m,α><m,\alpha>< italic_m , italic_α > is then minimal in β^^𝛽\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG.     

The following is an immediate corollary of Lemma 40.

Corollary 7

If m𝑚mitalic_m is a normal world for α𝛼\alphaitalic_α the pair <m,α><m,\alpha>< italic_m , italic_α > is a state of V𝑉Vitalic_V and is minimal in α^normal-^𝛼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG.

Proof: Suppose m𝑚mitalic_m is normal for α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. First, since there is a normal world for α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, α∈S𝛼𝑆\alpha\in Sitalic_α ∈ italic_S and the pair <m,α><m,\alpha>< italic_m , italic_α > is in V𝑉Vitalic_V. Since m𝑚mitalic_m is normal for α𝛼\alphaitalic_α it satisfies α𝛼\alphaitalic_α.     

We may now prove that the model W𝑊Witalic_W satisfies the smoothness property and defines the consequence relation  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ .

Lemma 41

Let α𝛼\alphaitalic_α be a consistent formula. The set α^⊆Vnormal-^𝛼𝑉\widehat{\alpha}\subseteq Vover^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG ⊆ italic_V is smooth.

Proof: Suppose <m,β>∈α^<m,\beta>\in\widehat{\alpha}< italic_m , italic_β > ∈ over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG. Then, m𝑚mitalic_m is a normal world for β𝛽\betaitalic_β that satisfies α𝛼\alphaitalic_α and, by Lemma 39, α¯≤β¯¯𝛼¯𝛽\overline{\alpha}\leq\overline{\beta}over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG ≤ over¯ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG. If α¯=β¯¯𝛼¯𝛽\overline{\alpha}=\overline{\beta}over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG = over¯ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG, then, by Lemma 40, <m,β><m,\beta>< italic_m , italic_β > is minimal in α^^𝛼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG. Otherwise, α¯<β¯¯𝛼¯𝛽\overline{\alpha}<\overline{\beta}over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG < over¯ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG. In this case, let n𝑛nitalic_n be any world normal for α𝛼\alphaitalic_α (there is such a world since α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is consistent). The pair <n,α><n,\alpha>< italic_n , italic_α > is minimal in α^^𝛼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG by Lemma 40 and <n,α>≺<m,β><n,\alpha>\prec<m,\beta>< italic_n , italic_α > ≺ < italic_m , italic_β >.     

Lemma 42

If <m,α><m,\alpha>< italic_m , italic_α > is minimal in β^normal-^𝛽\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG, then m𝑚mitalic_m is normal for β𝛽\betaitalic_β.

Proof: Suppose <m,α><m,\alpha>< italic_m , italic_α > is minimal in β^^𝛽\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG. By Lemma 40 α¯=β¯¯𝛼¯𝛽\overline{\alpha}=\overline{\beta}over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG = over¯ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG. Therefore α⁢ℛ⁢β𝛼ℛ𝛽\alpha\cal R\betaitalic_α caligraphic_R italic_β. But m𝑚mitalic_m is normal for α𝛼\alphaitalic_α and satisfies β𝛽\betaitalic_β, and Lemma 37 implies that m𝑚mitalic_m is normal for β𝛽\betaitalic_β.     

Appendix B Non-standard probabilistic semantics

B.1 Introduction

We shall describe now, in Definition 33 another family of probabilistic models, they provide much more direct semantics for nonmonotonic reasoning than Adams’, at the price of using the language of non-standard (in the sense of A. Robinson) probability theory. The purpose of this section is to provide additional evidence in support of Thesis 1. We shall show that rational relations are exactly those that may be defined by non-standard probabilistic models. In other terms, if, given a probability distribution, we decide to accept the assertion α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β iff the conditional probability of β𝛽\betaitalic_β given α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is very close to one, then the consequence relation we define is rational. On the other hand, any rational relation may be defined, in such a way, by some probability distribution. The results presented in the appendix are not used in the body of the paper. A different representation theorem for rational relations, also based on Theorem 5, in terms of one-parameter families of standard probabilistic models has been proved recently by K. Satoh [32]. Results relating the semantics of conditionals and non-Archimedean probabilities seem to have been obtained by R. Giles around 1980.

There is a school of thought in Artificial Intelligence, represented in particular by [3, 2], that denies the validity of the logical approach to modeling common-sense reasoning. The alternative suggested is the Bayesian probabilistic approach. Namely, the only way in which we should make sensible inferences from our knowledge α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is by estimating the conditional probability of the required conclusion β𝛽\betaitalic_β given our knowledge α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, and then adopting β𝛽\betaitalic_β if we are satisfied that this conditional probability is close enough to 1111. We believe that this approach may run into considerable practical difficulties, the choice being between keeping an explicit data base of these many conditional probabilities or estimating them from a small sample.
