The chief source of difficulty here is that knowing the probability of α𝛼\alphaitalic_α and β𝛽\betaitalic_β tells you very little about the probability of their intersection.

But we shall not argue the matter in detail here. The main purpose of this section is to show that rational knowledge bases may be considered to come from such a probabilistic model, if we let the cut-off point of how close the conditional probability of β𝛽\betaitalic_β given α𝛼\alphaitalic_α has to be before we are ready to adopt β𝛽\betaitalic_β as a sensible consequence of α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, approach 1111 as a limit. Namely, β𝛽\betaitalic_β is a sensible consequence of α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, iff the conditional probability is infinitesimally close to 1111. In order to have an interesting theory, there must be probabilities that are not standard real numbers, but belong to a richer system of numbers, containing some infinitesimally small numbers.

We shall show that this approach allows one to keep a probabilistic intuition while thinking about common-sense reasoning, namely think about α⁢ ∼ ⁢β𝛼 ∼ 𝛽\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\betaitalic_α ∼ italic_β as meaning that the conditional probability of β𝛽\betaitalic_β given α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is large, and still defines a well-behaved consequence relation that is not necessarily monotonic. Note that if one considers a standard probabilistic model and accepts α⁢ ∼ ⁢β𝛼 ∼ 𝛽\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\betaitalic_α ∼ italic_β as satisfied by the model iff the conditional probability P⁢r⁢(α/β)>1−ϵ𝑃𝑟𝛼𝛽1italic-ϵPr(\alpha/\beta)>1-\epsilonitalic_P italic_r ( italic_α / italic_β ) > 1 - italic_ϵ, for some choice of a positive ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ one obtains a consequence relation that is not well-behaved. For instance, one may have α⁢ ∼ ⁢β𝛼 ∼ 𝛽\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\betaitalic_α ∼ italic_β and α⁢ ∼ ⁢γ𝛼 ∼ 𝛾\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gammaitalic_α ∼ italic_γ satisfied by the model, while α⁢ ∼ ⁢β∧γ𝛼 ∼ 𝛽𝛾\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\ \beta\wedge\gammaitalic_α ∼ italic_β ∧ italic_γ is not satisfied. If, on the other one hand, one chooses ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ to be 00, one obtains a well-behaved consequence relation, but this relation is always monotonic, and the entailment defined is classical entailment (read  ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼  as material implication). J. McCarthy told us he suggested considering non-standard probabilistic models long ago, but, as far as we know, this suggestion has not been systematically pursued.

The structure of this section is as follows: first we shall, briefly, survey the basic notions of non-standard analysis. We shall also introduce non-standard probability spaces. Then we shall introduce non-standard probabilistic models for non-monotonic reasoning, define the consequence relation given by such a model and prove that any consequence relation given by a non-standard probability model is rational. Lastly we shall show that the axioms are complete for this interpretation, i.e., any rational consequence relation can be represented as the consequence relation given by some non-standard probability model, at least in the case the language ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L is countable. If ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L is not countable, an easy counter-example shows the result does not hold, but we shall not elaborate in this paper.

B.2 Non-Standard Analysis

Non-standard analysis was invented by Abraham Robinson in order to give a rigorous development of analysis in which limiting processes are replaced by behaviour at the infinitesimally small, e.g., the derivative becomes a quotient of the change in the function divided by the change in the argument, when the argument is infinitesimally increased. In this section we shall give a very brief introduction to the basic ideas. The reader interested in a full treatment can consult A. Robinson’s [31] or Keisler’s [16] books on the topic. More advanced topics related to non-standard probability theory are surveyed in [6].

The basic idea of non-standard analysis is to extend the real numbers to a larger ordered field while preserving many of the basic properties of the reals. Therefore, we consider a structure of the form

ℛ*=⟨R*,+*,×*,<*,0,1⟩superscriptℛsuperscript𝑅superscriptsuperscriptsuperscript01{\cal R}^{*}=\langle R^{*},+^{*},\times^{*},<^{*},0,1\ranglecaligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ⟨ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , + start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , × start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , < start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 0 , 1 ⟩

such that ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an elementary extension of the standard real numbers, namely 𝐑⊂R*𝐑superscript𝑅{\bf R}\subset R^{*}bold_R ⊂ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the operations and the order relation of ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT extend those of R and for every first order formula ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ

ℛ*⊧Φ⁢(x1,…,xn)⁢iff⁢𝐑⊧Φ⁢(x1,…,xn)modelssuperscriptℛΦsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛iff𝐑modelsΦsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛\mbox{${\cal R}^{*}$}\models\Phi(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n})\ \mbox{iff}\ {\bf R}\models\Phi(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n})caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊧ roman_Φ ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) iff bold_R ⊧ roman_Φ ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )

for x1,…,xn∈𝐑subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛𝐑x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}\in{\bf R}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ bold_R. Since we would like to consider not only properties of the real numbers, but real valued functions, functions from real valued functions into reals, and so on, we shall consider a richer structure: the superstructure of the real numbers.

Definition 27

The superstructure of the set X𝑋Xitalic_X is V∞⁢(X)=⋃n=0∞Vnsubscript𝑉𝑋superscriptsubscript𝑛0subscript𝑉𝑛V_{\infty}(X)=\bigcup_{n=0}^{\infty}V_{n}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) = ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where Vnsubscript𝑉𝑛V_{n}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are defined by induction:

  • •

    V0=Xsubscript𝑉0𝑋V_{0}=Xitalic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_X

  • •

    Vn+1=𝒫⁢(Vn)∪Vnsubscript𝑉𝑛1𝒫subscript𝑉𝑛subscript𝑉𝑛V_{n+1}={\cal P}(V_{n})\cup V_{n}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_P ( italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∪ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where 𝒫⁢(Y)𝒫𝑌{\cal P}(Y)caligraphic_P ( italic_Y ) is the power set of Y.

Note that the superstructure of X𝑋Xitalic_X contains all the relations on X𝑋Xitalic_X, all n𝑛nitalic_n-valued functions from X𝑋Xitalic_X into X𝑋Xitalic_X, etc. In a non-standard model of the real numbers we would like to have a non-standard counterpart to any standard member of the superstructure of the real numbers. Note that the set theoretical relation ∈\in∈ makes sense in the superstructure of X𝑋Xitalic_X. Recall that a formula of the first order language having only ∈\in∈ as a non logical constant is called bounded if is constructed by the usual connectives and bounded  quantifiers, namely (∀x∈y)for-all𝑥𝑦(\forall x\in y)( ∀ italic_x ∈ italic_y ) and (∃x∈y)𝑥𝑦(\exists x\in y)( ∃ italic_x ∈ italic_y ) meaning respectively: ∀x⁢𝑖𝑓⁢x∈y⁢𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑛⁢…for-all𝑥𝑖𝑓𝑥𝑦𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑛…\forall x\ \mbox{\em if}\ x\in y\ \mbox{\em then}\ldots∀ italic_x if italic_x ∈ italic_y then … and ∃x⁢x∈y∧…𝑥𝑥𝑦…\exists x\ x\in y\wedge\ldots∃ italic_x italic_x ∈ italic_y ∧ ….

Definition 28

A non-standard model of analysis is an ordered field ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTthat is a proper extension of the ordered field of the reals, together with a map *{}^{*}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT * end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT from the superstructure of R into the superstructure of ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, such that for every bounded formula Φ⁢(x1⁢…⁢xn)normal-Φsubscript𝑥1normal-…subscript𝑥𝑛\Phi(x_{1}\ldots x_{n})roman_Φ ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT … italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ):

V∞⁢(𝐑)⊧Φ⁢(a1⁢…⁢an)⁢𝑖𝑓𝑓⁢V∞⁢(ℛ*)⊧Φ⁢(a1*⁢…⁢an*)⁢(𝐋𝐞𝐢𝐛𝐧𝐢𝐳⁢𝐏𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐜𝐢𝐩𝐥𝐞)modelssubscript𝑉𝐑Φsubscript𝑎1…subscript𝑎𝑛𝑖𝑓𝑓subscript𝑉superscriptℛmodelsΦsuperscriptsubscript𝑎1…superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑛𝐋𝐞𝐢𝐛𝐧𝐢𝐳𝐏𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐜𝐢𝐩𝐥𝐞V_{\infty}({\bf R})\models\Phi(a_{1}\ldots a_{n})\ \mbox{iff}\ V_{\infty}(\mbox{${\cal R}^{*}$})\models\Phi(a_{1}^{*}\ldots a_{n}^{*})\ {\bf(Leibniz\ Principle)}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_R ) ⊧ roman_Φ ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT … italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) iff italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ⊧ roman_Φ ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT … italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ( bold_Leibniz bold_Principle )

and such that for x∈𝐑𝑥𝐑x\in{\bf R}italic_x ∈ bold_R x*=xsuperscript𝑥𝑥x^{*}=xitalic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_x (we assume that *{}^{*}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT * end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT transforms the standard operations of R into those of ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT).

The Leibniz principle guarantees that the non-standard counterpart of any standard notion (namely its *{}^{*}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT * end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT) preserves many of the properties of the standard object. In particular it is an object of the same kind: for example if A is a set of functions from R to R, then A*superscript𝐴A^{*}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a set of functions from ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT into ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. As another example consider the absolute value as a function from R to R. In R it has the property

(∀x∈𝐑)(∣x∣≥0∧(∣x∣=0↔x=0))\left(\forall x\in{\bf R})(\mid x\mid\geq 0\wedge\left(\mid x\mid=0\leftrightarrow x=0\right)\right)( ∀ italic_x ∈ bold_R ) ( ∣ italic_x ∣ ≥ 0 ∧ ( ∣ italic_x ∣ = 0 ↔ italic_x = 0 ) )

Then by the Leibniz principle

(∀x∈ℛ*)(∣x∣*≥*0∧(∣x∣*=0↔x=0))(\forall x\in\mbox{${\cal R}^{*}$})\left(\mid x\mid^{*}\geq^{*}0\wedge\left(\mid x\mid^{*}=0\leftrightarrow x=0\right)\right)( ∀ italic_x ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ( ∣ italic_x ∣ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 ∧ ( ∣ italic_x ∣ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0 ↔ italic_x = 0 ) )

In fact since the *{}^{*}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT * end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT versions of the standard arithmetic operations and relations (like ≤\leq≤, ≥,>,<\geq,>,<≥ , > , <) are so similar to the standard ones (they extend them) we shall simplify the notation by dropping the *{}^{*}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT * end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT, letting the context determine whether we mean the standard operation on R, or its extension to ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The next theorem shows that this is not a formal game:

Theorem 8 (Robinson)

There exists a non-standard model for analysis.

The proof is an application of the compactness theorem. The extension of R, ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, is not unique but nothing in the following arguments depends on the particular choice of the non-standard extension of R. So fix one such extension ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Definition 29
  1. 1.

    x∈ℛ*𝑥superscriptℛx\in\mbox{${\cal R}^{*}$}italic_x ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, x≠0𝑥0x\neq 0italic_x ≠ 0, is called finite if ∣x∣<ydelimited-∣∣𝑥𝑦\mid x\mid<y∣ italic_x ∣ < italic_y for some y∈𝐑𝑦𝐑y\in{\bf R}italic_y ∈ bold_R, or, equivalently, if ∣x∣<ndelimited-∣∣𝑥𝑛\mid x\mid<n∣ italic_x ∣ < italic_n for some natural number n𝑛nitalic_n.

  2. 2.

    x∈ℛ*𝑥superscriptℛx\in\mbox{${\cal R}^{*}$}italic_x ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is called infinitesimal if for all ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ in R, ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0italic_ϵ > 0, ∣x∣<ϵdelimited-∣∣𝑥italic-ϵ\mid x\mid<\epsilon∣ italic_x ∣ < italic_ϵ. Following our definition 00 is infinitesimal.

  3. 3.

    x∈V∞⁢(ℛ*)𝑥subscript𝑉superscriptℛx\in V_{\infty}(\mbox{${\cal R}^{*}$})italic_x ∈ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is called internal if x∈y*𝑥superscript𝑦x\in y^{*}italic_x ∈ italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for some y∈V∞⁢(𝐑)𝑦subscript𝑉𝐑y\in V_{\infty}({\bf R})italic_y ∈ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_R ). The set of internal objects is denoted by V∞*superscriptsubscript𝑉V_{\infty}^{*}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

  4. 4.

    x∈V∞⁢(ℛ*)𝑥subscript𝑉superscriptℛx\in V_{\infty}(\mbox{${\cal R}^{*}$})italic_x ∈ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is standard if x=y*𝑥superscript𝑦x=y^{*}italic_x = italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for some y∈V∞⁢(𝐑)𝑦subscript𝑉𝐑y\in V_{\infty}({\bf R})italic_y ∈ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_R ).

It follows easily, from the fact that ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a proper extension of R, that there are infinitesimal, as well as infinite, members of ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In fact x𝑥xitalic_x is infinitesimal iff 1/x1𝑥1/x1 / italic_x is infinite. If N is the set of natural numbers, one can show that N is a proper subset of 𝐍*superscript𝐍{\bf N}^{*}bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and every member of 𝐍*−𝐍superscript𝐍𝐍{\bf N}^{*}-{\bf N}bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_N is called a non-standard natural number.

Lemma 43
  1. 1.

    The sum, product and difference of two infinitesimals is infinitesimal.

  2. 2.

    The product of an infinitesimal and a finite member of ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is infinitesimal.

Theorem 9 (Robinson’s Overspill Principle)

Let ⟨An∣n∈𝐍⟩inner-productsubscript𝐴𝑛𝑛𝐍\langle A_{n}\mid n\in{\bf N}\rangle⟨ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ italic_n ∈ bold_N ⟩ be a sequence of members of Vk⁢(𝐑)subscript𝑉𝑘𝐑V_{k}({\bf R})italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_R ) for some k∈𝐍𝑘𝐍k\in{\bf N}italic_k ∈ bold_N. Assume also that, for all n∈𝐍𝑛𝐍n\in{\bf N}italic_n ∈ bold_N, An≠∅subscript𝐴𝑛A_{n}\neq\emptysetitalic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ ∅ and An+1⊆Ansubscript𝐴𝑛1subscript𝐴𝑛A_{n+1}\subseteq A_{n}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊆ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then ⋂n∈𝐍An*subscript𝑛𝐍superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑛\bigcap_{n\in{\bf N}}A_{n}^{*}⋂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ∈ bold_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is not empty.

Sketch of proof : Note that a sequence of elements of Vk⁢(𝐑)subscript𝑉𝑘𝐑V_{k}({\bf R})italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_R ) can be considered to be a function from N into Vk⁢(𝐑)subscript𝑉𝑘𝐑V_{k}({\bf R})italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_R ), and therefore it is a member of V∞⁢(𝐑)subscript𝑉𝐑V_{\infty}({\bf R})italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_R ). Hence ⟨An∣n∈𝐍⟩*superscriptinner-productsubscript𝐴𝑛𝑛𝐍\langle A_{n}\mid n\in{\bf N}\rangle^{*}⟨ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ italic_n ∈ bold_N ⟩ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT makes sense and it is a function from 𝐍*superscript𝐍{\bf N}^{*}bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT into Vk⁢(𝐑)*subscript𝑉𝑘superscript𝐑V_{k}({\bf R})^{*}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_R ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Its value at h∈𝐍*ℎsuperscript𝐍h\in{\bf N}^{*}italic_h ∈ bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT will be denoted by (A)h*subscriptsuperscript𝐴ℎ(A)^{*}_{h}( italic_A ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Note that (A)n*=An*subscriptsuperscript𝐴𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑛(A)^{*}_{n}=A_{n}^{*}( italic_A ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for n∈𝐍𝑛𝐍n\in{\bf N}italic_n ∈ bold_N. Let h∈𝐍*−𝐍ℎsuperscript𝐍𝐍h\in{\bf N}^{*}-{\bf N}italic_h ∈ bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_N. One can easily check, using the Leibniz principle, that (A)h*subscriptsuperscript𝐴ℎ(A)^{*}_{h}( italic_A ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is not empty and that for n∈𝐍𝑛𝐍n\in{\bf N}italic_n ∈ bold_N (A)h*⊆An*subscriptsuperscript𝐴ℎsubscriptsuperscript𝐴𝑛(A)^{*}_{h}\subseteq A^{*}_{n}( italic_A ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊆ italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, hence ⋂n∈𝐍An*subscript𝑛𝐍superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑛\bigcap_{n\in{\bf N}}A_{n}^{*}⋂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ∈ bold_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is not empty.     

We can now define the notion of non-standard probability space, which is like a standard (finitely additive) probability space, except that the values of the probability function are in ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Definition 30

An ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-probability space is a triple ⟨X,ℱ,P⁢r⟩𝑋ℱ𝑃𝑟\langle X,{\cal F},Pr\rangle⟨ italic_X , caligraphic_F , italic_P italic_r ⟩ where X is a non-empty set , ℱℱ\cal Fcaligraphic_F is a Boolean subalgebra of 𝒫⁢(X)𝒫𝑋{\cal P}(X)caligraphic_P ( italic_X ), (namely X∈ℱ𝑋ℱX\in\cal Fitalic_X ∈ caligraphic_F, ∅∈ℱℱ\emptyset\in\cal F∅ ∈ caligraphic_F, and ℱℱ\cal Fcaligraphic_F is closed under finite unions, intersections and differences) and P⁢r𝑃𝑟Pritalic_P italic_r is a function from ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F into ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that

  1. 1.

    P⁢r⁢(A)≥0𝑃𝑟𝐴0Pr(A)\geq 0italic_P italic_r ( italic_A ) ≥ 0 for A∈ℱ𝐴ℱA\in\cal Fitalic_A ∈ caligraphic_F.

  2. 2.

    P⁢r⁢(X)=1𝑃𝑟𝑋1Pr(X)=1italic_P italic_r ( italic_X ) = 1

  3. 3.

    P⁢r⁢(A∪B)=P⁢r⁢(A)+P⁢r⁢(B)𝑃𝑟𝐴𝐵𝑃𝑟𝐴𝑃𝑟𝐵Pr(A\cup B)=Pr(A)+Pr(B)italic_P italic_r ( italic_A ∪ italic_B ) = italic_P italic_r ( italic_A ) + italic_P italic_r ( italic_B ) for A,B∈ℱ𝐴𝐵ℱA,B\in\cal Fitalic_A , italic_B ∈ caligraphic_F, A and B disjoint

Note that many of the notions that are usually associated with probability spaces are immediately generalized to ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-probability space, like independence of ‘events’ (namely sets in ℱℱ\cal Fcaligraphic_F) and conditional probability: if P⁢r⁢(A)≠0𝑃𝑟𝐴0Pr(A)\not=0italic_P italic_r ( italic_A ) ≠ 0 then the conditional probability of B given A, is

P⁢r⁢(B∣A)=P⁢r⁢(A∩B)P⁢r⁢(A).𝑃𝑟conditional𝐵𝐴𝑃𝑟𝐴𝐵𝑃𝑟𝐴Pr(B\mid A)=\frac{Pr(A\cap B)}{Pr(A)}.italic_P italic_r ( italic_B ∣ italic_A ) = divide start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_A ∩ italic_B ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_A ) end_ARG .

See [6] for sophisticated applications of non-standard probability spaces. A useful way of getting ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-probability spaces is by using hyperfinite sets, sets which are considered by ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to be finite.

Definition 31

An internal object A∈V∞*𝐴subscriptsuperscript𝑉A\in V^{*}_{\infty}italic_A ∈ italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is called hyperfinite iff there exists a function f∈V∞*𝑓subscriptsuperscript𝑉f\in\mbox{$V^{*}_{\infty}$}italic_f ∈ italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and h∈𝐍*ℎsuperscript𝐍h\in{\bf N}^{*}italic_h ∈ bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that f is a 1-1 mapping of h onto A. Note that we follow the usual set theoretical convention by which a natural number is identified with all smaller natural numbers. Of course here we apply this convention also to non-standard natural numbers.

By applying the Leibniz principle we can show that if A is hyperfinite and B is an internal subset of A, then B is hyperfinite. Given an ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-valued function f which is internal, and A an hyperfinite subset of the domain of f, we can naturally define the ‘sum’ of the values of f on A, ∑x∈A*f⁢(x)subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝐴𝑓𝑥\sum^{*}_{x\in A}f(x)∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x ∈ italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_x ). ∑*superscript\sum^{*}∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is defined by taking the *{}^{*}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT * end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT of the standard operation of taking the sum of a finite set of real numbers. ∑*superscript\sum^{*}∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT shares many of the properties of its standard counterpart, for example

∑x∈A∪B*⁢f⁢(x)=∑x∈A*⁢f⁢(x)+∑x∈B*⁢f⁢(x)subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝐴𝐵𝑓𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝐴𝑓𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝐵𝑓𝑥\mbox{$\sum^{*}$}_{x\in A\cup B}f(x)=\mbox{$\sum^{*}$}_{x\in A}f(x)+\mbox{$\sum^{*}$}_{x\in B}f(x)∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x ∈ italic_A ∪ italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_x ) = ∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x ∈ italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_x ) + ∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x ∈ italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_x )

for A, B hyperfinite and disjoint. The next definition generalizes the notion of a finite probability space.

Definition 32 (Hyperfinite Probability Space)

Let A∈V∞*𝐴subscriptsuperscript𝑉A\in\mbox{$V^{*}_{\infty}$}italic_A ∈ italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be an hyperfinite set, let f be an internal ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-valued function on A, which is not constantly zero and such that for x∈A𝑥𝐴x\in Aitalic_x ∈ italic_A f⁢(x)≥0𝑓𝑥0f(x)\geq 0italic_f ( italic_x ) ≥ 0. Then the ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-probability space generated by A and f (denoted by P⁢R*⁢(A,f)𝑃superscript𝑅𝐴𝑓PR^{*}(A,f)italic_P italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_A , italic_f ) ) is ⟨A,ℱ,P⁢r⟩𝐴ℱ𝑃𝑟\langle A,{\cal F},Pr\rangle⟨ italic_A , caligraphic_F , italic_P italic_r ⟩ where ℱℱ\cal Fcaligraphic_F is the collection of all internal subsets of A, and P⁢rnormal-Pnormal-r{\em Pr}normal_P normal_r is given by

P⁢r⁢(B)=∑*x∈B⁢f⁢(x)∑*x∈A⁢f⁢(x)𝑃𝑟𝐵subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝐵𝑓𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝐴𝑓𝑥Pr(B)=\frac{\mbox{$\sum^{*}$}_{x\in B}f(x)}{\mbox{$\sum^{*}$}_{x\in A}f(x)}italic_P italic_r ( italic_B ) = divide start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x ∈ italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_x ) end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x ∈ italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_x ) end_ARG

One can verify that under the conditions of Definition 32, P⁢R*⁢(A,f)𝑃superscript𝑅𝐴𝑓PR^{*}(A,f)italic_P italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_A , italic_f ) is a ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-probability space.

B.3 Non-standard Probabilistic Models and Their Consequence Relations

An ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT probabilistic model is an ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-probability measure on some subset ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M of 𝒰𝒰{\cal U}caligraphic_U. Of course, we assume that for every formula of our language, α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, the set α^^𝛼\hat{\mbox{$\alpha$}}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG is measurable, namely it is in ℱℱ\cal Fcaligraphic_F. The probability measure induces a non-standard probability assignment to the formulas of the language by P⁢r⁢(α)=P⁢r⁢(α^)𝑃𝑟𝛼𝑃𝑟^𝛼Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$})=Pr(\hat{\mbox{$\alpha$}})italic_P italic_r ( italic_α ) = italic_P italic_r ( over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG ). The ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT probabilistic model ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M is said to be neat if for every formula, α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, if P⁢r⁢(α)=0𝑃𝑟𝛼0Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$})=0italic_P italic_r ( italic_α ) = 0 then α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is satisfied in no world of ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M.

Definition 33
  1. 1.

    Let ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M be an ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT probabilistic model. The conditional assertion α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β is valid in ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M, ℳ⊧α ∼ βmodelsℳα ∼ β\mbox{${\cal M}$}\models\mbox{\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\mbox{$\beta$}}caligraphic_M ⊧ italic_α italic_∼ italic_β, if either P⁢r⁢(α)=0𝑃𝑟𝛼0Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$})=0italic_P italic_r ( italic_α ) = 0 or the conditional probability of β𝛽\betaitalic_β given α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is infinitesimally close to 1, i.e., 1−P⁢r⁢(β∣α)1𝑃𝑟conditional𝛽𝛼1-Pr(\mbox{$\beta$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})1 - italic_P italic_r ( italic_β ∣ italic_α ) is infinitesimal. Note that this is equivalent to saying that P⁢r⁢(α)=0𝑃𝑟𝛼0Pr(\alpha)=0italic_P italic_r ( italic_α ) = 0 or P⁢r⁢(¬⁢β∣α)𝑃𝑟conditional𝛽𝛼Pr(\neg\mbox{$\beta$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})italic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_β ∣ italic_α ) is infinitesimal.

  2. 2.

    The consequence relation defined by ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M is:

    K⁢(ℳ)={α ∼ β∣ℳ⊧α ∼ β}𝐾ℳconditional-setα ∼ βmodelsℳα ∼ βK(\mbox{${\cal M}$})=\{\mbox{\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\mbox{$\beta$}}\mid\mbox{${\cal M}$}\models\mbox{\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\mbox{$\beta$}}\}italic_K ( caligraphic_M ) = { italic_α italic_∼ italic_β ∣ caligraphic_M ⊧ italic_α italic_∼ italic_β }
Theorem 10 (Soundness for Non-standard Probabilistic Models)

For every ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT probabilistic model ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M, K(ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M) is a rational consequence relation.

Proof: Left Logical Equivalence, Right Weakening, and Reflexivity are immediate. And follows from:

P⁢r⁢(¬⁡(β∧γ)∣α)=P⁢r⁢((¬⁢β∨¬⁢γ)∣α)≤P⁢r⁢(¬⁢β∣α)+P⁢r⁢(¬⁢γ∣α)𝑃𝑟conditional𝛽𝛾𝛼𝑃𝑟conditional𝛽𝛾𝛼𝑃𝑟conditional𝛽𝛼𝑃𝑟conditional𝛾𝛼Pr(\neg(\mbox{$\beta$}\wedge\mbox{$\gamma$})\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})=Pr((\neg\mbox{$\beta$}\vee\neg\mbox{$\gamma$})\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})\leq Pr(\neg\mbox{$\beta$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})+Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})italic_P italic_r ( ¬ ( italic_β ∧ italic_γ ) ∣ italic_α ) = italic_P italic_r ( ( ¬ italic_β ∨ ¬ italic_γ ) ∣ italic_α ) ≤ italic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_β ∣ italic_α ) + italic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_γ ∣ italic_α )

and from the fact that the sum of two infinitesimals is infinitesimal. Or is proved by the following manipulation:

P⁢r⁢(¬⁢γ∣α∨β)𝑃𝑟conditional𝛾𝛼𝛽\displaystyle Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$}\vee\mbox{$\beta$})italic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_γ ∣ italic_α ∨ italic_β ) =\displaystyle== P⁢r⁢(¬⁢γ∧(α∨β))P⁢r⁢(α∨β)≤𝑃𝑟𝛾𝛼𝛽𝑃𝑟𝛼𝛽absent\displaystyle\frac{Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\wedge(\mbox{$\alpha$}\vee\mbox{$\beta$}))}{Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$}\vee\mbox{$\beta$})}\leqdivide start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_γ ∧ ( italic_α ∨ italic_β ) ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_α ∨ italic_β ) end_ARG ≤
P⁢r⁢(¬⁢γ∧α)P⁢r⁢(α∨β)𝑃𝑟𝛾𝛼𝑃𝑟𝛼𝛽\displaystyle\frac{Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\wedge\mbox{$\alpha$})}{Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$}\vee\mbox{$\beta$})}divide start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_γ ∧ italic_α ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_α ∨ italic_β ) end_ARG +\displaystyle++ P⁢r⁢(¬⁢γ∧β)P⁢r⁢(α∨β)≤𝑃𝑟𝛾𝛽𝑃𝑟𝛼𝛽absent\displaystyle\frac{Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\wedge\mbox{$\beta$})}{Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$}\vee\mbox{$\beta$})}\leqdivide start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_γ ∧ italic_β ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_α ∨ italic_β ) end_ARG ≤
P⁢r⁢(¬⁢γ∧α)P⁢r⁢(α)𝑃𝑟𝛾𝛼𝑃𝑟𝛼\displaystyle\frac{Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\wedge\mbox{$\alpha$})}{Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$})}divide start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_γ ∧ italic_α ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_α ) end_ARG +\displaystyle++ P⁢r⁢(¬⁢γ∧β)P⁢r⁢(β)=P⁢r⁢(¬⁢γ∣α)+P⁢r⁢(¬⁢γ∣β)𝑃𝑟𝛾𝛽𝑃𝑟𝛽𝑃𝑟conditional𝛾𝛼𝑃𝑟conditional𝛾𝛽\displaystyle\frac{Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\wedge\mbox{$\beta$})}{Pr(\mbox{$\beta$})}=Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})+Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\mid\mbox{$\beta$})divide start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_γ ∧ italic_β ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_β ) end_ARG = italic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_γ ∣ italic_α ) + italic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_γ ∣ italic_β )

and again using the fact that the sum of two infinitesimals is infinitesimal. We assumed above that P⁢r⁢(α)>0𝑃𝑟𝛼0Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$})>0italic_P italic_r ( italic_α ) > 0 and P⁢r⁢(β)>0𝑃𝑟𝛽0Pr(\mbox{$\beta$})>0italic_P italic_r ( italic_β ) > 0. If this fails then the argument is easier. We shall prove Rational Monotonicity by contradiction, so we assume that α ∼ ⁢¬⁢βα ∼ 𝛽\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\neg\mbox{$\beta$}roman_α ∼ ¬ italic_β is not in K(ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M), and that α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ is in K(ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M). We shall prove that α∧β ∼ γ𝛼β ∼ γ\mbox{$\alpha$}\wedge\mbox{$\beta$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\mbox{$\gamma$}italic_α ∧ roman_β ∼ roman_γ is in K(ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M). We can assume that P⁢r⁢(α∧β)>0𝑃𝑟𝛼𝛽0Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$}\wedge\mbox{$\beta$})>0italic_P italic_r ( italic_α ∧ italic_β ) > 0 (hence P⁢r⁢(α)>0𝑃𝑟𝛼0Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$})>0italic_P italic_r ( italic_α ) > 0) otherwise the argument is trivial.

P⁢r⁢(¬⁢γ∣α∧β)𝑃𝑟conditional𝛾𝛼𝛽\displaystyle Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$}\wedge\mbox{$\beta$})italic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_γ ∣ italic_α ∧ italic_β ) =\displaystyle== P⁢r⁢(¬⁢γ∧α∧β)P⁢r⁢(α∧β)=𝑃𝑟𝛾𝛼𝛽𝑃𝑟𝛼𝛽absent\displaystyle\frac{Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\wedge\mbox{$\alpha$}\wedge\mbox{$\beta$})}{Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$}\wedge\mbox{$\beta$})}=divide start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_γ ∧ italic_α ∧ italic_β ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_α ∧ italic_β ) end_ARG =
P⁢r⁢(¬⁢γ∧α∧β)P⁢r⁢(α)𝑃𝑟𝛾𝛼𝛽𝑃𝑟𝛼\displaystyle\frac{Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\wedge\mbox{$\alpha$}\wedge\mbox{$\beta$})}{Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$})}divide start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_γ ∧ italic_α ∧ italic_β ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_α ) end_ARG /\displaystyle// P⁢r⁢(α∧β)P⁢r⁢(α)≤𝑃𝑟𝛼𝛽𝑃𝑟𝛼absent\displaystyle\frac{Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$}\wedge\mbox{$\beta$})}{Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$})}\leqdivide start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_α ∧ italic_β ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_α ) end_ARG ≤
P⁢r⁢(¬⁢γ∧α)P⁢r⁢(α)𝑃𝑟𝛾𝛼𝑃𝑟𝛼\displaystyle\frac{Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\wedge\mbox{$\alpha$})}{Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$})}divide start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_γ ∧ italic_α ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_α ) end_ARG /\displaystyle// P⁢r⁢(α∧β)P⁢r⁢(α)=𝑃𝑟𝛼𝛽𝑃𝑟𝛼absent\displaystyle\frac{Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$}\wedge\mbox{$\beta$})}{Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$})}=divide start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_α ∧ italic_β ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_α ) end_ARG =
P⁢r⁢(¬⁢γ∣α)𝑃𝑟conditional𝛾𝛼\displaystyle Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})italic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_γ ∣ italic_α ) ×\displaystyle\times× 1P⁢r⁢(β∣α)1𝑃𝑟conditional𝛽𝛼\displaystyle\frac{1}{Pr(\mbox{$\beta$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_β ∣ italic_α ) end_ARG (21)

Since α ∼ ⁢¬⁢βα ∼ 𝛽\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\neg\mbox{$\beta$}roman_α ∼ ¬ italic_β is not in K⁢(ℳ)𝐾ℳK(\mbox{${\cal M}$})italic_K ( caligraphic_M ) , we get that P⁢r⁢(β∣α)𝑃𝑟conditional𝛽𝛼Pr(\mbox{$\beta$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})italic_P italic_r ( italic_β ∣ italic_α ) is not infinitesimal, hence 1P⁢r⁢(β∣α)1𝑃𝑟conditional𝛽𝛼\frac{1}{Pr(\mbox{$\beta$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_β ∣ italic_α ) end_ARG is finite. By Lemma 43 P⁢r⁢(¬⁢γ∧α)×1P⁢r⁢(β∣α)𝑃𝑟𝛾𝛼1𝑃𝑟conditional𝛽𝛼Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\wedge\mbox{$\alpha$})\times\frac{1}{Pr(\mbox{$\beta$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})}italic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_γ ∧ italic_α ) × divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_β ∣ italic_α ) end_ARG is infinitesimal. Hence by Equation B.3, α∧β ∼ γ𝛼β ∼ γ\mbox{$\alpha$}\wedge\mbox{$\beta$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\mbox{$\gamma$}italic_α ∧ roman_β ∼ roman_γ is in K⁢(ℳ)𝐾ℳK(\mbox{${\cal M}$})italic_K ( caligraphic_M ). Cautious Monotonicity now follows easily. Suppose α⁢ ∼γsimilar-to𝛼 𝛾\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\gammaitalic_α ∼ italic_γ and α𝛼\alphaitalic_α ∼similar-to absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim∼ β𝛽\betaitalic_β are both in K⁢(ℳ)𝐾ℳK(\mbox{${\cal M}$})italic_K ( caligraphic_M ). If α⁢ ∼¬⁢βsimilar-to𝛼 𝛽\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\betaitalic_α ∼ ¬ italic_β is not in K⁢(ℳ)𝐾ℳK(\mbox{${\cal M}$})italic_K ( caligraphic_M ), we conclude by Rational Monotonicity. If α⁢ ∼¬⁢βsimilar-to𝛼 𝛽\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\betaitalic_α ∼ ¬ italic_β is in K⁢(ℳ)𝐾ℳK(\mbox{${\cal M}$})italic_K ( caligraphic_M ), we must have P⁢r⁢(α)=0𝑃𝑟𝛼0Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$})=0italic_P italic_r ( italic_α ) = 0, since P⁢r⁢(β∣α)𝑃𝑟conditional𝛽𝛼Pr(\beta\mid\alpha)italic_P italic_r ( italic_β ∣ italic_α ) and P⁢r⁢(¬⁢β∣α)𝑃𝑟conditional𝛽𝛼Pr(\neg\beta\mid\alpha)italic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_β ∣ italic_α ) cannot be both infinitesimally close to 1. Therefore P⁢r⁢(α∧β)=0𝑃𝑟𝛼𝛽0Pr(\alpha\wedge\beta)=0italic_P italic_r ( italic_α ∧ italic_β ) = 0 and we conclude that α∧β⁢ ∼γ∈K⁢(ℳ)similar-to𝛼𝛽 𝛾𝐾ℳ\alpha\wedge\beta\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\gamma\in K(\mbox{${\cal M}$})italic_α ∧ italic_β ∼ italic_γ ∈ italic_K ( caligraphic_M ).     

B.4 Completeness for the Non-Standard Probabilistic Interpretation

Theorem 11

Suppose the language ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L is countable (this assumption cannot be dispensed with) and P𝑃Pitalic_P is a rational consequence relation on ℒℒ{\cal L}caligraphic_L. Let ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be any non-standard model of analysis, then there exists an ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-probabilistic neat model ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M such that K⁢(ℳ)=K𝐾ℳ𝐾K(\mbox{${\cal M}$})=Kitalic_K ( caligraphic_M ) = italic_K.

Proof: Let W=⟨S,l,≺⟩𝑊𝑆𝑙precedesW=\langle S,l,\prec\rangleitalic_W = ⟨ italic_S , italic_l , ≺ ⟩, with ranking function r𝑟ritalic_r, be a countable (i.e., S𝑆Sitalic_S is countable) ranked model that defines the consequence relation P𝑃Pitalic_P. The model built in the proof of Theorem 5 shows that such models exist. If S𝑆Sitalic_S is finite, or even if each level in W𝑊Witalic_W is finite and W𝑊Witalic_W is well-founded, one may simply use the construction described just before Lemma 22, with some arbitrary infinitesimal ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ. In case the model W𝑊Witalic_W is infinitely broad, i.e., has some level containing an infinite number of states, then the construction has to be slightly more sophisticated, but the real difficulty appears when W𝑊Witalic_W is not well-founded, and we have already remarked that there are rational relations that have no well-founded ranked model. Following the proof of Lemma 22 we would like to assign a (non-standard) probability distribution to the states of the model in such a way that the relative probabilty of a level to that of a lower level is infinitesimal, but, for every formula which is satified at a given level, we would like to keep its relative weight within the level non infinitesimal. To each formula we shall assign a positive real number r𝑟ritalic_r such that, if the formula is satisfied at level l𝑙litalic_l, its relative probability within this level should be at least r𝑟ritalic_r. In order that these requirements not be contradictory, the sum of the r𝑟ritalic_r’s so assigned should be at most 1111. Quite arbitrarily, we pick for the i𝑖iitalic_i-th formula r=1/2i+1𝑟1superscript2𝑖1r=1/2^{i+1}italic_r = 1 / 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Now we have to show that we can find a probability assignment satisfying these requirements. We shall define a set Bnsubscript𝐵𝑛B_{n}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of all probability assignments that are good up to rank n𝑛nitalic_n. An assignment which is good for every n𝑛nitalic_n will satisfy our requirements. So, we would like to intersect the Bnsubscript𝐵𝑛B_{n}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT’s. The overspill principle will tell us that this intersection is not empty.

Since S𝑆Sitalic_S is countable we may assume that S=𝐍𝑆𝐍S={\bf N}italic_S = bold_N. Since every countable linear ordering may be order embedded into the real numbers, we may assume without loss of generality that the ranking function, r𝑟ritalic_r, is into R. Since ≺precedes\prec≺ is a partial ordering of N, ≺*superscriptprecedes\prec^{*}≺ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a partial ordering of 𝐍*superscript𝐍{\bf N}^{*}bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT which is ranked by the ranking function r*superscript𝑟r^{*}italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT mapping 𝐍*superscript𝐍{\bf N}^{*}bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT into ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

For each formula α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, let Aα=(α^)*subscript𝐴𝛼superscript^𝛼A_{\mbox{$\alpha$}}=(\hat{\mbox{$\alpha$}})^{*}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note that Aαsubscript𝐴𝛼A_{\mbox{$\alpha$}}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a subset of 𝐍*superscript𝐍{\bf N}^{*}bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (but must not be a subset of N). We can now associate a world, 𝒰hsubscript𝒰ℎ\mbox{${\cal U}$}_{h}caligraphic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with each h∈𝐍*ℎsuperscript𝐍h\in{\bf N}^{*}italic_h ∈ bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, defined by 𝒰h⊧pmodelssubscript𝒰ℎ𝑝\mbox{${\cal U}$}_{h}\models pcaligraphic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊧ italic_p iff h∈Apℎsubscript𝐴𝑝h\in A_{p}italic_h ∈ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. It is easily checked that, for standard hℎhitalic_h (i.e., h∈𝐍ℎ𝐍h\in{\bf N}italic_h ∈ bold_N), one has 𝒰h=l⁢(h)subscript𝒰ℎ𝑙ℎ\mbox{${\cal U}$}_{h}=l(h)caligraphic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_l ( italic_h ) and that, for arbitrary hℎhitalic_h, 𝒰h⊧αmodelssubscript𝒰ℎ𝛼\mbox{${\cal U}$}_{h}\models\mbox{$\alpha$}caligraphic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊧ italic_α iff h∈Aαℎsubscript𝐴𝛼h\in A_{\mbox{$\alpha$}}italic_h ∈ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Our idea now is to find an hℎhitalic_h in 𝐍*superscript𝐍{\bf N}^{*}bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and an internal function f𝑓fitalic_f, from hℎhitalic_h into ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that, if we consider the probability distribution given by the hyperfinite probability space P⁢R*⁢(h,f)𝑃superscript𝑅ℎ𝑓PR^{*}(h,f)italic_P italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_h , italic_f ) on the set of worlds {𝒰k∣k∈𝐍*,k<h}conditional-setsubscript𝒰𝑘formulae-sequence𝑘superscript𝐍𝑘ℎ\{\mbox{${\cal U}$}_{k}\mid k\in{\bf N}^{*},k<h\}{ caligraphic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ italic_k ∈ bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_k < italic_h }, we shall get a probabilistic model whose consequence relation is exactly P𝑃Pitalic_P (recall that we are identifying a member of 𝐍*superscript𝐍{\bf N}^{*}bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with the set of smaller members of 𝐍*superscript𝐍{\bf N}^{*}bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT). Fix an enumeration ⟨αn∣n∈𝐍⟩inner-productsubscript𝛼𝑛𝑛𝐍\langle\mbox{$\alpha$}_{n}\mid n\in{\bf N}\rangle⟨ italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ italic_n ∈ bold_N ⟩ of all the formulas of our language. For i∈𝐍𝑖𝐍i\in{\bf N}italic_i ∈ bold_N let xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the real number such that the ranking function f𝑓fitalic_f maps all the states minimal in αi^^subscript𝛼𝑖\hat{\mbox{$\alpha$}_{i}}over^ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG to it.

We are now going to define a sequence of sets of possible approximations to the object we are looking for, namely the appropriate h∈𝐍*ℎsuperscript𝐍h\in{\bf N}^{*}italic_h ∈ bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the appropriate f𝑓fitalic_f. For n∈𝐍𝑛𝐍n\in{\bf N}italic_n ∈ bold_N, let Bnsubscript𝐵𝑛B_{n}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the set of all triples of the form (k,ϵ,f)𝑘italic-ϵ𝑓(k,\epsilon,f)( italic_k , italic_ϵ , italic_f ) that have the following properties:

  1. 1.

    k≥n𝑘𝑛k\geq nitalic_k ≥ italic_n,

  2. 2.

    ϵ∈𝐑italic-ϵ𝐑\epsilon\in{\bf R}italic_ϵ ∈ bold_R, ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0italic_ϵ > 0, ϵ≤1/nitalic-ϵ1𝑛\epsilon\leq 1/nitalic_ϵ ≤ 1 / italic_n,

  3. 3.

    f𝑓fitalic_f is a function from N into R such that for any s∈𝐍𝑠𝐍s\in{\bf N}italic_s ∈ bold_N, f⁢(s)>0𝑓𝑠0f(s)>0italic_f ( italic_s ) > 0,

  4. 4.

    for any x,y∈𝐑𝑥𝑦𝐑x,y\in{\bf R}italic_x , italic_y ∈ bold_R such that x<y𝑥𝑦x<yitalic_x < italic_y, if x𝑥xitalic_x and y𝑦yitalic_y are in the range of the ranking function r𝑟ritalic_r on k𝑘kitalic_k, then

    ∑m<k,r⁢(m)=yf⁢(m)∑m<k,r⁢(m)=xf⁢(m)≤ϵ,subscriptformulae-sequence𝑚𝑘𝑟𝑚𝑦𝑓𝑚subscriptformulae-sequence𝑚𝑘𝑟𝑚𝑥𝑓𝑚italic-ϵ\frac{\sum_{m<k,r(m)=y}f(m)}{\sum_{m<k,r(m)=x}f(m)}\leq\epsilon,divide start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m < italic_k , italic_r ( italic_m ) = italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_m ) end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m < italic_k , italic_r ( italic_m ) = italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_m ) end_ARG ≤ italic_ϵ ,
  5. 5.

    for αisubscript𝛼𝑖\mbox{$\alpha$}_{i}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i<k𝑖𝑘i<kitalic_i < italic_k, if C=αi^∩{j∣r⁢(j)=xi}∩{0,…,k−1}≠∅𝐶^subscript𝛼𝑖conditional-set𝑗𝑟𝑗subscript𝑥𝑖0…𝑘1C=\hat{\mbox{$\alpha$}_{i}}\cap\{j\mid r(j)=x_{i}\}\cap\{0,\ldots,k-1\}\neq\emptysetitalic_C = over^ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ∩ { italic_j ∣ italic_r ( italic_j ) = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } ∩ { 0 , … , italic_k - 1 } ≠ ∅, then

    ∑m∈C,m<kf⁢(m)∑m<k,r⁢(m)=xif⁢(m)≥12i+1subscriptformulae-sequence𝑚𝐶𝑚𝑘𝑓𝑚subscriptformulae-sequence𝑚𝑘𝑟𝑚subscript𝑥𝑖𝑓𝑚1superscript2𝑖1\frac{\sum_{m\in C,m<k}f(m)}{\sum_{m<k,r(m)=x_{i}}f(m)}\geq\frac{1}{2^{i+1}}divide start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m ∈ italic_C , italic_m < italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_m ) end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m < italic_k , italic_r ( italic_m ) = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_m ) end_ARG ≥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG

It easily follows from the definition of the sequence of sets ⟨Bn∣n∈𝐍⟩inner-productsubscript𝐵𝑛𝑛𝐍\langle B_{n}\mid n\in{\bf N}\rangle⟨ italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ italic_n ∈ bold_N ⟩ that Bn+1⊆Bnsubscript𝐵𝑛1subscript𝐵𝑛B_{n+1}\subseteq B_{n}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊆ italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for n∈𝐍𝑛𝐍n\in{\bf N}italic_n ∈ bold_N. One may also verify from item 4 that, if (k,ϵ,f)∈Bn𝑘italic-ϵ𝑓subscript𝐵𝑛(k,\epsilon,f)\in B_{n}( italic_k , italic_ϵ , italic_f ) ∈ italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and if x𝑥xitalic_x is in the range of r𝑟ritalic_r on k𝑘kitalic_k, then:

∑m<k,r⁢(m)>xf⁢(m)∑m<k,r⁢(m)=xf⁢(m)≤∑i=1∞ϵi=ϵ1−ϵsubscriptformulae-sequence𝑚𝑘𝑟𝑚𝑥𝑓𝑚subscriptformulae-sequence𝑚𝑘𝑟𝑚𝑥𝑓𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖italic-ϵ1italic-ϵ\frac{\sum_{m<k,r(m)>x}f(m)}{\sum_{m<k,r(m)=x}f(m)}\leq\sum_{i=1}^{\infty}\epsilon^{i}=\frac{\epsilon}{1-\epsilon}divide start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m < italic_k , italic_r ( italic_m ) > italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_m ) end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m < italic_k , italic_r ( italic_m ) = italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_m ) end_ARG ≤ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_ϵ end_ARG (22)
Lemma 44

For any n∈𝐍𝑛𝐍n\in{\bf N}italic_n ∈ bold_N, Bn≠∅subscript𝐵𝑛B_{n}\neq\emptysetitalic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ ∅.

Proof: The proof is essentially similar to the remarks preceding the proof of Lemma 22 in Section 4.3. Let, indeed, Wnsubscript𝑊𝑛W_{n}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the finite ranked model defined by ⟨{0,…,n−1},≺,l⟩0…𝑛1precedes𝑙\langle\{0,\ldots,n-1\},\prec,l\rangle⟨ { 0 , … , italic_n - 1 } , ≺ , italic_l ⟩. We can easily arrange a probability assignment for it such that the ratio of the probability of each rank and and each smaller rank will be at most 1/n1𝑛1/n1 / italic_n. Within the rank we have to satisfy item 5 in the definition of Bnsubscript𝐵𝑛B_{n}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT but we can easily arrange for i<n𝑖𝑛i<nitalic_i < italic_n, that if αisubscript𝛼𝑖\mbox{$\alpha$}_{i}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has a non empty intersection with this rank, then its relative probability within this rank is at least 12i+11superscript2𝑖1\frac{1}{2^{i+1}}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG. This may be arranged because ∑i∈𝐍12i+1=1subscript𝑖𝐍1superscript2𝑖11\sum_{i\in{\bf N}}\frac{1}{2^{i+1}}=1∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ bold_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG = 1. If we extend this probability assignment to any function from N into R, we see that (n,1n,f)∈Bn𝑛1𝑛𝑓subscript𝐵𝑛(n,\frac{1}{n},f)\in B_{n}( italic_n , divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG , italic_f ) ∈ italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.     

Once we have Lemma 44 we can use Robinson’s overspill principle (Theorem  9) to show that ∩n∈𝐍Bn*subscript𝑛𝐍superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑛\cap_{n\in{\bf N}}B_{n}^{*}∩ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ∈ bold_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is not empty. So let (h~,ε~,f~)~ℎ~𝜀~𝑓(\mbox{$\tilde{h}$},\mbox{$\tilde{\varepsilon}$},\mbox{$\tilde{f}$})( over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG , over~ start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG , over~ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ) be a member of Bn*superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑛B_{n}^{*}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for every n∈𝐍𝑛𝐍n\in{\bf N}italic_n ∈ bold_N. One can easily verify that h~~ℎ\tilde{h}over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG is in 𝐍*superscript𝐍{\bf N}^{*}bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and that it is a non-standard natural number: indeed for every n∈𝐍𝑛𝐍n\in{\bf N}italic_n ∈ bold_N, h~>n~ℎ𝑛\mbox{$\tilde{h}$}>nover~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG > italic_n since (h~,ε~,f~)∈Bn*~ℎ~𝜀~𝑓superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑛(\mbox{$\tilde{h}$},\mbox{$\tilde{\varepsilon}$},\mbox{$\tilde{f}$})\in B_{n}^{*}( over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG , over~ start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG , over~ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ) ∈ italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Similarly ε~~𝜀\tilde{\varepsilon}over~ start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG is a positive member of ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that for every standard natural number n𝑛nitalic_n we have ε~≤1n~𝜀1𝑛\mbox{$\tilde{\varepsilon}$}\leq\frac{1}{n}over~ start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG ≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG, hence ε~~𝜀\tilde{\varepsilon}over~ start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG is a positive infinitesimal. Also f~~𝑓\tilde{f}over~ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG is a function from 𝐍*superscript𝐍{\bf N}^{*}bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT into the positive members of ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, satisfying the appropriate transfer of items 5 and 4 into the context of ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In particular, Equation 22 carries over and we have x=r*⁢(m)𝑥superscript𝑟𝑚x=r^{*}(m)italic_x = italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) for some m∈𝐍*,m<h~formulae-sequence𝑚superscript𝐍𝑚~ℎm\in{\bf N}^{*},m<\mbox{$\tilde{h}$}italic_m ∈ bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_m < over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG:

∑*m<h~,r*⁢(m)>x⁢f~⁢(m)∑*m<h~,r*⁢(m)=x⁢f~⁢(m)≤ε~1−ε~subscriptsuperscriptformulae-sequence𝑚~ℎsuperscript𝑟𝑚𝑥~𝑓𝑚subscriptsuperscriptformulae-sequence𝑚~ℎsuperscript𝑟𝑚𝑥~𝑓𝑚~𝜀1~𝜀\frac{\mbox{$\sum^{*}$}_{m<\mbox{$\tilde{h}$},r^{*}(m)>x}\mbox{$\tilde{f}$}(m)}{\mbox{$\sum^{*}$}_{m<\mbox{$\tilde{h}$},r^{*}(m)=x}\mbox{$\tilde{f}$}(m)}\leq\frac{\mbox{$\tilde{\varepsilon}$}}{1-\mbox{$\tilde{\varepsilon}$}}divide start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m < over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG , italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) > italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( italic_m ) end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m < over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG , italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) = italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( italic_m ) end_ARG ≤ divide start_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 1 - over~ start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG end_ARG (23)

We conclude therefore that the left-hand side of Equation 23 is infinitesimal. We claim that the ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT probabilistic model ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M whose collection of states is h~~ℎ\tilde{h}over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG, i.e., {m∣m∈𝐍*,m<h~}conditional-set𝑚formulae-sequence𝑚superscript𝐍𝑚~ℎ\{m\mid m\in{\bf N}^{*},m<\mbox{$\tilde{h}$}\}{ italic_m ∣ italic_m ∈ bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_m < over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG }, the world associated with m𝑚mitalic_m is 𝒰msubscript𝒰𝑚\mbox{${\cal U}$}_{m}caligraphic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the probability measure is given by the hyperfinite probability space P⁢R*⁢(h~,f~)𝑃superscript𝑅~ℎ~𝑓PR^{*}(\mbox{$\tilde{h}$},\mbox{$\tilde{f}$})italic_P italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG , over~ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ) is the model we are looking for. Since any f𝑓fitalic_f satisfying the requirements can be multiplied by any positive member of ℛ*superscriptℛ{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and still satisfies the requirements, we may assume without loss of generality that

∑m∈𝐍*,m<h~*⁢f~⁢(m)=1subscriptsuperscriptformulae-sequence𝑚superscript𝐍𝑚~ℎ~𝑓𝑚1\mbox{$\sum^{*}$}_{m\in{\bf N}^{*},m<\mbox{$\tilde{h}$}}\mbox{$\tilde{f}$}(m)=1∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m ∈ bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_m < over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( italic_m ) = 1

Note that ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M is a neat model since, if we have both m<h~𝑚~ℎm<\mbox{$\tilde{h}$}italic_m < over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG and 𝒰m⊧αmodelssubscript𝒰𝑚𝛼\mbox{${\cal U}$}_{m}\models\mbox{$\alpha$}caligraphic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊧ italic_α, we must also have P⁢r⁢(α)≥f~⁢(m)>0𝑃𝑟𝛼~𝑓𝑚0Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$})\geq\mbox{$\tilde{f}$}(m)>0italic_P italic_r ( italic_α ) ≥ over~ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( italic_m ) > 0.

Claim 1

K⁢(ℳ)=K𝐾ℳ𝐾K(\mbox{${\cal M}$})=Kitalic_K ( caligraphic_M ) = italic_K

Proof: First note that α ∼ ⁢𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐬𝐞∈K⁢(ℳ)α ∼ 𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐬𝐞𝐾ℳ\mbox{$\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }{\bf false}$}\in K(\mbox{${\cal M}$})roman_α ∼ bold_false ∈ italic_K ( caligraphic_M ) iff α ∼ ⁢𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐬𝐞∈Kα ∼ 𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐬𝐞𝐾\mbox{$\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }{\bf false}$}\in Kroman_α ∼ bold_false ∈ italic_K. If α ∼ ⁢𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐬𝐞∈Kα ∼ 𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐬𝐞𝐾\mbox{$\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }{\bf false}$}\in Kroman_α ∼ bold_false ∈ italic_K, then Aα=∅subscript𝐴𝛼A_{\mbox{$\alpha$}}=\emptysetitalic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∅, hence {m∣m∈𝐍*,𝒰⊧α}=∅conditional-set𝑚formulae-sequence𝑚superscript𝐍models𝒰𝛼\{m\mid m\in{\bf N}^{*},\mbox{${\cal U}$}\models\mbox{$\alpha$}\}=\emptyset{ italic_m ∣ italic_m ∈ bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_U ⊧ italic_α } = ∅. Therefore α ∼ ⁢𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐬𝐞∈K⁢(ℳ)α ∼ 𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐬𝐞𝐾ℳ\mbox{$\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }{\bf false}$}\in K(\mbox{${\cal M}$})roman_α ∼ bold_false ∈ italic_K ( caligraphic_M ). For the other direction, if α ∼ ⁢𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐬𝐞∉Kα ∼ 𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐬𝐞𝐾\mbox{$\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }{\bf false}$}\not\in Kroman_α ∼ bold_false ∉ italic_K, then, for some m∈𝐍𝑚𝐍m\in{\bf N}italic_m ∈ bold_N, Um⊧αmodelssubscript𝑈𝑚𝛼U_{m}\models\mbox{$\alpha$}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊧ italic_α. But m𝑚mitalic_m, being a standard natural number, is less than h~~ℎ\tilde{h}over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG, hence some state in ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M satisfies α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. By the neatness of ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M, α ∼ ⁢𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐬𝐞∉K⁢(ℳ)α ∼ 𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐬𝐞𝐾ℳ\mbox{$\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }{\bf false}$}\not\in K(\mbox{${\cal M}$})roman_α ∼ bold_false ∉ italic_K ( caligraphic_M ). By the previous remark, we can now assume that α ∼ ⁢𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐬𝐞∉Kα ∼ 𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐬𝐞𝐾\mbox{$\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }{\bf false}$}\not\in Kroman_α ∼ bold_false ∉ italic_K, hence α^≠∅^𝛼{\mbox{$\hat{\mbox{$\alpha$}}$}\neq\emptyset}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG ≠ ∅. Let m∈𝐍𝑚𝐍m\in{\bf N}italic_m ∈ bold_N be minimal in α^^𝛼\hat{\mbox{$\alpha$}}over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG and let x=r⁢(m)𝑥𝑟𝑚x=r(m)italic_x = italic_r ( italic_m ). Let i∈𝐍𝑖𝐍i\in{\bf N}italic_i ∈ bold_N be such that α=αi−1𝛼subscript𝛼𝑖1\mbox{$\alpha$}=\mbox{$\alpha$}_{i-1}italic_α = italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In particular we have:

(∀y∈𝐑)⁢(y<x⇒r−1⁢(y)∩α^)=∅.for-all𝑦𝐑𝑦𝑥⇒superscript𝑟1𝑦^𝛼(\forall y\in{\bf R})(y<x\Rightarrow r^{-1}(y)\cap\mbox{$\hat{\mbox{$\alpha$}}$})=\emptyset.( ∀ italic_y ∈ bold_R ) ( italic_y < italic_x ⇒ italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_y ) ∩ over^ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG ) = ∅ .

Using the Leibniz principle we get:

{m∣m∈𝐍*,m<h~,𝒰m⊧α}⊆{m∣m∈𝐍*,r*⁢(m)≥x}.conditional-set𝑚formulae-sequence𝑚superscript𝐍formulae-sequence𝑚~ℎmodelssubscript𝒰𝑚𝛼conditional-set𝑚formulae-sequence𝑚superscript𝐍superscript𝑟𝑚𝑥\{m\mid m\in{\bf N}^{*},m<\mbox{$\tilde{h}$},\mbox{${\cal U}$}_{m}\models\mbox{$\alpha$}\}\subseteq\{m\mid m\in{\bf N}^{*},r^{*}(m)\geq x\}.{ italic_m ∣ italic_m ∈ bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_m < over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG , caligraphic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊧ italic_α } ⊆ { italic_m ∣ italic_m ∈ bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) ≥ italic_x } .

Let us define now

η=∑m∈h~,r*⁢(m)>x*⁢f~⁢(m)𝜂subscriptsuperscriptformulae-sequence𝑚~ℎsuperscript𝑟𝑚𝑥~𝑓𝑚\eta=\mbox{$\sum^{*}$}_{m\in\mbox{$\tilde{h}$},r^{*}(m)>x}\mbox{$\tilde{f}$}(m)italic_η = ∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m ∈ over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG , italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) > italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( italic_m )

and

ρ=∑m∈h~,r*⁢(m)=x*⁢f~⁢(m).𝜌subscriptsuperscriptformulae-sequence𝑚~ℎsuperscript𝑟𝑚𝑥~𝑓𝑚\rho=\mbox{$\sum^{*}$}_{m\in\mbox{$\tilde{h}$},r^{*}(m)=x}\mbox{$\tilde{f}$}(m).italic_ρ = ∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m ∈ over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG , italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) = italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( italic_m ) .

For every formula γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ define:

λ⁢(γ)=∑m∈h~,r*⁢(m)=x,𝒰m⊧γ*⁢f~⁢(m)𝜆𝛾subscriptsuperscriptformulae-sequence𝑚~ℎformulae-sequencesuperscript𝑟𝑚𝑥modelssubscript𝒰𝑚𝛾~𝑓𝑚\lambda(\mbox{$\gamma$})=\mbox{$\sum^{*}$}_{m\in\mbox{$\tilde{h}$},r^{*}(m)=x,\,\mbox{${\cal U}$}_{m}\models\mbox{$\gamma$}}\mbox{$\tilde{f}$}(m)italic_λ ( italic_γ ) = ∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m ∈ over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG , italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) = italic_x , caligraphic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊧ italic_γ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( italic_m )

Of course one always has P⁢r⁢(γ)≥λ⁢(γ)𝑃𝑟𝛾𝜆𝛾Pr(\mbox{$\gamma$})\geq\lambda(\mbox{$\gamma$})italic_P italic_r ( italic_γ ) ≥ italic_λ ( italic_γ ). Note that by Equation 23, η/ρ𝜂𝜌\eta/\rhoitalic_η / italic_ρ is infinitesimal. Also by item 5 of the definition of the sequence ⟨Bn∣n∈𝐍⟩inner-productsubscript𝐵𝑛𝑛𝐍\langle B_{n}\mid n\in{\bf N}\rangle⟨ italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ italic_n ∈ bold_N ⟩ if Aγ∩{m∣m∈h~,r*⁢(m)=x}≠∅subscript𝐴𝛾conditional-set𝑚formulae-sequence𝑚~ℎsuperscript𝑟𝑚𝑥A_{\mbox{$\gamma$}}\cap\{m\mid m\in\mbox{$\tilde{h}$},r^{*}(m)=x\}\neq\emptysetitalic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_γ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ { italic_m ∣ italic_m ∈ over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG , italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) = italic_x } ≠ ∅ and if γ=αj−1,j∈𝐍formulae-sequence𝛾subscript𝛼𝑗1𝑗𝐍\mbox{$\gamma$}=\mbox{$\alpha$}_{j-1},j\in{\bf N}italic_γ = italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_j ∈ bold_N then

λ⁢(γ)≥ρ×12j.𝜆𝛾𝜌1superscript2𝑗\lambda(\mbox{$\gamma$})\geq\rho\times\frac{1}{2^{j}}.italic_λ ( italic_γ ) ≥ italic_ρ × divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG .

Now, assume α ∼ β∈Kα ∼ β𝐾\mbox{\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\mbox{$\beta$}}\in Kroman_α ∼ roman_β ∈ italic_K. Hence for every m∈h~𝑚~ℎm\in\mbox{$\tilde{h}$}italic_m ∈ over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG, if 𝒰⊧¬⁢β∧αmodels𝒰𝛽𝛼\mbox{${\cal U}$}\models\neg\mbox{$\beta$}\wedge\mbox{$\alpha$}caligraphic_U ⊧ ¬ italic_β ∧ italic_α, we must have r*⁢(m)>xsuperscript𝑟𝑚𝑥r^{*}(m)>xitalic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) > italic_x. Therefore P⁢r⁢(¬⁢β∧α)≤η𝑃𝑟𝛽𝛼𝜂Pr(\neg\mbox{$\beta$}\wedge\mbox{$\alpha$})\leq\etaitalic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_β ∧ italic_α ) ≤ italic_η. Therefore:

P⁢r⁢(¬⁢β∣α)=P⁢r⁢(¬⁢β∧α)P⁢r⁢(α)≤ηρ×12i=2i×ηρ.𝑃𝑟conditional𝛽𝛼𝑃𝑟𝛽𝛼𝑃𝑟𝛼𝜂𝜌1superscript2𝑖superscript2𝑖𝜂𝜌Pr(\neg\mbox{$\beta$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})=\frac{Pr(\neg\mbox{$\beta$}\wedge\mbox{$\alpha$})}{Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$})}\leq\frac{\eta}{\rho\times\frac{1}{2^{i}}}=2^{i}\times\frac{\eta}{\rho}.italic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_β ∣ italic_α ) = divide start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_β ∧ italic_α ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_α ) end_ARG ≤ divide start_ARG italic_η end_ARG start_ARG italic_ρ × divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG = 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT × divide start_ARG italic_η end_ARG start_ARG italic_ρ end_ARG .

Therefore P⁢r⁢(¬⁢β∣α)𝑃𝑟conditional𝛽𝛼Pr(\neg\mbox{$\beta$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})italic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_β ∣ italic_α ) is infinitesimal and by definition α ∼ β∈K⁢(ℳ)α ∼ β𝐾ℳ\mbox{\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\mbox{$\beta$}}\in K(\mbox{${\cal M}$})roman_α ∼ roman_β ∈ italic_K ( caligraphic_M ). If α ∼ β∉Kα ∼ β𝐾\mbox{\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\mbox{$\beta$}}\not\in Kroman_α ∼ roman_β ∉ italic_K, then some m∈𝐍𝑚𝐍m\in{\bf N}italic_m ∈ bold_N, r*⁢(m)=xsuperscript𝑟𝑚𝑥r^{*}(m)=xitalic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) = italic_x satisfies 𝒰m⊧¬⁢β∧αmodelssubscript𝒰𝑚𝛽𝛼\mbox{${\cal U}$}_{m}\models\neg\mbox{$\beta$}\wedge\mbox{$\alpha$}caligraphic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊧ ¬ italic_β ∧ italic_α. But this m𝑚mitalic_m satisfies m∈h~𝑚~ℎm\in\mbox{$\tilde{h}$}italic_m ∈ over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG, so it is in our model. Let j∈𝐍𝑗𝐍j\in{\bf N}italic_j ∈ bold_N be such that ¬⁢β∧α=αj−1𝛽𝛼subscript𝛼𝑗1\neg\mbox{$\beta$}\wedge\mbox{$\alpha$}=\mbox{$\alpha$}_{j-1}¬ italic_β ∧ italic_α = italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Since we clearly have: P⁢r⁢(α)≤ρ+η𝑃𝑟𝛼𝜌𝜂Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$})\leq\rho+\etaitalic_P italic_r ( italic_α ) ≤ italic_ρ + italic_η, we also have:

P⁢r⁢(¬⁢β∣α)=P⁢r⁢(¬⁢β∧α)P⁢r⁢(α)≥12j×ρρ+η≥12j+1𝑃𝑟conditional𝛽𝛼𝑃𝑟𝛽𝛼𝑃𝑟𝛼1superscript2𝑗𝜌𝜌𝜂1superscript2𝑗1Pr(\neg\mbox{$\beta$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})=\frac{Pr(\neg\mbox{$\beta$}\wedge\mbox{$\alpha$})}{Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$})}\geq\frac{\frac{1}{2^{j}}\times\rho}{\rho+\eta}\geq\frac{1}{2^{j+1}}italic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_β ∣ italic_α ) = divide start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_β ∧ italic_α ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_α ) end_ARG ≥ divide start_ARG divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG × italic_ρ end_ARG start_ARG italic_ρ + italic_η end_ARG ≥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG

since obviously ρ≥η𝜌𝜂\rho\geq\etaitalic_ρ ≥ italic_η. So P⁢r⁢(¬⁢β∣α)𝑃𝑟conditional𝛽𝛼Pr(\neg\mbox{$\beta$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})italic_P italic_r ( ¬ italic_β ∣ italic_α ) is not infinitesimal and α ∼ β∉K⁢(ℳ)α ∼ β𝐾ℳ\mbox{\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\mbox{$\beta$}}\not\in K(\mbox{${\cal M}$})roman_α ∼ roman_β ∉ italic_K ( caligraphic_M ). (end of proof of Claim 1)     

We have already noticed that ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M is a neat model. Claim 1 shows that it has the desired property. (end of proof of Theorem 11)
